SubjectName: Asian Canadian and Asian Migration Studies
name: Selected Topics in ACAM Studies - ACAM CDN HEALTH
description: Selected Asian Canadian Asian Migration topics. Consult acam.arts.ubc.ca for this year's offerings.
prerequisite: (Restricted to students with at least Second year standing; a previous course in Asian Canadian and Asian Migration Studies is recommended.)

SubjectName: Asian Canadian and Asian Migration Studies
name: Asian Canadians in Popular Culture
description: Popular culture's role in the production of Asian Canadian and diasporic communities, with emphasis on race, gender, sexuality, and other identity categories.

SubjectName: Asian Canadian and Asian Migration Studies
name: Dis/Orienting Asian Canada
description: The histories, cultures, social dynamics, and life experiences of Asian communities in Canada in the context of global migrations. Restricted to students with second year status or higher.

SubjectName: Asian Canadian and Asian Migration Studies
name: Asian Canadian Community-Based Media
description: Digital media production in the context of community engagement. Includes critical media literacy, community-based research ethics, project design, training in media forms such audio, video, photography, and web publishing.

name: Animal Welfare and Animal Ethics
description: Credit will be granted for only one of APBI 315, ANSC 515, or AANB 515.

name: Research Methodology in Applied Animal Biology
Institutions of Adult Education
description: The history, roles, and activities of institutions in the field of adult education.  Institutions in Canada, Great Britain, and the United States are emphasized, and some experiences in other countries are examined.

name: Developing Short Courses, Workshops and Seminars
description: Organization and administration of adult education events such as short courses, seminars, workshops, conferences and institutes.

name: Teaching Adults
description: Planning, conducting and evaluating instruction for adults.  Consideration is given to different beliefs and ways of thinking about teaching.

name: An Overview of Adult Education
description: Survey of adult education theory and practice in Canada and the world. The focus is on the purpose and participation in, adult education, characteristics of learners, and the training of adult educators.

name: The Community Practice of Adult Education
description: Community based adult education with particular emphasis on the application of knowledge of the social, economic, cultural and political environment in developing and conducting adult education programs with an for individuals and groups.

name: Introduction to African Studies - INTRO AFRI STUDY
description: Cultural, historical, and geographical issues of African Studies.

name: Perspectives in African Studies: Literary and Theoretical Approaches - PRSPCTV: LIT&THR
description: Major issues and theoretical approaches.

name: Perspectives in African Studies: A Social Science Approach - PRSPCTV: SOC SCI
description: Major issues and theoretical approaches.

name: Literatures and Cultures of Africa and/or the Middle East - LIT CULT AFRC ME
description: Literary and cultural works from Africa; some sections include Africa and the Middle East. Multiple perspectives on local, national, and global issues including colonialism, migration, transnationalism, education, art and politics. May include fiction, poetry, drama, digital media, and other forms. Consult department website for current year's offerings.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing and 3 credits from one of (a) 100-level ENGL or (b) 200-level ENGL or (c) ARTS 001 or (d) ASTU 100 or (e) ASTU 101 or (f) WRDS 150 or (g) WRDS 350. 6 credits of 100- and/or 200-level English courses is recommended. Prerequisites must be met by the first day of class or students will be withdrawn.)

name: Directed Studies in Anatomy - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Permission of the Head and supervisor required.

name: Directed Studies in Anatomy - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Permission of the Head and supervisor required.

name: Gross Anatomy of the Limbs and Trunk
description: Lectures and laboratory sessions on the human gross and functional anatomy of the limbs and trunk. The course includes the study of predissected specimens. For credit only in the Department of Physical Therapy.

name: Cell Structure and Function
description: Seminar discussions of current topics in vertebrate cell biology.

name: Fundamentals of Body Design: Basic Principles in Human Anatomy as Illustrated by the Organization of the Back and Upper Limb
Directed Studies in Anatomy - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Permission of the Head and supervisor required.

name: Functional Human Anatomy of the Urogenital Systems: Pelvis and Perineum
Functional Human Anatomy of the Respiratory, Cardiovascular and Gastrointestinal Systems of the Thorax and Abdomen
Functional Human Anatomy of Head and Neck Systems
Functional Human Anatomy of the Musculoskeletal Systems: Back, Limbs and Joints
Functional Human Neuroanatomy: Central Nervous System
Functional Human Microscopic Anatomy: Basic Tissues, Organs and Systems
Directed Studies in Anatomy and Cell Biology - DIRECTED STUDIES
Muscle Biophysics
description: Selected topics in muscle contraction at an advanced level Permission of Head required.

name: Directed Studies in Anatomy and Cell Biology - DIRECTED STUDIES
Directed Studies in Anatomy and Cell Biology - DIRECTED STUDIES
Current Topics in the Morphological Sciences
description: Lectures, demonstrations, discussions and student seminars on selected and current topics in cell biology and the anatomical sciences. Attendance is required of all M.Sc. and Ph.D. students in Anatomy and Cell Biology.
prerequisite: (Students must be registered in graduate-level studies in Anatomy & Cell Biology.)

name: Directed Studies in Anatomy and Cell Biology - DIRECTED STUDIES
Introduction to Functional Human Anatomy: Survey of Microscopic Anatomy, Neuroanatomy and Gross Anatomy
Contemporary Social Problems - ANTH CON SOC PRB
description: Cultural background to contemporary events; problems of nationalism and regional conflicts, economic and social development, gender, religion and social change. Course may stress a different region of the world in different years.

name: Ethnic Relations - ETHNIC RELATIONS
description: An introduction to the study of the relations between ethnic groups and of the interplay between ethnicity and other social factors.

name: Introduction to Cultural Anthropology - INTRO CULT ANTH
description: Basic concepts and methods of anthropology; culture and race; comparative study of social systems, religion, symbolism, art, and other institutions. Examples are drawn from a variety of cultures.

name: Anthropology of Drugs
description: Illicit and/or licit drugs through historical, political, cultural and societal examples.

name: Eating Culture
description: An anthropological exploration of how the collection, cultivation and consumption of food shapes human society and culture.

name: Witches, Vampires, and Zombies: Anthropology of the Supernatural
description: Anthropological approaches to supernatural beliefs in both traditional and contemporary societies.

name: Sex, Gender, and Culture
description: An anthropological exploration of how understandings of sex and gender are culturally and historically shaped.

name: Japanese Popular Culture
description: Television shows, dramas, movies, advertising, marketing, manga (Japanese style "comics"), anime (Japanese animation), theatrical forms, popular literature, popular music, fashion fads, tourism, toys, and sports.

name: Culture and Communication
description: The study of communication; the relation between communication and its cultural context with emphasis on verbal and non-verbal communication, cross-cultural communication, and cultural differences in the use of oral, literate, and electronic media.

name: Introduction to Medical Anthropology
description: An examination of health and illness, in their social and cultural contexts.

name: Contemporary Anthropological Theory - CONTMP ANTH THRY
description: Contemporary approaches to society and culture in anthropology.

name: Ethnography of Special Areas - ETHNO SPEC AREAS
description: A specialized study of ethnographic and theoretical problems in one area. Different culture areas or regions may be selected each term. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

name: Ethnography of the Northwest Coast - ETHNOG NW COAST
description: Specialized study of ethnographic and theoretical problems of the region.

name: Anthropology of Gender
description: Theoretical approaches to, and the ethnographic study of, gender in cross-cultural contexts.

name: Japanese Culture and Society
description: Japanese culture and society: patterns of organization, value systems, family, education, work, minorities and diversity, harmony and conflict, urban/rural differences, gender, sexuality, youth, tradition, continuity, change, and future prospects.

name: Linguistic Anthropology - LINGUISTIC ANTH
description: A survey of the ethnographic uses of language data and the techniques of linguistic analysis.

name: Art, Aesthetics and Anthropology - ART&ANTHROPOLOGY
description: Anthropological perspectives on art, aesthetics, and expressive culture.

name: Museums, Heritage and Memory - MUSE HERITG MEM
description: Museums, galleries, monuments, and other cultural institutions' relations to our perception of history and geography.

name: Oral Tradition
description: An ethnographic perspective on the dynamics of oral tradition in various oral and literate cultures; the characteristics and roles of oral genres including folktale, genealogy, oral history, autobiography, and myth in these societies; and the relationship between orality and literacy.

name: Anthropology of Media
description: Analysis of contemporary mass media and of the anthropological use of media (photography, film, digital audio and video, etc.).

name: Introduction to Ecological Anthropology
description: Analysis of the relations between human societies and the ecological aspects of their environment (including technology, society, and ideology).  Previously ANTH 460.

name: Ethnography of the Pacific Islands: Melanesia - ETHNO: MELANESIA
description: Major cultural groupings in Melanesia, emphasizing both traditional cultures and the incorporation of the region into modern international institutions.

name: History of Anthropology - HISTORY OF ANTH
description: The development of anthropological theory and practice in institutional contexts.

name: Principles of Field Work
description: An examination of field work as the basic setting for ethnographic research. Research design; relationships with study participants, field techniques, and data analysis and presentation.

name: Anthropological Statistics
description: Applications of statistical techniques to quantitative and qualitative data in Anthropology.

name: Museum Practice and Curatorship - MUS PRC&CURATRSH
description: Management of museum collections and their public presentation, addressing questions of access, collaboration, and cultural property. The public interpretation of anthropological concepts and materials utilizing the programs and facilities of the Museum of Anthropology.

name: Topics in Medical Anthropology
description: Anthropological perspectives on health, illness, and disability as represented by classic and contemporary research in selected topics in medical anthropology including disease and human evolution, illness and human ecology, culture and epidemiology, ethnomedical systems, the relationship between folk and biomedicine and the cultural construction and social organization of health care, illness and disability. Specific content will vary from year to year. Consult the Department brochure.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under the supervision, of a Department faculty member selected by the student. No more than six credits of Directed Studies may be taken for credit toward the Major or Honours program.

name: Honours Tutorial - HONOURS TUTORIAL
description: Will usually require the presentation of at least one research paper.

name: Anthropology of Law
description: Cross-cultural study of the operation of law within contested systems of meaning, the social organization of law, and forms of consciousness of the participants in legal/justice practices.

name: History of Anthropological Thought
description: Various approaches to anthropology, from classical to contemporary.

name: Current Research in Anthropology - CURRENT RES ANTH
description: The relationship between current theoretical issues and research methods.

name: Qualitative Methods in Anthropology
description: A discussion of selected methods used to observe, describe, and interpret cultural phenomena and social organization, including participant observation, interviewing, ethnographic semantics, life histories, componential analysis, and photography. Attention will also be given to ethics in anthropological research and writing and to such analytic matters as the nature of description, conceptualization, generalization, and content analysis.

name: Graduate Research Seminar - GRAD RSRCH SEM
Graduate Research Seminar - GRAD RSRCH SEM
Graduate Research Seminar - GRAD RSRCH SEM
Organizational Leadership
description: Behaviour of people and groups and its application to management and leadership within professional organizations; motivation, group dynamics, and organizational structure; leadership styles and effectiveness; assessing organizational effectiveness. Collaboratively delivered with the Faculty of Commerce and Business Administration.

name: Project Management and Leadership
description: Leading complex multi-disciplinary projects through management processes; project management frameworks, standards; core management processes of planning, scheduling, estimating, survey of communication, risk, and management issues; case studies in industry-relevant project management. Collaboratively delivered with the Faculty of Commerce and Business Administration.

name: Sustainability and Leadership
description: Skills for leading change that influences triple-bottom-line; sustainability, change agency systems thinking; awareness and perspective for engagement and communication; adaptive leadership; change dynamics; cases studies in organizational and social change. Collaboratively delivered with the Faculty of Commerce and Business Administration.

name: Analytics and Interpretation for Applied Sciences
description: Relevant measurable metrics of a project; data interpretation techniques; introduction to data visualization; overview of big data and predictive analytics; strategies related to metrics and data, ethical and privacy concerns. Collaboratively delivered with the Faculty of Commerce and Business Administration.

name: Capstone Project - CAPSTONE PROJECT
description: A capstone design project designed to give students experience in leading complex multidisciplinary projects relevant to their professional specialization. Collaboratively delivered with the Faculty of Commerce and Business Administration.

name: Co-operative Education Work Term I
description: Supervised, technical work integrated learning experience in a public or private organization for a minimum of three months. Formal co-op assignments required. Restricted to undergraduate students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: Introduction to Engineering I
description: An introduction to the engineering profession including: roles and responsibilities of the engineer, the engineering disciplines, sustainability, an introduction to the engineering design process, introduction and application of the relevant foundational scientific principles, prototyping, engineering graphics, technical communication, and engineering ethics.

name: Introduction to Engineering II
description: An introduction to the engineering profession including: the engineering design process, sustainability, prototype testing, introduction and application of the relevant foundational scientific principles, team functioning, engineering graphics, and technical communication.

name: Engineering Analysis I
description: Functions, limits, differentiation, applications of derivatives, integration, applications of definite integrals.

name: Introduction to Computation in Engineering Design
description: Analysis and simulation, laboratory data acquisition and processing, measurement interfaces, engineering tools, computer systems organization, programming languages. Credit will only be given for one of: APSC 160, CPSC 301, or EOSC 211.

name: Electricity, Magnetism, and Waves
description: Coulomb's law, electric field, Gauss' law, electric potential, conductors, capacitance, electric currents, resistance, DC circuits, magnetic fields and forces, sources of magnetic fields, electromagnetic induction, mechanical waves, electromagnetic waves, light propagation, geometrical optics.

name: Matter and Energy I
description: Thermometry, states of matter and phase change, ideal and real gases, 1st law of thermodynamics, 2nd law of thermodynamics, liquids, solutions.

name: Engineering Analysis II
description: Integrals and transcendental functions, techniques of integration, applications of integration, polar coordinates, infinite sequences and series, vectors and the geometry of space, and partial derivatives.

name: Matter and Energy II
description: Atomic structures and bonding, solid crystals, chemical equilibrium, reactions in gas phase and in aqueous solutions, acid-base and redox reactions, kinetics of chemical reactions, thermochemistry, electrochemistry.

name: Co-operative Education Work Term
description: Supervised, technical work integrated learning experience in a public or private organization for a minimum of three months. Formal co-op assignments required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: Technical Communication
description: Written and oral communication in engineering. Report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation of technical material. Credit will be granted for only one of BMEG 201, CHBE 201, CIVL 203, CPEN 281, ELEC 281, IGEN 201, MANU 201, MECH 226, MTRL 201, or APSC 201.
prerequisite: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150.

name: Technology and Society I
description: The course deals with the influence of technology on the social, political, economic, and environmental aspects of society. The specific subject matter varies from year to year. Examples of subjects considered include, resources, energy, nuclear power, technology, the effects of technology on the family, education, agriculture, international policy and others.

name: Technology and Society II
description: The course deals with the influence of technology on the social, political, economic and environmental aspects of society. The subject matter varies from year to year and differs from APSC 261. It may be taken as a continuation of APSC 261 or taken independently. Examples of subjects considered include pollution, work place health hazards, social impact of computers, problem solving, green revolution, technology and the third world, engineering ethics and others.

name: Engineering Materials
description: Atomic bonding; crystal structures and imperfections; properties of metals, ceramics, polymers, wood, concrete and fibre composite materials; selection of materials; corrosion; mechanical testing and heat treatment.

name: Engineering Materials Laboratory
description: Atomic bonding; crystal structures and imperfections; properties of metals, ceramics, polymers, wood, concrete and fibre composite materials; selection of materials; corrosion; mechanical testing and heat treatment.

name: Co-operative Education Work Term
description: Supervised, technical work integrated learning experience in a public or private organization for a minimum of three months. Formal co-op assignments required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: The Art of the Possible: An Introduction to Engineering for Non-Engineers
description: An introduction to engineering for the non-specialist. A case-studies approach includes examples from sustainability-related technology, consumer products, structures, and energy conversion.

name: Nuclear Weapons and Arms Control
description: The evolution and contemporary significance of nuclear weapons and arms control policy and technology from the perspective of the physical and life sciences and the social sciences and humanities.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing in B.A. or B.Sc. programs, or second-year standing in B.A.Sc. program.)

name: Prototyping
description: Systematic approach and use of tools for prototyping.  Using software, electronics, and physical components for practical advancement of initiatives in innovation, product development market identification, and problem solving.

name: Living Language: Science and Society
description: Multi-disciplinary course in which students, individually and in groups, examine, integrate and apply subject-specific knowledge through the lens of language and the framework of the language sciences, with a focus on themes of real-world importance.
prerequisite: (Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.)

name: Co-operative Education Work Term
description: Supervised, technical work integrated learning experience in a public or private organization for a minimum of three months. Formal co-op assignments required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: Co-operative Education Work Term
description: Supervised, technical work integrated learning experience in a public or private organization for a minimum of three months. Formal co-op assignments required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: Co-operative Education Work Term
description: Supervised, technical work integrated learning experience in a public or private organization for a minimum of three months. Formal co-op assignments required. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education Program.

name: Management Fundamentals for Technology-Based Product Marketing and Development
description: Management topics are presented from the perspective of technology-based industrial practice; project management, marketing and marketing planning, product development and commercialization, introduction to quality management, teamwork and effective individual participation.

name: Professional Engineering Practice
description: Legislation affecting the practice of engineering; ethical principles and responsibilities. Management of engineering enterprises; labour relations, safety and environmental legislation. Restricted to engineering undergraduate students in the final year of their program.

name: Interdisciplinary Engineering Design Project - INTER ENG PRJECT
description: Projects involving students from several departments.

name: New Venture Design
description: Teams comprising students in APSC 486 and COMM 486 create a business plan and a prototype or engineering solution of a novel product, process, or process component.

name: Interdisciplinary Engineering Design Project - INTER ENG PRJECT
description: Projects involving students from several departments.

name: Co-op Work Term II
description: Supervised, technical paid work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 12 weeks full-time. Co-op assignment(s) required. Restricted to graduate degree students meeting requirement(s) of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education program.

name: Co-op Work Term I
description: Supervised, technical paid work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 12 weeks full-time. Co-op assignment(s) required. Restricted to graduate degree students meeting requirement(s) of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education program.

name: Co-op Work Term III
description: Supervised, technical paid work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 12 weeks full-time. Co-op assignment(s) required. Restricted to graduate degree students meeting requirement(s) of the Faculty of Applied Science and the Co-operative Education program.

name: Entrepreneurial Thinking for Applied Scientists
description: Issues and case studies in creating and running ventures, with a particular emphasis on exploring applied science projects through a new venture lens, strategic planning, finance and risk.

name: Technology Entrepreneurship for Engineers
description: A broad introduction to the entrepreneurial process, for engineers who would like to form or grow a technology company, and those with a general interest in the field. Key factors of new venture creation are identified and evaluated.

name: Finfish Genetics and Reproduction in Aquaculture
Beginning Classical and Quranic Arabic I
description: Classical Arabic, with an introduction to vocabulary and grammar and the reading of simple Qur'anic texts and wisdom sayings in the original.

name: Beginning Classical and Quranic Arabic II
description: Classical Arabic, with further introduction to vocabulary and grammar and the reading of Qur'anic texts in the original.

name: Intermediate Classical and Quranic Arabic II
description: Classical Arabic. Designed to further enrich vocabulary and grammar and to enhance fluency in reading and interpreting longer texts from Qur'an, Hadith and other genres.

name: Intermediate Classical and Quranic Arabic I
description: Classical Arabic. Designed to enrich vocabulary and grammar and to enhance fluency in reading and interpreting a range of Qur'anic texts.

name: Atmospheric Environments
description: Physical principles underlying weather and climates. Thermal, moisture and wind climates from the scale of plants and animals to the globe. Daily weather systems and climate change. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOB 200, GEOB 204 or APBI 244.

name: Introduction to Soil Science
description: Physical, chemical and biological properties of soils; soil formation, classification, use and conservation. There are no prerequisites for this course, but background in Biology 12, Chemistry 12, and Physics 12 (or first-year university-level) is strongly advised. Credit will only be granted for one of APBI 100 or APBI 200.

name: Vascular Plants
description: A comparative study of pteridophytes, gymnosperms and angiosperms, integrating form, function, and ecology.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. (Or (c) 7 credits of first-year biology.)

name: Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
description: Principles and practices necessary to understand practical concerns of sustainable food systems.  Students who already present credit for APBI 260 are not permitted to receive credit for APBI 265.

name: Agroecology I: Introduction to principles and techniques
description: Biophysical and socioeconomic factors affecting systems management and production in selected agroecosystems.

name: Introductory Topics in Applied Biology
description: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in applied biology. Topics will vary from year to year.

name: Comparative Cardiovascular, Respiratory and Osmoregulatory Physiology
description: Cardiovascular, respiratory and osmoregulatory physiology of vertebrates.
prerequisite: BIOL 204 and one of BIOL 260, BIOL 361. (And 3rd year standing.)

name: Reproductive and Digestive Physiology
description: Reproductive and digestive physiology, and current technologies applied to these systems in domestic and wild animals.
prerequisite: One of BIOL 204, BIOL 260. (3rd year standing.)

name: Animals and Society
description: Contemporary use of animals for food production, companionship, recreation and science; social and ethical issues concerning human impacts on animals; animals in human culture; protection of animals by society and the law.
prerequisite: (At least third-year standing in any faculty.)

name: Animal Welfare and the Ethics of Animal Use
description: Scientific assessment of animal well-being, ethical concepts applied to animal use, and animal welfare issues arising in agriculture, biomedical research and other areas. Credit will be granted for only one of APBI 315, ANSC 515, or AANB 515.
prerequisite: (At least third-year standing in any faculty.)

name: Equine Biology, Health and Welfare
description: Anatomy, physiology, reproduction, nutrition of the horse; common disease pathology, prevention and treatments; equine behaviour.

name: Welfare and Ethics of using Animals in Science
description: Historical and current debate, ethical perspectives, governance, and scientific understanding of experiences of animals in research.

name: Applied Plant Breeding
description: Small-scale classical (i.e., non-biotechnological) plant breeding. Hands-on, application-oriented approach to techniques and procedures for managing seed inventories, designing and implementing a simple plant breeding program, and evaluating the impact of selection on breeding populations and desired outcomes.

name: Aquaculture and the Environment
description: Interactions between aquaculture and the environment. Current issues, comparison of systems, species, production methods, environments, and socioeconomics.
prerequisite: One of BIOL 230, APBI 260, APBI 265, CONS 330, ENVR 200, ENVR 300. (and third year standing. Or permission of the instructor.)

name: Horticultural Techniques
description: Horticulture theory and methodology in an experiential learning format. Plant identification, seeding, propagation, canopy management, cultivation media, horticultural systems examined in the context of integrated crop management.

name: Introduction to Seed Plant Taxonomy
description: Introduction to seed plant taxonomy emphasizing descriptive morphology and identification. Each student will be required to submit a plant collection.

name: Weed Science
description: Importance, identification, dissemination and biology of weeds; preventive, cultural, biological and chemical methods of control.

name: Introduction to Entomology
description: A survey of the structure, classification and biology of insects; ecology and life-histories of insects; insect-plant relations.

name: Soil Biology
description: The diversity of soil organisms (bacteria, protozoa, fungi, animals, plants) in natural and managed ecosystems; roles in primary production, nutrient cycling, decomposition and reclamation; interactions between soil organisms; responses to environmental change.

name: Plant Physiology
description: Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants.
prerequisite: BIOL 121 and either (a) CHEM 123 or (b) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113. (CHEM 233 is recommended.)

name: Agroecology II: Application and analysis
description: Animals and Plants as Components of Agricultural Ecosystems. A systems approach is used to investigate the functions and interactions of plants and animals in agricultural systems.

name: Key Indicators of Agroecosystem Sustainability
description: A detailed exploration of biophysical, economic, and social ecosystem sustainability indicators for primary production subsystems.

name: Research Methods in Applied Biology
description: Research methods including research design, scientific critique, writing proposals and reports, and oral presentation.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing in the Applied Biology program and permission of the instructor.)

name: Soil Processes
description: Integration of soil physics, chemistry, and biology in understanding essential soil processes.

name: Stress and Coping in Animals
description: Understanding, assessing, and managing stress in farm, companion, captive wildlife, and research animals: sources of stress; behavioural, emotional, cognitive, and physiological responses; effects on growth, reproduction, health.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing or higher. APBI 315 and courses in animal physiology and animal behavior recommended.)

name: Applied Animal Health and Physiology
description: Application of physiology and pathology principles to health and disease of domestic animals.
prerequisite: BIOL 201 and one of APBI 311, CAPS 301.

name: Animals and Global Issues
description: Research seminar integrating diverse information to address global animal issues including: animal-source foods and human health, environmental impact of livestock production, trade in exotic animals.

name: Applied Animal Behaviour
description: Application of principles and research methods of animal behaviour to practical problems in the care of farm, companion, wild and research animals, and in animal training, and human-wildlife conflict.

name: Intensive Fish Production
description: Management of fin fish throughout the life cycle; broodstock, egg, larvae, and juvenile. Control of environmental factors, including pathogens, for maximum productivity at all life stages.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing or higher. One of APBI 311, BIOL 204 or BIOL 260. APBI 312 recommended.)

name: Compassionate Conservation
description: Evaluation of humane treatment of individual animals living in the wild and managed within conservation biology. Assessment of attitudes and viewpoints of the role of animal welfare in conservation biology.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing or higher. APBI 315 and BIOL 416 or CONS 330 recommended.)

name: Ecological Restoration
description: Ecological principles relevant to restoration of ecosystems are applied to the restoration of several types of ecosystems.
prerequisite: APBI 200 and one of FRST 201, APBI 260, BIOL 230.

name: Fish Health
description: Management of fish health in aquaculture; common fish pathogens, epidemiology, prevention, and treatment of diseases.
prerequisite: (Third year standing or higher. One of APBI 311, BIOL 204 or BIOL 260. APBI 312 and APBI 418 strongly recommended.)

name: Plant-Microbe Interactions
description: Biology and physiology of selected plant-microbe relationships. Impacts of plant-microbe relationships on society.
prerequisite: BIOL 200 and one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203, BIOL 201, BIOL 233, BIOL 234, BIOL 260.

name: Insect Ecology
description: Behavioural, population, and community ecology of insects. Interaction between insects and plants and the application of the principals of insect ecology to biological control of insects and weeds.
prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 205 or (b) all of BIOL 327, APBI 327.

name: Integrated Pest Management
description: Development and implementation of multi-disciplinary pest management programs in agricultural crops.

name: Plant Genomics
description: Concepts, principles, and recent discoveries in genome structure and comparative genomics in plants with a focus on economically important plants; applications of genomics approaches to questions in plant genetics, evolution, and ecology.

name: Wine Grape and Berry Biology
description: Grapevine genetics, morphology, and physiology and major biological features of other important berry crops for British Columbia such as blueberry, cranberry, and raspberry. Credit will be granted for only one of APBI 442, APBI 443, or PLNT 542.
prerequisite: All of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 and one of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, APBI 210, BIOL 210.

name: Agroforestry
description: An introduction to the application of knowledge and principles of agroecology and forest ecology to global agroforestry systems. The course includes a one-weekend field trip that requires a supplemental fee.
prerequisite: (An undergraduate course in ecology or equivalent.)

name: Agroecology III: Synthesis and evaluation
description: The relationship between biological diversity and sustainability in food producing agroecosystems; emphasis on ecological similarities between natural ecosystems and managed  agroecosystems.

name: Capstone in Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
description: Integrates classroom and applied learning at the UBC Farm with design project.

name: Advanced Topics in Applied Biology
description: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in applied biology.

name: Applied Animal Biology Practicum - APBI PRACTICUM
description: Application of principles and concepts of Applied Animal Biology to experiential learning in the fields of wild, companion, lab, and farm animal welfare and management.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing or higher. APBI 314 and/or APBI 315 are recommended.)

name: Human Wildlife Conflict
description: Evaluation of the impacts of human wildlife conflicts on wildlife populations; application of innovative methods to reduce human wildlife conflicts.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing or higher. BIOL 230 or FRST 395 and APBI 315 or APBI 416 recommended.)

name: Applied Animal Biology Practicum - APBI PRACTICUM
description: Application of principles and concepts of Applied Animal Biology to experiential learning in the fields of wild, companion, lab, and farm animal welfare and management.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing or higher. APBI 314 and/or APBI 315 are recommended.)

name: Undergraduate Essay
description: Preparation of a comprehensive and analytical review of an approved topic under the supervision of a faculty member. Consultation with a program advisor is required.

name: Undergraduate Thesis
description: Design and execution of an experimental/analytical research project leading to the preparation of a thesis.
prerequisite: (Approval of a program advisor; consult before the end of classes in third year.)

name: Sustainable Soil Management
description: Application of fundamental, unifying, soil science principles in sustainable ecosystem management.

name: Introduction to Archaeology
description: Survey of world archaeology, from the emergence of humankind to the beginning of state societies.

name: Bones: The Origins of Humanity
description: The origin and evolution of the human lineage and the emergence of human biological and cultural traits with emphasis on the fossil record before the Pleistocene. Credit will be granted for only one of ARCL 140 or ANTH 225.

name: Archaeological Methods
description: Introduces the methods and principles applied in anthropological archaeology and cultural-historical research.

name: Controlling Nature: Plant and Animal Domestication
description: How, when and why humans became dependent on cultivated foods and domestic animals and the methods used to document plant and animal domestication.

name: Forensic Anthropology
description: The application of methods from biological anthropology and archaeology to the identification, recovery, and analysis of skeletal remains from crime scenes, mass disasters, and unexplained deaths.

name: Archaeological Interpretation
description: Current theoretical developments explored through the practice of archaeology. Examples drawn from a range of times and places focusing on emerging technologies, food production, colonial encounters and culture contact, materiality and symbolic systems, social inequality and complexity, and human-environmental interactions.

name: The Archaeology of Collapse and Sustainability
description: An evaluation of the issues of sustainability and collapse of ecological and social systems through the archaeological study of the past.

name: Archaeological Foundations of East and Southeast Asia
description: Survey of the archaeology of East and Southeast Asia, with an emphasis on the beginnings of the economic, social, political, and artistic traditions and systems of the great civilizations, and the conditions in which they arose. Theories of cultural development emphasizing Neolithic and state-level societies will be discussed.

name: Paleoanthropology
description: Origin and development of the hominins; the hominin fossil record, and theories relating to hominin evolution.

name: Archaeological and Anthropological Mapping
description: Current methods in mapping spatial information in archaeology and related subfields of anthropology.

name: Molecular Archaeology
description: Molecular techniques in archaeology and their application to anthropological and archaeological research.

name: Analytical Techniques in Archaeology - LAB TECH ARCHEGY
description: A survey of methods and techniques in the interpretation of archaeological data; practical experience in processing and analyzing archaeological materials by means of a research project. Students will prepare manuscripts, drawings and photographs for publication and will learn the basics of lithic and faunal analyses.

name: The Archaeology of Death
description: A survey of methods, theory, and case-studies in mortuary archaeology.

name: Topics in Architectural History II (1900-Present) - ARC+SUBJECTIVITY
description: History of architecture in the post-1900 time period. Technological, political, social, and economic changes which have influenced architecture and related fields.

name: Topics in Architectural History I (Pre-1900) - ARC + DISEASE
description: History of architecture in the pre-1900 time period. Technological, political, social, and economic changes that have influenced architecture and related fields.

name: Topics in Architectural History I (Pre-1900) - EMPIRE BUILDING
description: History of architecture in the pre-1900 time period. Technological, political, social, and economic changes that have influenced architecture and related fields.

name: Materials and Methods of Construction
description: An investigation of building materials and systems considering design objectives, environmental conditions, historical context, regulatory controls, and economic constraints. The major building systems of light wood frame, steel, and concrete and the technical and expressive opportunities inherent in each. Credit will be granted for only one of ARCH 411 or DES 232. Restricted to B.En.D. students.

name: Architectural Design Studio I
description: A series of projects focusing on conceptual development, design synthesis, principles of typology, organization and representation.

name: Introductory Workshop
description: Commences in August the two weeks prior to Labour Day. Enrolment mandatory for all incoming students. A non-refundable fee will charged to cover expenses. Credit will be granted for only one of ARCH 502 or LARC 511.

name: Topics in Architectural History I (Pre-1900) - EMPIRE BUILDING
description: History of architecture in the pre-1900 time period. Technological, political, social, and economic changes that have influenced architecture and related fields.

name: Topics in Architectural History I (Pre-1900) - ARC + DISEASE
description: History of architecture in the pre-1900 time period. Technological, political, social, and economic changes that have influenced architecture and related fields.

name: Topics in Architectural History II (1900-Present) - ARC+SUBJECTIVITY
description: History of architecture in the post-1900 time period. Technological, political, social, and economic changes which have influenced architecture and related fields.

name: Architectural Technology I
description: Architectural technology, including materials and methods, construction types, and building system integration. Strong emphasis on enclosure performance with focus on smaller buildings and light wood framing construction.

name: Structures I
description: Quantitative and qualitative means for understanding of statics, materials and flow of force through a structure.

name: Design Media I
description: Foundations of manual and digital skills and concepts employing a variety of subjects, techniques and software. Credit will be granted for only one of ARCH 515, DES 211 or ENDS 320.

name: Environmental Systems and Controls I
description: Building form and fabric considerations to assure appropriate thermal, luminous, sonic, and atmospheric conditions within buildings.

name: Design Media II
description: Intermediate manual and digital skills and concepts employing a variety of subjects, techniques and software. Credit will be granted for only one of ARCH 517, ARCH 437 or DES 212.

name: Architectural Design Studio IV
prerequisite: All of ARCH 500, ARCH 501, ARCH 520, ARCH 511, ARCH 512, ARCH 513, ARCH 531.

name: Contemporary Theories in Architecture
description: Theoretical propositions and their built manifestations.

name: Architectural Technology II
description: Analysis and design of advanced assemblies. Integration of multiple building systems within a wide range of construction types, and more complex enclosures in a variety of climatic conditions. Emphasis on technical performance, durability and sustainability.

name: Architectural Structures II
description: Complex multi-span and continuous systems: effective material configuration, approximate methods of analysis, selection of appropriate structural systems, earthquake configuration and high rises.

name: Environmental Systems and Controls II
description: Mechanical and electrical services of buildings and their integration with architectural form and fabric.

name: Seminar: Contemporary Practice
description: Topics across a range of practice related subject matter.

name: Seminar in Architecture - INDIG RES MTHDS
description: An exploration of selected topics in architecture. Enrolment is limited to facilitate discussion.

name: Professional Practice
description: Ethical, legal and business context of professional practice, including contracts, project management.

name: Directed Studies in Architecture - DRECTD STDY ARCH
description: Directed research and exploration of selected topics in architecture.

name: Directed Studies in Architecture - DRECTD STDY ARCH
description: Directed research and exploration of selected topics in architecture.

name: Graduate Project Part I
description: Preparation of a graduation design project including literature review.

name: Graduate Project Part II
description: Design component, completion, and defense of the graduation design project.
prerequisite: ARCH 548. (and no more than 18 credits outstanding beyond ARCH 549)

name: Co-operative Education - CO-OP EDUC I
description: Approved and supervised work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of one academic term. Technical report required.

name: Co-operative Education - CO-OP EDUC II
description: Approved and supervised work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of one academic term. Technical report required.

name: Research Methods
description: Contemporary concerns and issues associated with research in architecture and landscape architecture.

name: Seminar: Technology and Analysis - THE STAIRCASE
description: Topics across a range of building material and construction technology-based subject matter.

name: Seminar: Technology and Analysis - CRFT ARCH DTLNG
description: Topics across a range of building material and construction technology-based subject matter.

name: Green Building Contemporary Practice
description: Enhanced building environmental performance and the integration of green building principles, strategies and technologies.

name: Regenerative Development
description: The relationship between human and natural systems in the context of regenerative design. Provides an understanding of how regenerative approaches differ from green design and how they can offer new insights and directions for design.

name: Research Thesis
description: Restricted to M.A.S.A. candidates.

name: Special Topics - THEMES IN ARC
description: Individual or small group study of special topics.

name: Arts Co-op Search Term #2
description: Search term to obtain second work term. Completion of self-assessment, individual coaching sessions, and minimum number of job applications required. Students apply for jobs and go for interviews until they are hired. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.

name: Arts Co-op Work Term #1
description: Approved and supervised work experience with a non-profit, public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Reflective assignments required. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.

name: Arts Co-op Search Term #1
description: Search term to obtain first work term. Completion of pre-employment workshops, group and individual coaching sessions on job search processes, and minimum number of job applications required.  Students apply for jobs and go for interviews until they are hired. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-op Program.
prerequisite: (Completion of Writing Component of Arts Writing and Research Requirement strongly recommended.)

name: Arts Co-op Work Term #2
description: Approved and supervised work experience with a non-profit, public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Reflective assignments required. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTC 210 or 211. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.

name: Arts Co-op Work Term #2 (Extension)
description: Extension of co-op term with the same employer as ARTC 110 for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Reflective assignments required. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTC 210 or 211. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.

name: Arts Co-op Search Term #3
description: Search term to obtain third work term. Completion of self-assessment, individual coaching sessions, and minimum number of job applications required. Students apply for jobs and go for interviews until they are hired. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.

name: Arts Co-op Work Term #3
description: Approved and supervised work experience with a non-profit, public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Reflective assignments required. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTC 310 and 311. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.

name: Arts Co-op Work Term #3 (Extension)
description: Extension of co-op term with the same employer as ARTC 210 or 211 for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Reflective assignments required. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTC 310 and 311. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.

name: Arts Co-op Search Term #4
description: Search term to obtain optional fourth work term. Completion of self-assessment, individual coaching sessions. Students apply for jobs and go for interviews until they are hired. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.

name: Arts Co-op Work Term #4
description: Optional fourth work term. Approved and supervised work experience with a non-profit, public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Reflective assignments required. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTC 410 and 411. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.

name: Arts Co-op Search Term #5
description: Search term to obtain optional fifth work term. Completion of self-assessment, individual coaching sessions. Students apply for jobs and go for interviews until they are hired. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.

name: Arts Co-op Work Term #4 (Extension)
description: Extension of co-op term with the same employer as ARTC 310 or 311 for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Reflective assignments required. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTC 410 and 411. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.

name: Arts Co-op Work Term #5
description: Optional fifth work term. Approved and supervised work experience with a non-profit, public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Reflective assignments required. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTC 450 and 451. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.

name: Arts Co-op Search Term #6
description: Search term to obtain optional sixth work term. Completion of self-assessment, individual coaching sessions. Students apply for jobs and go for interviews until they are hired. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.

name: Arts Co-op Work Term #5 (Extension)
description: Extension of co-op term with the same employer as ARTC 410 or 411 for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Reflective assignments required. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTC 450 and 451. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.

name: Arts Co-op Work Term #6
description: Optional sixth work term. Approved and supervised work experience with a non-profit, public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Reflective assignments required. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTC 460 and 461. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.

name: Arts Co-op Work Term #6 (Extension)
description: Extension of co-op term with the same employer as ARTC 450 or 451 for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Reflective assignments required. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTC 460 and 461. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading. Restricted to students in the Arts Co-operative Education Program.

name: Selection and Acquisition of Archival Documents
Advanced Arrangement and Description of Archival Documents
Management of Audiovisual and Non-textual Archives
Topics in Archival Automation - TPCS ARCH AUTMTN
Administering Records under Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Legislation
Topics in the Management of Records - TPCS MGMT RECRDS
Topics in the Management of Records - TPCS MGMT RECRDS
Topics in the Management of Records - TPCS MGMT RECRDS
Information Practice and Protocol in Support of Indigenous Initiatives
prerequisite: Either (a) all of LIBR 506, LIBR 507, LIBR 508, LIBR 509 or (b) all of ARST 510, ARST 515, ARST 516, ARST 573.

name: Directed Research Project - DIRECTED RES PRJ
Directed Research Project - DIRECTED RES PRJ
Professional Experience
description: Project-based experience undertaken with a faculty associate occupying a minimum of ten hours a week for 12 consecutive weeks or the equivalent time. Evaluation: Pass/Fail.
prerequisite: (24 credits in the program are required.)

name: Crisis and Contradiction in Art and the Built Environment
description: Concepts and issues critical to the understanding of art and its histories in a global context.

name: Art in Europe to the Sixteenth Century
description: A selective survey of painting, sculpture, and architecture.

name: Ways of Seeing: Introduction to Visual Studies
description: Drawing on examples from across history and around the world, this course deals with the role of the visual in society, culture, and everyday experience.

name: Art, Colonialism, and Indigeneity
description: Tensions and conflicts resulting from the expansion of trade and encounters among cultures, ethnicities, and religious practices, explored in visual art and architecture from the sixteenth century to the advent of the modern era.

name: What is Modern Art?
description: Select issues in 20th-century art and the visual and built environment.

name: Art and Feminism(s): Histories, Lineages, Legacies
description: Feminist art and visual culture, from the political activism of the feminist first wave to its intersections with present-day social justice movements.

name: Asian Architecture: Sacred and Urban Spaces
description: Select built forms in Asia, such as temples, tombs, palaces, cities and gardens, and their relations to cultural, social and political systems.

name: Seminar on Methods and Approaches in Art History
description: Theories, problems, and literature in the study of art history. Required of all Major and Honours students in art history.

name: Art and the Christian Transformation of the Roman Empire
description: Visual culture and the rise of Christianity; social, political and religious contexts of art, including diverse viewing practices and cultural frameworks. Credit will be granted for only one of ARTH 310 or ARTH 330.

name: The Archaeology of Ancient Iraq and Syria: Babylon and Beyond
description: An overview of the archaeology of the ancient Near East, with special emphasis on the civilizations of Mesopotamia, from the appearance of the first cities (c. 3400 BCE) to the end of the Persian period (c. 330 BCE).

name: Medieval Art in the Age of Monasticism
description: Art in Europe between 1000 and 1200; the role of monasteries as leading institutions and patrons of art and large-scale architecture.

name: Greek Art and Architecture
description: Visual culture of the ancient Greek world in the second and first millennia BCE, especially from c. 1000 to 30 BCE.

name: Heaven and Earth: Renaissance Art and Culture in Northern Europe
description: Early Modern painting, sculpture, and the graphic arts from the great devotional triptychs, through the Reformation, to the emergence of a secular art (1400-1600).

name: Public and Private Bodies: Italian Renaissance Art and Culture
description: Visual art and culture within the social, political, and religious contexts of the Papacy and the city-states ca. 1350-1550 (Siena, Florence, Venice, Mantua).

name: Roman Art and Architecture
description: Visual culture of the ancient Roman world from the 8th century BCE to the 4th century CE.

name: 20th Century Art and Culture: The Triumph and Demise of Modernism
description: A critical survey of western art and cultural production from the turn of the century to the development of Pop Art.

name: 19th-Century Art and Social Space
description: Ideologies of gender, class, race, ethnicity, and economics in 19th-century European and American visual culture.

name: 20th Century Art and Culture: The Postmodern
description: A critical examination of international visual art and culture from the 1950s to the present;  the role of art in consumerist society and the emergence of postmodernism.

name: Grounding the Islamic Image
description: Contextualizing the complex language of images in the Islamic world.

name: History of Photography: Archive, Spectacle, Reality
description: History and theory of photography, from the competitive context of invention in the 1830s to contemporary uses in social media.

name: Chinese Modern and Contemporary Art
description: Chinese art and its global entanglements from Qing Encounters to the 21st century.

name: Art in Japan: The Problem with Painting
description: Key debates in the history of painting and its institutionalization.

name: Art as Technology
description: Relationship between artistic practice and media, examined through a history of paradigm shifts in technology.

name: Is Art History Queer?
description: Issues in the history of art through the lens of queer theory.

name: Seminar in Modern and Contemporary Art - MOD & CONTEM ART
Film and the City
description: The complex interrelations between film and the city; dominant urban theories, film technologies and viewing practices and the intersections between them.

name: Visual and Digital Media Theory
description: A thematic examination of key arguments in visual and digital media theory, focusing on developments in lens-based and digital media in relationship to twentieth-century and contemporary artistic practice.

name: Studies in 20th Century Art - 20TH CENT ART
Studies in Art in the Islamic World
Studies in Chinese Art - CHN ART
Studies in Japanese Art - JAPANESE ART
The Methodology of Art History
description: Required of all art history graduate students.

name: Global Issues in the Arts and Sciences
description: Selected global issues explored through the methodologies and perspectives of both the physical and life sciences and the humanities and social sciences.
prerequisite: (Second year standing in the Faculty of Arts or Faculty of Science.)

name: Introduction to Sustainability
description: Sustainability examined from scientific, economic, and societal perspectives.

name: American Sign Language and Deaf Culture I
description: Listening to and speaking ASL.  Emphasizes core grammar and vocabulary, contextual use, connection between language and Deaf culture. For students new to ASL.

name: American Sign Language and Deaf Culture II
description: Skills in using ASL in a range of social contexts. Training in grammar and vocabulary that builds fluency, and in using the language appropriately for meaningful interactions with members of the Deaf community. For students with basic ASL conversational ability.

name: Introduction to the Solar System
description: General principles of the celestial sphere, laws of motion and light, optics, and telescopes; current knowledge of the Sun and Solar System.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 11, PHYS 12, PHYS 100. (plus Principles of Mathematics 12.)

name: Frontiers of Astrophysics
description: Stellar masses and evolution. White dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Extrasolar planet formation and detection. Dark matter in the Milky Way and other galaxies. Cosmological observations and principles.
prerequisite: Either (a) one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157, PHYS 153 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121; or (b) SCIE 001.

name: Introduction to Stars and Galaxies
description: Modern stellar and extragalactic astronomy. Stars and stellar evolution from protostars to black holes; galaxies and quasars; cosmology. ASTR 200/205 rather than ASTR 102 are recommended for students who intend to pursue studies in Astronomy.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 11, PHYS 12, PHYS 100. (plus Principles of Mathematics 12.)

name: Galaxies
description: Structure and kinematics of our galaxy. Spiral arms and dynamics of stars in spiral and elliptical galaxies. Galactic formation, evolution, dynamics, and groups. Active galaxies and quasars.
prerequisite: ASTR 205 and one of PHYS 210, EOSC 211, CPSC 302, CPSC 303.

name: Stars and Stellar Populations
description: Measurement of positions, motions, and distances in astronomy.  Temperature, masses, and spectra of stars.  Hertzsprung-Russell diagram.  Quantitative stellar structure and evolution.  Chemical composition of stars in different Galactic populations. Globular and open star clusters.
prerequisite: ASTR 200 and one of PHYS 210, EOSC 211, CPSC 302, CPSC 303.

name: Exploring the Universe: The Solar System
description: A survey of recent discoveries about the planets and other objects in the solar system, without the use of advanced mathematics. The Sun, the existence of planetary systems around other stars, and the search for life. Not open to first year students and not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science.

name: Exploring the Universe: Stars and Galaxies
description: A survey of recent discoveries in modern astronomy without the use of advanced mathematics. Stars, pulsars, black holes, galaxies, quasars and the origin and evolution of the Universe. Not open to first year students and not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science.

name: Exoplanets and Astrobiology
description: Observations and basic characteristics of extrasolar planets, including their formation, evolution, and potential for supporting life.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 102, PHYS 107, PHYS 108, PHYS 117, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 253, STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 241, BIOL 300, COMM 291, ECON 325, EPSE 482, EPSE 483, FRST 231, GEOG 374, KIN 371, POLI 380, PSYC 217, PSYC 218, PSYC 277, PSYC 278, PSYC 366, SOCI 328.

name: Directed Research Project in Astronomy
description: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a written report.  Requires approval of the course instructor and program advisor in the Department of Physics and Astronomy.

name: Astronomical and Astrophysical Measurements
description: Astronomical instrumentation and techniques for ground and space-based observations. Theory of measurement, imaging, interferometry and spectroscopy of electromagnetic radiation at optical, radio, infrared, and X-ray wavelengths. Astronomical data analysis.
prerequisite: All of PHYS 210, PHYS 408 and one of PHYS 312, MATH 316.

name: Cosmology
description: Introduction to the study of the Universe as a whole. Foundations of the Hot Big Bang model, the early Universe, nucleosynthesis, the cosmic microwave background, large-scale structure, galaxy formation and quasars. Credit will be granted for only one of ASTR 403 or PHYS 571.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 200, PHYS 250. (ASTR 300 is recommended.)

name: Astronomical Laboratory
description: Experiments in the use of astronomical instrumentation and data analysis. Use of the 40-cm reflector, spectrograph and electronic detectors. Photometric and spectroscopic analysis of digital data.

name: High-Energy Astrophysics
description: Radiative processes. White dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Accreting systems. Gamma-ray bursts.
prerequisite: All of PHYS 203, PHYS 301, MATH 215 and ASTR 300.

name: Honours Thesis in Astronomy
description: A research project in astronomy, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a thesis.

name: Planetary Science
description: Structure of planetary systems, planetary interiors, planet formation, planetary atmospheres, meteoritics, impact cratering.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 210, EOSC 211 and one of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317 and one of MATH 316, PHYS 312 and one of ASTR 200, EOSC 212.

name: Introduction to the Major Eastern Religions
description: Introduction to the major Asian religious traditions (Islam, Hinduism, Sikhism, Jainism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Daoism, Christianity, Shintoism, and Shamanism); employs theoretical models drawn from religious studies.

name: Introduction to Modern Asia
description: A survey of the emergence of modern Asia. Aims at an understanding of how the various peoples of Asia have maintained distinctive cultural identities despite centuries of political, economic, social and cultural change.

name: Introduction to Traditional Asia
description: A survey of the histories and cultures of Asia before 1600 and the coming of the Europeans. Emphasis will be given to parallel themes in the development of the civilizations of South, Southeast and East Asia.

name: Traditions of Yoga
description: Philosophical, religious, and cultural development of yoga in classical and medieval South Asia and its relation to contemporary globalized practice.

name: Cultural Foundations of East Asia
description: A comparative survey of the beliefs, assumptions and values which have shaped the civilizations of East Asia in both traditional and modern times.

name: Writing About Japan
description: Literary, historiographic, religious, and feminist approaches to Japanese myths, legal tracts, religious tales, fiction, and poetry.

name: Introduction to Buddhism
description: Origins, basic teachings, development of Theravada, Mahayana, and Tantric traditions, historical spread first through Asia and later the world, and Buddhism in contemporary societies.

name: Sex, Gender, and Sexuality in Japanese Literature and Film
description: The integral role that sex, gender, and sexuality play in literary and cinematic works from Japan. Literary works will be read in translation, movies will be subtitled.

name: China in World History
description: The history of China in a global context, from the earliest times to the most recent past; how China has changed the world and how engagement with the world has changed China.

name: Writing and Culture in East Asia
description: Practical, aesthetic, historical, technological and political issues pertaining to the use of Chinese characters - hanzi (Chinese), kanji (Japanese), or hanccha (Korean) - throughout the region.

name: Buddhism in the Modern Era
description: Buddhism from the nineteenth century to present day with special emphasis on its history and character in local settings, including specific traditions such as Tibetan Nyingma and Japanese Zen, as well as the development of a modern and global "Buddhism."

name: Survey of South and Southeast Asian Performing Arts
description: An historical perspective of the performing arts of South and Southeast Asia, highlighting the role of music, dance, and the dramatic arts in the lives of actors and audiences.  Option to complete a practicum performance.

name: Asian Horror Cinema: National Nightmares and Specters of Trauma
description: Engaging with the ideologies, industrial histories, socio-cultural contexts, and aesthetics of horror films - and the genre itself - from various Asian cinemas.

name: Myth, Ritual and Epic in Ancient India
description: Myths of creation Gods and goddesses of the Vedic pantheon. Connections with myths in other parts of the world, particularly in the Indo-European tradition. Literary representations of the myths.

name: South Asian Beyond South Asia
description: A history of South Asian peoples and communities that emigrated overseas, including Indo-Canadians.

name: Tibetan Buddhism
description: Religious terrain of the Tibetan cultural realm, looking at the history and development of Tibetan Buddhism and key ideas of the four main Tibetan Buddhist traditions.

name: Tibetan and Himalayan Culture and Society
description: History and culture of the Himalayan regions, including India, China, Tibet, Nepal, and Bhutan.

name: Premodern Japan
description: Japanese history (political, economic, social and cultural) to 1600.

name: The Rise of Korean Civilization
description: The evolution of a distinctive Korean civilization within the East Asian cultural sphere. Primary focus on cultural, social and political development from the earliest times to the sixteenth century.

name: Japan from Feudal to Modern State
description: Japanese history from 1600 to the Meiji Restoration. Political, economic, social and cultural forces which were involved in transforming Japan.

name: Contemporary Chinese Popular Cultures
description: Chinese popular cultures of the late twentieth and early twenty-first centuries, in relation to social changes, national policies, individual choices, everyday experience, and globalization.

name: History of Early China
description: History of China from the earliest times to the disintegration of the Tang empire. Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the origins and foundations of Chinese society.

name: Hong Kong Cinema
description: A survey of the cinema of Hong Kong from the post-war period to the present. The influence of Hong Kong on global cinema, and the forces (artists, studios, audiences, etc.) that have given rise to filmmaking styles and genres perceived as "distinctively Hong Kong."

name: Critical Approaches to Manga and Anime
description: A critical introduction to Japanese manga and anime in the 20th and 21st centuries.

name: Confucianism in China and Beyond: Reinventions of Tradition
description: Key ideas and trends in Confucian thought and practice from its origins to modern times through primary sources in translation and secondary scholarship.

name: Korean Popular Music in Context
description: History, contexts, and the genres of Korean popular music. Students will analyze specific artists and songs using a range of approaches. While an understanding of basic concepts of music will be helpful, no previous exposure to ethnomusicology or music performance is required.

name: Contemporary South Asian Gender and Sexuality Studies
description: Main theories and key concepts with a particular focus on the changing status of women, and gender and sexual minorities.

name: Sufi and Bhakti Devotional Literatures
description: Sufi and Bhakti thought and tradition in South Asia through literary works in translation.

name: The Korean People in Modern Times (1600 to the present)
description: The transformation of Korea from a Confucian state into an industrial nation. The rise of nationalism and modern ideologies in Korea. Cultural, social and economic changes Korea has undergone as it has entered the modern world.

name: Writing Women in Premodern East Asia
description: The construction of gender in literary writings by and about women in select areas of premodern East Asia.

name: History of Later Imperial China
description: History of China from the end of Tang to the eve of its modern transformation.  Students will acquire the analytical skills and tools to understand the political, socio-economic, and cultural changes in imperial China.

name: Chinese Literature in Translation: The Vernacular Tradition
description: Readings in drama and fiction, 800 to 1800 AD. The emergence of vernacular genres as distinct from and sometimes opposed to the existing classical genres.

name: Topics in Japanese Cultural History II: The Early Modern Age - TPCS JAPN CLT II
description: Focuses each year on a specific topic related to the culture of early modern Japan.

name: Traditional Korean Literature in Translation
description: An introduction to Korean literature from ancient times to 1900.

name: Modern Chinese Fiction in Translation
description: Reading of selected novels and stories written between 1750 and the present.

name: Introduction to Hindi Film
description: History, aesthetics, politics, and social roles of Bollywood films. Films will be subtitled.

name: Introduction to Japanese Cinema
description: Students will be introduced to the work of the major directors (e.g., Ozu, Mizoguchi, Kurosawa, Itami, Oshima, Shinoda). Ideological uses of literary texts and period pieces (e.g., Ugetsu, Life of Oharu, Double Suicide). Impact of depiction of Japanese in American film.

name: History of Chinese Cinema
description: Introduction to the work of major directors.

name: Modern Korean Literature in Translation
description: Selected fiction and poetry written between 1917 and the present.

name: Modern Chinese Fiction in Translation II
description: A thematic survey of modern Chinese fiction and film in translation.

name: Pre-Modern Japanese Fiction (in translation) - PREMOD JAPN FCTN
description: The influential genre of early tales and fiction in pre-modern Japan.

name: Modern Japanese Literature in Translation - MOD JAPN LIT TRN
description: An introduction to the literature and cultural history of modern Japan, with readings drawn from various literary genres, from 1868 to the present.

name: Contemporary Korean Culture
description: An introduction to the literature, drama, music, and art of Korea today. Particular attention will be paid to the continuing influence of traditional themes and forms.

name: Foundations of Chinese Thought
description: Chinese thought from its beginnings until the Han dynasty (206 BCE to 220 CE) in its historical and cultural contexts. Includes, among others: Confucius; Mo Zi; the Legalists/Authoritarians; Zhuang Zi; the Lao Zi book.

name: Development of Traditional Chinese Thought
description: Chinese thought from the Han dynasty (206 BCE to 220 CE) to Wang Yangming (1472-1529) in its historical and cultural contexts.

name: History of Hong Kong
description: History, culture, and identities of Hong Kong from the early 1800s to the present.

name: Global Chinese Cinemas
description: A survey of Chinese cinemas in global perspective, covering films, filmmakers, producers, audiences, markets, industries, and critical discourse since the early twentieth century. Covers both cinematic culture and filmmaking technique.

name: Buddhism in China
description: History, thought, and practices of Chinese Buddhism from its beginnings until the twentieth century.

name: Chinese Grammar and Usage I
description: Analysis of modern Chinese grammar and its usage in various discourses, situating its form and function in relation to social and cultural contexts.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 337, CHIN 208, CHIN 338, CHIN 217, CHIN 347, CHIN 218, CHIN 348. (or a higher level of Chinese language proficiency.)

name: Japanese Religions
description: An introduction to traditional Japanese religions including Shinto, Buddhism, Shugendo, Confucianism, new religions and folklore, and their roles in Japanese history, culture and society.

name: Buddhist, Brahamanical and Jain Philosophers in Interaction
description: Debates on issues of epistemology, language and ontology among the philosophical schools or systems of classical India Nagarjuna, Bhartrhari, Uma-svati, Sankara and others.

name: Life Writings of South Asian Diasporic Women
description: Auto/biographies and life writings of South Asian women in the Diaspora. Emphasizes theories of representation, subjectivity, agency, difference, and memory.

name: Classical Persian Literature in English Translation
description: Works of classical Persian literature dating from the tenth to the seventeenth century.

name: History of the Indian Ocean World
description: Societies and empires shaped by voyages of exploration, religious pilgrimages, trading diasporas and forced migration in the world of the Indian Ocean.

name: Post-Revolutionary Iranian Cinema
description: Gender politics, family relationships, and women's social, economic, and political roles in post-revolutionary Iran as shown through Iranian cinema.

name: Modern Persian Literature
description: Modern Persian literature, including fiction, drama, and/or poetry, of Iran, Afghanistan, and/or Tajikistan dating from the mid-19th to the 21st century (in English translation).

name: Narrative Literature in Premodern India
description: Stories of gods, goddesses and religious heroes from the Ramayana, Mahabharata, Puranas, Avadanas and in classical poetry and drama.

name: Films of the South Asian Diaspora
description: Contemporary films of the South Asian Diaspora, with a focus on Canada, US, and UK. Emphasizes theories of representation, visual and cultural analysis.

name: Chinese Grammar and Usage II
description: Analysis of modern Chinese grammar and its usage in various discourses, situating its form and function in relation to social and cultural contexts. Continuation of ASIA 386.
prerequisite: ASIA 386. (or higher level of Chinese language proficiency.)

name: North Korea in Historical Context
description: Analytical overview of North Korea's politics, society, and economy.
