prerequisite: (Restricted to fourth-year students. 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.)

name: International Relations in Premodern East Asia
description: International relations, particularly between Korea and Japan in the premodern East Asian context, focusing on migration, trade, diplomacy, war, collective memory, mutual perceptions, and the context of the Sinocentric international order.

name: Chinese Political Thought and Institutions
description: Chinese theories and practices of government and administration from earliest times to 1949.

name: International Relations in Modern East Asia: Korea and Japan
description: Trade, diplomacy, war, imperialism, militarism, colonialism, collective memory, mutual perceptions Korean-Japanese relations are examined as an exemplary case for exploring the dimensions of international conflict and partnership.

name: Tibetan Literature, Genres, and Book Culture
description: Tibetan literature, textual genres, and book and printing culture from the seventh century to the present.

name: Representations of Muslims in Hindi/Urdu Films
description: Depictions of Muslims in relation to the majoritarian community as well as other minorities in South Asian cinema, with a particular focus on the Hindi/Urdu film industry.

name: Masterworks of Chinese Fiction and Drama in Translation - CHIN FIC&DRAM TR
description: Reading of a classic novel or play, with attention to intellectual, social, and political subtexts as well as aesthetic dimensions and problems of interpretation.

name: Japanese Travel Literature
description: Japanese travel literature (myths, legends, poetry, tales, diaries, illustrated guides, satiric sermons, haiku, comic fiction, colonial reporting, and ethnography) from the 8th century to present.
prerequisite: (Restricted to fourth-year students. A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.)

name: Topics in Modern Japanese Fiction and Cultural History
description: Focuses on a limited time period or particular aspect of modern Japanese literature.

name: History and Culture of Taiwan
description: The major social, economic, political, and cultural changes in Taiwan since the seventeenth century; the post-World War II process of democratization and Taiwan's place in the contemporary world.

name: Gender and Sexuality in Modern Iranian Narratives
description: Literary, cinematic, folk, and/or popular culture texts from modern Iran. Emphasis on constructions and contestations of masculinities and femininities, as they intersect with sexuality, race, ethnicity, ability, and/or religion.

name: The Modern Korean Novel
description: Survey of major single-volume novels, ranging from Yi Kwang-su's Heartlessness to Ch'oe Yun's There a Petal Silently Falls, in translation.

name: Japanese Documentary Media
description: Historical survey of Japanese documentary film and media, including press, photography, reality TV shows, and social media.
prerequisite: (Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.)

name: Japanese Women's Self-Writing
description: Selected aspects of the more than 1000 years of self-writing (diary, autobiography, personal fiction). Theory and criticism about the use of writing as a medium of self-expression.

name: Japanese Horror
description: The genre of Japanese visual horror explored through formal visual literacy, genre theory, and textual analysis.

name: The History of the Choson Dynasty
description: Political, social, and cultural history of Korea's Choson Dynasty, focusing on how it lasted from 1392 to 1910 and why it collapsed so quickly at the beginning of the twentieth century. Credit will be granted for only one of ASIA 484 or ASIA 587.

name: Asian Classics - Fourth Year Seminar - ASIA CLSSCS SEM
description: Focus changes from year to year. Prerequisite: Permission of Instructor and fourth-year standing.

name: Asian Classics - Fourth Year Seminar - ASIA CLSSCS SEM
description: Focus changes from year to year. Prerequisite: Permission of Instructor and fourth-year standing.

name: Asian Classics - Fourth Year Seminar - ASIA CLSSCS SEM
description: Focus changes from year to year. Prerequisite: Permission of Instructor and fourth-year standing.

name: Asian Classics - Fourth Year Seminar - ASIA CLSSCS SEM
description: Focus changes from year to year. Prerequisite: Permission of Instructor and fourth-year standing.

name: India and the Persianate World
description: Histories of Muslim Empires, spanning Iran, India and Central Asia, from 1000-1800 CE. Examined through the conceptual lens of the Persianate World with emphasis on Persianate culture and power in South Asia.

name: Folk Cultures in the Asian Diaspora
description: The mediation of folklore (e.g. slang, songs, games, dance, foodways) in the everyday lives of immigrant and transnational Asian communities. Emphasis on Asian-Canadian folklore in Greater Vancouver through digital documentary media production and archival folklore research.
prerequisite: (Restricted to 4th year students. A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.)

name: Honours Thesis
description: Restricted to fourth-year students admitted to the Honours Program in Asian Studies.
prerequisite: (Restricted to fourth-year students. A minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework recommended.)

description: Introduction to essential skills for academic and professional work in Asian Studies. Outlines career trajectories in the PhD and beyond, including grant applications, cv-writing, and job searches. Required of Asian Studies PhD students, normally in their first year.

name: Doctoral Dissertation
description: In Chinese, Japanese, Korean, or South Asian Studies only.

name: Comparative Conceptions of the Self
description: Ways in which the "self" has been portrayed in eastern and western religious traditions. Thinkers to be considered include Aristotle, Mencius, Freud, Xunzi (Hsn-tzu), Nietzsche, and Zhuangzi (Chuang-tzu).

name: Canada, Japan and the Pacific: Political, Economic and Geographical Perspectives
description: An interdisciplinary introduction to political, economic and geographical interactions between Japan and Canada, the links between these countries and other Pacific Rim nations, and the historical origins of these connections. Specific topics will vary from year to year, but will include themes such as economic integration in the Pacific region; the role of resource economies such as Canada's; security relations in the Pacific; the role of Japanese investment in the Asia-Pacific region.

name: Writing for Research in the Social Sciences and the Humanities
description: Analysis of and practice in academic writing and reading in the social sciences and the humanities. Restricted to students in the Coordinated Arts Program.

name: 1st Year CAP Seminar
description: CAP seminar focused on writing and reading, including both literature and introduction to academic scholarship. Topics vary each year. Credits count toward both the Faculty of Arts Writing and Research Requirement and the Literature Requirement. Restricted to students in the Coordinated Arts Program.

prerequisite: (Restricted to students in the Sciences Po-UBC Dual Degree.)

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Approved and supervised paid work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Final written report required. Restricted to Master's degree students in departments with approved co-op programs.

name: Co-operative Education Work Placement 1
description: Approved and supervised paid work experience with a public or private organization for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Orientation, workshops, and co-op assignments required. Restricted to Ph.D. degree students in departments with Ph.D. approved co-op programs.

name: Atmospheric Radiation and Remote Sensing
description: Energy transfer at infrared, visible, and microwave wavelengths. Analysis of satellite measurements of the atmosphere and surface.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158. (and familiarity with a programming language.)

name: Meteorology of Storms
description: Characteristics and physical processes of thunderstorms, tornadoes, lightning, hail, hurricanes, blizzards, cyclones and other storms.

name: Applied Meteorology
description: Atmospheric-science principles elucidated by case studies applied to snow sports, sailing, surfing, soaring, and flying.

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Winter Session (Term 2) in third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.

name: Renewable Energy Meteorology
description: The meteorology of hydro, wind, and solar power. Atmospheric processes affecting renewable energy on global, regional and local weather scales.
prerequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157 and one of APSC 160, CPSC 103, CPSC 110, DSCI 100, EOSC 211.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Atmospheric Science.

name: Dynamic Meteorology
description: Dynamic principles governing atmospheric motions on a rotating planet. Simplified mathematical models of atmospheric flow based on scale analysis. Application to synoptic-scale and general circulation of the troposphere.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 312, MATH 316 and one of EOSC 250, MATH 217, MATH 317.

name: Cloud Physics and Chemistry
description: Cloud thermodynamics, chemistry and microphysics. Computer modelling of droplet growth, convection, and mixing. Application of differential equations to atmospheric problems.
prerequisite: MATH 215. (Familiarity with a programming language is required.)

name: Operational Meteorology
description: Introduction to meteorological prediction, meteorological data analysis, prognosis of weather systems, motion and development, satellite imagery, Doppler radar, numerical weather prediction, synoptic and mesoscale forecasting, applied laboratory exercises.

name: Numerical Techniques for Ocean, Atmosphere and Earth Scientists
description: Web-based introduction to the practical numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations including considerations of stability and accuracy. Credit will be granted for only one of ATSC 409 or ATSC 506/EOSC 511.
prerequisite: One of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 265. (Familiarity with a programming language is required.)

description: Statistical models of customer behaviour and past marketing actions, and applications to determining elements of the marketing mix.

name: Customer Relationship Management
description: Concepts of customer relationship management; metrics for customer loyalty satisfaction; RFM (recency, frequency, monetary) analysis in direct marketing, economics of customer relationship and customer loyalty program designs; exposure to trending topics; managerial understanding; practical analytical experience on real customer databases.

name: Topics in Marketing - BRANDS W PURPOSE
Supply Chain Strategy and Analytics
description: Strategic and operational decision-making within a supply chain and service provision context. Focuses on managerial decision- making using cases, decision models, and analytics.

name: Strategy in Organizations
description: Impact of corporate and organizational design on achieving profitability. Introduces the underlying economics of organizational design, including incentive pay, decentralization, transfer pricing, and complementarities.

name: Management Consulting and Corporate Decision Support
Strategic Management
description: Not available to MBA students.

name: Multinational Strategic Management
description: Credit will be granted for only one of BASM 530 or BAIM 500.

name: Optimal Decision Making I
description: Models and methods in continuous optimization; linear and nonlinear programming; applications to functional business areas and related fields. Students will learn to formulate an optimization model, solve it, interpret results, and derive insight relevant to intended application.

name: Simulation Modelling I: Data Processing and Monte Carlo Simulation
description: Computer simulation concepts such as Monte Carlo simulation and its benefits; developing simulation models; fitting probability distributions to available data in Excel; analyzing and processing available data for use in simulation models.

name: Simulation Modelling II: Queuing and Discrete Event Simulation
description: Simulation concepts such as Discrete Event Simulation and its benefits; queuing processes and theory; performing simulation optimization; discerning appropriateness of steady- state simulation models and conducting them; analyzing simulation outcomes and making comparisons.

name: Optimal Decision Making II
description: Models and methods in discrete optimization; emphasis on useful modelling methodologies and their applications. Students will learn to formulate an optimization model, solve it, interpret results, and derive insight relevant to intended application.

name: Analytics Leadership
description: Non-technical skills and practices for consulting; project management and problem solving for business consulting projects in analytics.

name: Decision Analysis Under Uncertainty
description: Decision making under uncertainty; using decision trees; the value of information; utility and risk preferences; behavioral aspects of decision making under uncertainty.

name: Plants, Carbon, and Environment
description: Introduction to plant biology, with special emphasis on growth and development, highlighting the biological mechanisms of radiation energy capture, and water and nutrient acquisition in the production of plant biomass.

name: Foundations in Bioproducts and the Bioeconomy
description: Introduction to the production, use, and attributes of renewable products and energy derived from biobased materials. Sustainability paradigms related to the bioeconomy; potential environmental and socio-political impacts associated with biobased technologies and transitions to sustainable economies.

name: Alternative Energy Systems
description: Introduction to safe, clean, and sustainable supplies of energy. Economic, social, environmental, and policy issues raised by current systems of energy use and production are examined.

name: Ecology of Managed Ecosystems
description: Provides a foundation in managed ecosystems and community ecology. Includes material on forest ecology and agricultural ecosystems as managed environments.

name: Problem-Based Learning In Bioinformatics
description: Develops the student's ability to exchange ideas in small groups focused on real but simplified problems in bioinformatics. Problems are carefully selected to cover all aspects of Bioinformatics research.  Required of students in the Bioinformatics graduate program.  Students not registered in the Bioinformatics graduate program must get permission to register in this course.

name: Special Topics in Bioinformatics - TPCS BIOINFORMCS
Statistical Methods for High Dimensional Biology
Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Advanced study under the direction of a faculty member composed of laboratory sessions and directed readings related to selected areas of bioinformatics. Students must get permission to register in this course.

name: Genetics, Evolution and Ecology
description: Principles of storage and transmission of genetic variation; origin and evolution of species and their ecological interactions. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 121 or BIOL 344.

name: Introduction to Modern Biology
description: Concepts fundamental to biological issues, such as the genetic basis of biological variation, evolution, infectious diseases, causes of cancer, population growth, and human effects on ecosystems.  Not open to students who have credit for Biology 12 (including AP, IB).

name: Biology of the Cell
description: The principles of cellular and molecular biology using bacterial and eukaryotic examples.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 12, CHEM 100, CHEM 110, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.

name: Laboratory Investigations in Life Science
description: Guided experimental investigations of biological questions.

name: Human Biology: Physiology and Introductory Anatomy
description: The principles of biology with particular reference to the human body (anatomy and physiology).  (physiology and introductory anatomy). Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 12, CHEM 100, CHEM 110, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.

name: Fundamentals of Cell Biology
description: Structure and function of plant and animal cells; membrane models, cytoplasmic organelles, biological information from gene to protein, the endomembrane system, secretion, intracellular digestion, endocytosis, transport processes, cytoskeleton and cell motility.
prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 112 and one of CHEM 123, CHEM 130; or (b) SCIE 001. (or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year BIOL and 6 credits of first-year CHEM or (d) one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121 and a corequisite of one of CHEM 203 or CHEM 223.)

name: Introduction to Biochemistry
description: Biological molecules, protein structure and enzyme action, energy transfer, central metabolic pathways and their regulation. Examples drawn from plants, animals and microorganisms. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) Credit will be granted for only one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, or BIOC 203.
prerequisite: BIOL 200 and one of CHEM 233, CHEM 260. (; or BIOL 200 and a corequisite of CHEM 213; or a corequisite of either CHEM 313 or CHEM 330.)

name: Vertebrate Structure and Function
description: Introduction to the vertebrate phyla and their evolution; a comparative study of vertebrate structure and function, with dissection of representative forms.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. (Or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.)

name: Eukaryotic Microbiology
description: Introduction to the origin and diversity of protists (protozoa and algae) at both cellular and genomic levels, including the role of endosymbiosis in evolution.
prerequisite: BIOL 140 and one of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. (BIOL 200 recommended.)

name: Comparative Invertebrate Zoology
description: An introduction to the unity, diversity and evolutionary history of invertebrates.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. (Or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.)

name: Biodiversity of Algae, Fungi and Bryophytes
description: Diversity, ecology, cell biology and evolutionary origins of multicellular eukaryotes, illustrated through mosses and liverworts; fungi and slime molds; and fresh water and marine algae.
prerequisite: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. (Or 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.)

name: Fundamentals of Ecology
description: Dynamics of plant and animal populations, structure of ecological communities and functioning of ecosystems. Interpretation of research results and application to environmental issues. Labs meet once a month. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

name: Fundamentals of Genetics
description: Genotype and phenotype, mechanisms of inheritance, genetic analysis. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001. (; or (c) a corequisite of one of CHEM 203 or CHEM 223 and one of BIOL 112 or BIOL 121.)

name: Fundamentals of Biostatistics
description: Statistical procedures for biological research; estimation, hypothesis testing, goodness of fit, analysis of variance and regression; use of computers for statistical analysis. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 121 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121; or (b) SCIE 001.

name: Fundamentals of Physiology
description: Principles of cellular and organismal physiology illustrated with examples from unicellular organisms, plants and animals, focusing on transport processes, water balance, nutrient acquisition and communication.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 or (b) SCIE 001. (or (c) 8 transfer credits of 1st year BIOL and 6 credits of 1st year chemistry.)

name: Vascular Plants
description: A comparative study of pteridophytes, gymnosperms and angiosperms, integrating form, function and ecology.
prerequisite: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. (or 8 transfer credits of first-year biology.)

name: Biomathematics
description: Introduction to uses of mathematics in the biological sciences; experimental design and modelling of biological processes. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

name: Advanced Ecology
description: Ecology of populations, communities and ecosystems. Tests of ecological theory with experiments and application to environmental issues. Labs meet once a month. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

name: Introduction to Animal Behaviour
description: Animal behavior from an ecological and evolutionary perspective; the methods used to study behaviour and test its adaptive significance.

name: Survey of Algae
description: A survey of the algae, considering their morphology, life history, classification, and ecology.

name: Introduction to Seed Plant Taxonomy
description: Introduction to seed plant taxonomy emphasizing descriptive morphology and identification. Each student will be required to submit a plant collection.

name: Introduction to Entomology
description: A survey of the structure, classification and biology of insects; ecology, life-histories and insect-plant relations.

name: Experimental Biology of Invertebrates
description: Behaviour and ecology of invertebrates as revealed by hands-on experiments in the laboratory and field.  Marine emphasis.

name: Introduction to Animal Mechanics and Locomotion
description: Comparative aspects of the functional design of skeletal systems and the mechanics of swimming, flying and terrestrial locomotion, with particular reference to the vertebrates.

name: Molecular Genetics
description: Isolation and identification of genes, analysis of gene structure; gene expression and its regulation in prokaryotes and in eukaryotes; developmental genetics.
prerequisite: One of BIOL 233, BIOL 234, MICB 322, FRST 302.

name: Developmental Biology (Lecture)
description: Animal development and its underlying causal principles; introductory embryology.
prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 201 or (b) all of BIOL 200, BIOL 260 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234.

name: Fundamentals of Evolutionary Biology
description: Natural selection; population genetics, quantitative genetics and systematics; classical and molecular approaches to the study of evolution.

name: Introduction to Genomics
description: An introduction to genome biology and applications of genomics.

name: Introductory Molecular Biology Laboratory
description: Use of recombinant DNA techniques.
prerequisite: BIOL 200. (And at least third-year standing in Science.)

name: Integrative Biology Laboratory
description: Field-based and laboratory-based investigation of organisms.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 140. (or (c) 8 transfer credits of first-year biology; and third-year standing or higher in Combined Major in Science.)

name: Plants and Peoples
description: The interactions of plants and human societies: the role of people in the origin, evolution and dispersal of food, drug and economic plants, and the influences of plants on human societies. Suitable for upper-level Arts students.

name: Microbes and Society
description: An elementary course in molecular biology primarily for Arts students. The historical development of recent discoveries in molecular biology with emphasis on bacteria and viruses and their interaction with humans. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.) Not for credit in Life Sciences.

name: Principles and Methodology in Biological Research
description: Contemporary research in the Botany and Zoology Departments; history and methodology of scientific discovery; seminars on current problems. Restricted to Honours students in Biology. Not to be taken concurrently with BIOL 449.

name: Plant Physiology I
description: Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants. Restricted to Majors and Honours students in Biology.
prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 121 and one of CHEM 123, CHEM 130; or (b) SCIE 001. (CHEM 233 is recommended.)

name: Plant Physiology II: Plant Development
description: Introduction to the processes involved in growth and development: cell division, tissue culture, meristems, differentiation, and the action of major growth regulators, and photomorphogenesis. Emphasis on experimental approaches.
prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234; or (b) FRST 302. (CHEM 233 is recommended.)

name: Cellular Physiology
description: The cytoskeleton, cell dynamics, and regulation of cellular activities. Preference will be given to Majors or Honours students in Biology and Combined Honours Biophysics.
prerequisite: BIOL 200 and one of APBI 312, APBI 351, BIOL 260, BIOL 351, BIOL 352, BIOL 361, FRST 311.

name: Comparative Cardiovascular, Respiratory and Osmoregulatory Physiology
description: Cardiovascular, respiratory, and osmoregulatory physiology. Preference will be given to students who are in Biology, Nutritional Sciences, and Combined Honours Biophysics.
prerequisite: BIOL 204 and one of BIOL 260, BIOL 361.

name: Principles of Neurobiology I
description: Introduction to the structure and function of the nervous system, excitable membranes, and synaptic signaling using representative vertebrate and invertebrate species.

name: Principles of Muscle Physiology and Energetics
description: Introduction to the structure and function of the muscular system, metabolism and energetics from a comparative perspective across vertebrates and invertebrates.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Work experience in an industrial setting, taken during Winter Session (Term 2) of third year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

name: Principles of Neurobiology II
description: Examination of the neural systems underlying sensation, action, and complex behaviours using representative vertebrate and invertebrate species.

name: Aquatic Ecology
description: Theoretical and applied limnology; ecology of inland water organisms in relation to physical, chemical and biological factors. One weekend field trip required.
prerequisite: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200.

name: Ecological Methodology
description: Design, execution, and analysis of ecological surveys and experiments. Practical field methods for estimating population metrics and describing community structure. Computer techniques for the statistical analysis of ecological data.
prerequisite: BIOL 230 and one of BIOL 300, STAT 200.

name: Microbial Ecology
description: Theoretical and applied ecology of microbes. Focus on microbial symbionts of animals, plants and seaweeds.  Research project development through critical analysis of microbial ecological literature and computational analysis of ecological data.
prerequisite: BIOL 121 and one of BIOL 300, FRST 231, STAT 200. (Fourth-year standing.)

name: Plant Ecology I
description: Plant community ecology including a consideration of the major approaches to sampling, analyzing and interpreting vegetation patterns. Instruction given in field work and computer analysis of field data.

name: Insect Ecology
description: Behavioural, population and community ecology of insects. Interactions between insects and plants and the application of the principles of insect ecology to biological control of insects and weeds.

name: Zoogeography
description: The role of physical, ecological, and evolutionary processes in determining the geographic distribution of animals including humans, with implications for speciation and conservation. Restricted to students in third and fourth year.

name: Principles of Conservation Biology
description: Ecological basis of conserving biological diversity and ecosystem services; application of ecological theory to global and local conservation problems in the context of economic, legal, political, and social perspectives. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

name: Phylogenetic Biology
description: Biodiversity from an evolutionary perspective. The evolutionary (phylogenetic) tree of genetic descent that links all organisms: its reconstruction, interpretation, and implications for fields from ecology to molecular biology.
prerequisite: BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234. (BIOL 336 is recommended)

name: Evolutionary Ecology
description: Ecological adaptation and evolutionary processes in contemporary populations; natural selection, variation, optimization, foraging theory, coevolution, arms races; life history theory, evolution of sex, sexual selection, evolution in managed populations.

name: Ocean Conservation and Sustainability
description: An interdisciplinary conservation course with a solutions-oriented approach to marine issues, drawing from natural sciences, social sciences, business, law, and communication.

name: Plant-Microbe Interactions
description: Biology and physiology of selected plant-microbe relationships. Impacts of plant-microbe relationships on society.
prerequisite: BIOL 200 and one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203, BIOL 201, BIOL 233, BIOL 234, BIOL 260.

name: Ornithology and Herpetology
description: Ecology, evolution, behavior, and conservation of birds, amphibians, and reptiles.  Laboratories and field projects will focus on identification, systematics, and natural history, with particular attention to species from British Columbia.

name: Biomechanics
description: An analytical approach to the study of skeletal mechanics and animal locomotion. Selected topics in the structure and properties of biological materials, the functional design of skeletons for locomotion, and the fluid mechanics of swimming and flight.

name: Evolutionary Morphology of Marine Invertebrates
description: Comparative analysis of marine invertebrate morphology from a macroevolutionary perspective.  Origin and evolution of reoccurring adaptations in meiofaunal, benthic, pelagic, and deep-sea invertebrates, including their larval stages.

name: Genome Evolution
description: Integration of molecular genetics and genomics with evolutionary biology. Emphasis on the evolutionary dynamics of genomes and the evolutionary implications of recent discoveries in molecular genetics and genomics.

name: Research Strategies and Techniques in Cell Biology
description: Major physiological mechanisms that define eukaryotic cells, explored through student visits to UBC research laboratories and discussion of recent scientific literature, with emphasis on the techniques and strategies that enable researchers to test hypotheses and advance new concepts.
prerequisite: BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234. (And fourth-year standing.)

name: Integrated Functional Genomics
description: Global transcript, protein, and metabolite profiling technologies and their integration; applications focus on plant functions and plant interactions with pathogens and pests.

name: Population Genetics
description: Theoretical and experimental aspects of population and quantitative genetics.
prerequisite: BIOL 336 and either (a) BIOL 200 and one of BIOL 233, BIOL 234; or (b) FRST 302.

name: Zoological Physics
description: Animal systems viewed from a physicist's perspective. Topics include sensory systems, energy budgets, locomotion, internal flows, physical advantages of grouping.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, SCIE 001. (BIOL 325 is recommended.)

name: Plant Genomics
description: Concepts, principles, applications, and recent discoveries in genome structure, genetics, and comparative genomics in plants with a focus on economically important plants.

name: Cell Biology of Intracellular Trafficking
description: Analysis of cellular organelles and the intracellular traffic between them, concentrating on mammalian cell systems.
prerequisite: One of BIOL 340, BIOL 341 and one of BIOL 361, BIOL 362.

name: Darwin's Fishes
description: A series of computer-assisted lectures using ichthyology and the work of Charles Darwin to illustrate basic principles of biology, and their practical implementation, i.e., how biologists select research programs, generate and test hypotheses, and present their case to peers and the public.

name: Principles and Methodology in Biological Research
description: Seminars, debates, workshops and tutorials designed to produce competence in specific areas of Biology. Restricted to Honours students in Biology.

name: Directed Studies in Biology - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: A course designed to allow students to undertake an investigation on a specific topic as agreed upon by the faculty member and the student. Permission of the supervisor required. No more than six credits of BIOL 448 may be taken with the same supervisor.

name: Directed Studies in Biology - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: A course designed to allow students to undertake an investigation on a specific topic as agreed upon by the faculty member and the student. Permission of the supervisor required. No more than six credits of BIOL 448 may be taken with the same supervisor.

name: Directed Studies in Biology - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: A course designed to allow students to undertake an investigation on a specific topic as agreed upon by the faculty member and the student. Permission of the supervisor required. No more than six credits of BIOL 448 may be taken with the same supervisor.

name: Directed Studies in Biology - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: A course designed to allow students to undertake an investigation on a specific topic as agreed upon by the faculty member and the student. Permission of the supervisor required. No more than six credits of BIOL 448 may be taken with the same supervisor.

name: Directed Biological Research
description: A course designed to allow students to undertake a research project in selected fields. Open only to Honours students in Biology, with permission of the supervisor. Presentation of a thesis and an oral examination are required.

name: Comparative Animal Physiology
description: Selected topics in physiology emphasizing comparisons between diverse phylogenetic groups of animals.

name: Molecular Adaptation of Animals to the Environment
description: Physiological, biochemical, and molecular strategies of adaptation of animals to environmental challenges.  The evolution of genetic and biochemical systems, and their impact on animal structure and function.
prerequisite: One of BIOL 361, BIOL 362, BIOL 364, BIOL 370, BIOL 371 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203. (BIOL 457 is recommended.)

name: Comparative Neurobiology
description: Current approaches in neurobiology, from the cellular to the behavioural level, are examined using representatives of vertebrate and invertebrate nervous systems.
prerequisite: One of BIOL 361, BIOL 362, BIOL 364, CAPS 301, PSYC 360.

name: Comparative Environmental Physiology
description: A survey of physiological adaptions of animals to different environments.

name: Developmental Neurobiology
description: Cellular, molecular and physiological aspects of nervous system development with applications to understanding adult nervous system function and neurological disorders.

name: Gene Regulation in Development
description: Control of gene expression in development; the genetic and physiological basis of epigenetic determination; inductive interactions.
prerequisite: BIOL 335 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203. (BIOL 331 is recommended.)

name: Animal Developmental Genetics
description: Role of genes in embryonic development.  Emphasis on tissue specific expression patterns and the role of genetic networks in establishing cell types.

name: Neurobiology of Sensory and Motor Systems
description: Analysis of the mechanisms of sensory processing and motor orchestration using vertebrate and invertebrate model systems.  Neural circuit structure, specialization, information coding, integration, and behaviour.

name: Diversity and Evolution of Fishes
description: Introduction to fish diversity, with a focus on their phylogenetic interrelationships and the evolutionary, ecological, and biogeographic processes involved in generating patterns of fish biodiversity.

name: Student Directed Seminars - STUDNT DIR SEMNR
description: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars". Normally not suitable as a specific BIOL program elective.

name: Co-operative Work Placement III
description: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
description: Work experience in an industrial research setting, taken during the Winter Session (Terms 1 and 2) following fourth year. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Biology.

name: Quantitative Methods in Ecology and Evolution
prerequisite: (BIOL 300 or equivalent and graduate student standing.)

name: Microbial Ecology
description: Theoretical and applied ecology of microbes. Focus on microbial symbionts of animals, plants and seaweeds.  Critical analysis of microbial ecological literature and computational analysis of ecological data.

name: Advanced Topics in Biology - ADV TOPICS BIOL
Advanced Topics in Biology - ADV TOPICS BIOL
Advanced Topics in Biology - ADV TOPICS BIOL
Advanced Topics in Biology - ADV TOPICS BIOL

Advanced Topics in Biology - ADV TOPICS BIOL
Advanced Topics in Biology - ADV TOPICS BIOL
Advanced Topics in Biology - ADV TOPICS BIOL
Advanced Topics in Biology - ADV TOPICS BIOL
Introductory Biotechnology
description: Block registration for the biotechnology, microbiology, physiology, communication for biotechnology, organic chemistry, information technology, plant anatomy, plant physiology and cell biology courses taken in the Joint BCIT/UBC Degree in Biotechnology.  Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

name: Advanced Biotechnology
description: Block registration for the microbiology, molecular genetics, biochemistry, management and regulatory affairs, process systems, analytical chemistry and communication courses taken in the BCIT/UBC Joint Degree in Biotechnology.  Credit limited to students in the Joint Degree Program.

name: Introductory Medical Biochemistry
description: Introduction to proteins and enzymes, carbohydrate metabolism, and glucose homeostasis. The course emphasis is on human biochemistry and it is designed for students going into health science fields. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203 or BIOL 201.

name: Fundamentals of Biochemistry
description: Amino acids and proteins. Enzymes and enzymology. Human metabolic pathways. Structure, function and metabolism of carbohydrates including glycogen storage and gluconeogenesis. Restricted to students in Biochemistry specializations. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203 or BIOL 201.

name: Biochemistry Laboratory
description: Techniques by which the chemical and physical properties of fundamental components of the cell are studied.

name: Molecular Biochemistry
description: Structure, function and metabolism of lipids, steroids, amino acids and nucleotides; the biochemistry and molecular biology of replication, transcription, translation and gene regulation. For students in Biochemistry and Honours programs in other life sciences.  Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 302 or BIOC 303.
prerequisite: One of BIOC 203, BIOC 202, BIOL 201 and either (a) CHEM 213 or (b) all of CHEM 205, CHEM 233.

name: Contemporary Biochemical Research
description: Exploration of the breadth and importance of biochemical research to present day challenges in medicine and biotechnology. Detailed experimental research case studies of novel biochemical methods used to address pressing and ongoing biochemical issues.

name: Internship Work Placement I
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic laboratory for three or four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.
prerequisite: (Completion of academic third year in Biochemistry major or honours program is required.)

name: Internship Work Placement II
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

name: Proteins: Structure and Function
description: Structural components of proteins, classification by primary, secondary and tertiary structure, protein chemistry and purification, peptide and protein synthesis by chemical means and three-dimensional structure determination using X-ray diffraction and NMR.
prerequisite: One of BIOC 302, BIOC 303, BIOT 380. (A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses.)

name: Enzymology
description: Kinetic analysis, catalytic mechanisms, transition state stabilization and regulation of activity, strategies for active site characterization and case studies of well-documented enzyme systems. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 403, CHEM 413 or CHEM 569.
prerequisite: BIOC 402. (A minimum standing of 65% is recommended.)

name: Biochemical Methods
description: Theory and application of classical and emerging technologies in biochemical research.  Emphasis on using primary literature and oral presentation skills.  Restricted to Honours students in Biochemistry or others with permission of the instructor.

name: Nucleic Acids-Structure and Function
description: Chemical, physical and biological properties of nucleic acids and their role in replication, transcription, translation and regulation of expression of genetic material. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 410 or BIOC 510.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of BIOC 303, BIOL 335 or (b) BIOT 380. (A minimum standing of 65% is recommended in these courses.)

name: Advanced Biochemical Techniques
description: Multi-week experiments in areas of contemporary biochemistry research using classical and modern techniques.  Emphasis on experimental design, technique, critical analysis of data, and scientific communication skills.  Restricted to Honours students in Biochemistry and others with permission of the instructor.

name: Recombinant DNA Techniques
description: Multi-week experiments involving contemporary nucleic acid research, cloning and recombinant protein engineering. Emphasis is on experimental design, critical analysis of data and scientific communication skills.  Restricted to Major students in Biochemistry.

name: Concepts in Molecular Biology
description: Developing areas of molecular biology, focusing on experimental design and data analysis. Signal transduction, the use of model eukaryotes, and the regulation of gene expression.
prerequisite: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

name: Directed Studies in Biochemistry - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: A library (3 credits) or a laboratory project with written report (3 or 6 credits) allowing a student to undertake an investigation on a specific topic as agreed upon by the faculty and student.
prerequisite: (Permission of the Department Head is required.)

name: Directed Studies in Biochemistry - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: A library (3 credits) or a laboratory project with written report (3 or 6 credits) allowing a student to undertake an investigation on a specific topic as agreed upon by the faculty and student.
prerequisite: (Permission of the Department Head is required.)

name: Honours Thesis - HONOURS THESIS
description: A research problem under the direction of a faculty member. Restricted to Honours students.

name: Honours Thesis - HONOURS THESIS
description: A research problem under the direction of a faculty member. Restricted to Honours students.

name: Membrane Biochemistry
description: Biochemistry of membranes and membrane proteins, membrane fusion, electrical signaling, and the involvement of membrane proteins in disease and drug development.
prerequisite: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

name: Honours Thesis - HONOURS THESIS
description: A research problem under the direction of a faculty member. Restricted to Honours students.

name: Biochemistry and Society: Current Issues
description: Biochemical basis of select global challenges. Critical evaluation of primary literature to form evidence-based opinions and communicating biochemistry as it relates to several controversial societal issues.

name: Advanced Techniques in Biochemistry
description: Theoretical basis and practical applications of a selection of advanced techniques currently used in biochemical research. Topics will vary.
prerequisite: One of BIOC 303, BIOT 380 and all of BIOC 402, BIOC 410.

name: Internship Work Placement III
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

name: Internship Work Placement IV
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial or academic research setting for four months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Internship Program in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.

name: Advanced Biochemistry Laboratory - ADV BIOC LAB
description: Practical applications of advanced biochemical techniques. Admission is limited and is by permission of the department head.

name: Seminar in Biochemistry
description: Attendance is required of all graduate students in Biochemistry. Normally students will make a presentation once per year on a topic approved by their research advisor or committee or on the results of their research.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: In special cases, with approval of the department head, advanced courses may be arranged for graduate students in attendance.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: In special cases, with approval of the department head, advanced courses may be arranged for graduate students in attendance.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: In special cases, with approval of the department head, advanced courses may be arranged for graduate students in attendance.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: In special cases, with approval of the department head, advanced courses may be arranged for graduate students in attendance.

name: Advanced Topics in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology
description: Discussions based on topics in the current literature.

name: Biochemical Aspects of Cellular Regulation
description: Mechanisms involved in the responses of cells to adrenergic, steroid and peptide hormones and growth factors. Recent advances in approaches and regulation of the concentration and specific activity of key enzymes, transport systems and structural proteins. Given in alternate years.

name: Advanced Topics in Biochemistry
description: Advances in biochemical approaches. Topics vary.

name: Advanced Topics in Protein Chemistry I
description: Contemporary theoretical and experimental investigation of protein structure-function relationships. Topics will vary.

name: Advanced Topics in Protein Chemistry II
description: Contemporary theoretical and experimental investigation of protein structure-function relationships. Topics will vary.

name: General Biochemistry
description: Metabolic reactions of lipids, steroids, amino acids and nucleotides; the biochemistry of replication, transcription and translation. Credit will be granted for only one of BIOC 302 or BIOC 303.
prerequisite: One of BIOL 201, BIOC 202, BIOC 203 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 233.

name: Topics in Botany - TOPICS IN BOTANY
Topics in Botany - TOPICS IN BOTANY
Topics in Botany - TOPICS IN BOTANY
Topics in Botany - TOPICS IN BOTANY
Internship
description: 4 months for M.Sc.

name: Internship
description: 8 months for Ph.D. students.

name: British Columbia Real Estate Law and Real Estate Ethics
description: Canadian legal system and contract law and detailed aspects of real estate law as it applies in British Columbia.

name: Capital Markets and Real Estate
description: Basic principles of macroeconomics and application to current economic problems.

name: Micro Foundations of Real Estate Economics
description: Basic principles of microeconomics and application to current economic problems.

name: Canadian Real Property Law and Real Estate Ethics
description: Canadian legal system and contract law and detailed aspects of real estate law as it applies across Canada.

name: Real Estate Finance in a Canadian Context
description: History, function and mechanics of Canadian mortgage markets.

name: Foundations of Real Estate Mathematics
description: Introduction to mathematics of real estate finance and statistical measures and methods and their application to practical real estate concepts.

name: Application of Statistics in Business
description: Methods and applications of statistics in business; data analysis, descriptive regression; data generation; sampling distributions; hypothesis testing; confidence intervals; two sample problems; inference in regression.

name: Introductory Financial Accounting
description: Introduction to the construction and interpretation of financial reports prepared primarily for external use.

name: Introductory Management Accounting
description: Introduction to the development and use of accounting information for management planning and control, and the development of cost information for financial reports.

name: Managerial Economics
description: Economic foundations of managerial decision making.

name: Principles of Organizational Behaviour
description: An introductory examination of work organizations and the behaviour of individuals within them.  Phenomena to be studied include organizational structure, environments, group processes, motivation and leadership.

name: Urban and Real Estate Economics
description: Comprehensive treatment of urban and real estate economics; introduction to study of cities and real estate market; analytical microeconomic principles.

name: Real Estate Investment Analysis and Advanced Income Appraisal
description: Valuation techniques for income real estate, including income method of appraisal, tax consequences of real property ownership, and portfolio analysis methodology.

name: Information Systems
description: Introduction to information technology related to business use: design, implementation, and application of information systems.

name: Foundations of Real Estate Appraisal
description: Introduction to concepts and techniques for appraising the value of real estate.

name: Statistical and Computer Applications in Valuation
description: Explores creative, practical uses of statistical and computer applications in determining and analyzing real estate value. Through case studies and hands-on computer work, students will learn the fundamentals of exploratory data analysis and appraisal valuation modelling.

name: Intermediate Financial Accounting I
description: An examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.

name: Case Studies in Residential Valuation
description: Examines common issues that affect the practice of residential real estate valuation. Credit will be granted for only one of BUSI 352 or both BUSI 442 and BUSI 452.

name: Cost Accounting
description: The provision and analysis of cost accounting information that will assist management in making operating decisions and in evaluating operational performance.

name: Introduction to Income Tax
description: A study of income tax from the standpoint of the individual and business enterprise.

name: Business Finance
description: An introduction to the basic principles of financial valuation and an examination of corporate enterprise decisions including working capital management; capital budgeting; capital structures and dividend policy.

name: Introduction to Business Law
description: Introduction to the law of contracts, with particular reference to contracts for sale of goods and related law of personal property, principles of agency, partnership, and company law.

name: Residential Property Analysis
description: Underlying theory and techniques used in design, construction, and inspection of residential properties.

name: Residental Property Guided Case Study
description: The residential property appraisal process, focusing both on valuation techniques as well as general research and report writing skills.

name: Commercial Property Analysis
description: Underlying theory and techniques used in the design and construction of commercial properties.

name: Integrated Business Leadership
description: Pass/Fail.

name: Integrated Business Leadership - INTEG BUS LDRSHP
description: Pass/Fail.

name: Real Estate Business
description: General business skills for real estate practitioners.

name: Real Estate Management I
description: Examines the day-to-day issues which affect the practice of property management.

name: Case Studies in Appraisal I
description: Examines the day-to day issues that affect the practice of real estate appraisal.

name: Assessment Administration
description: Introduces the practice of real property assessment, including the nature of the techniques used, the required duties of assessors, and how an assessment office is administrated.

name: Real Estate Development I
description: Real estate development process from the project idea to the cursory feasibility stage.  Steps in development planning, including analysis, design and evaluation.  Evaluating development potential, land acquisition, and site planning.

name: Computer Aided Mass Property Assessment
description: This course develops and applies the major techniques for valuing real property.

name: Real Estate Development II
description: Analysis of real estate development process with an examination of economic feasibility studies, approval processes, project financing, construction, project management, and marketing phases.

name: Intermediate Financial Accounting II
description: A continuation of the examination of accounting as a means of measurement and as an information system for external reporting purposes.

name: Real Estate Management II
description: Continuation of BUSI 441.

name: Advanced Financial Accounting
description: An examination of advanced financial accounting topics.

name: Principles of Auditing
description: Principles of internal control; audit evidence; sampling and testing; audit reports; standards and responsibilities of the external audit.

name: Case Studies in Appraisal II
description: Continuation of BUSI 442

name: Critical Analysis and Forecasting in Real Estate
description: Delves into two quantitative decision-making methodologies  decision analysis and forecasting  and explores them using a problem-solving framework.
prerequisite: BUSI 121. (BUSI 331 and BUSI 444 are also recommended.)

name: Marketing Management
description: Basic considerations affecting the domestic and international marketing of goods and services.

name: Special Topics in Business - INTL LEADERSHIP
Strategic Management in Business
description: A conceptual and practical introduction to the major areas of busness strategy with an integrative perspective on managing a business.  Includes the analysis of a business and its environment, the development and evaluation of strategic alternatives, and implementation of change.
prerequisite: BUSI 293 and either (a) all of ECON 101, ECON 102 or (b) ECON 309.

name: Guided Case Study in Agricultural Real Estate
description: An agriculturally-focused version of BUSI 499.
prerequisite: All of BUSI 330, BUSI 331, BUSI 442, BUSI 452.

name: Income Property Guided Case Study
description: The income property appraisal process, focusing both on valuation techniques as well as general research and report writing skills.
prerequisite: All of BUSI 330, BUSI 331, BUSI 442, BUSI 452.

name: Biomedical Engineering Lab
description: Rapid prototyping of mechanical, electrical and electromechanical systems. Building parts with state of the art software and 3-D printing. Use of laboratory equipment and instrumentation. Credit will only be granted for one of BMEG 102 and BMEG 200.

name: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
description: Foundational material spanning the four streams of the BMEG undergraduate program. Topics include: sensors and instrumentation; biosignals; physiological modeling; biomechanics; biomaterials; cellular engineering; regenerative medicine; and engineering design in these contexts.

name: Technical Communication for Biomedical Engineers
description: Report preparation, business correspondence, and oral presentation in biomedical engineering specific cases and projects. Credit will be granted for only one of BMEG 201 or APSC 201.
prerequisite: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150.

name: Thermodynamics in Biomedical Engineering
description: Work, heat and energy; material and energy balances; the first law and second law of thermodynamics; entropy and process reversibility; availability (energy) analysis; Hess's Law; thermodynamic properties of fluids; and applications to biomedical systems.

name: Biomechanics I
description: Integrating the study of two dimensional movement of animals and humans with the study of the manner in which forces on biomechanical structures such as bones, ligaments, tendons, muscles and joints cause motion. Techniques of solid mechanics and two dimensional rigid body dynamics. Students who have received credit for MECH 435 cannot also receive credit for BMEG 230 or BMEG 330.

name: Circuits and Electromagnetics with Application to Biomedical Engineering
description: Electromagnetic phenomena in the  body; bioinstrumentation; electrostatic and electromagnetic fields, forces, capacitance and inductance; bio-effects of electromagnetic fields; and modelling electrical components of physiological and biomedical systems.

name: The Fundamental Units of Life: From Cells To Systems
description: The structure and function of cells and how they are organized to generate tissues and organ systems
prerequisite: One of CHEM 12, CHEM 100. (BIOL 12 strongly recommended)

name: Cellular Physiology and Biophysics
description: Cellular structure and mechanisms of membrane transport, signal transduction, muscle mechanochemistry and neurotransmission. Structure and hierarchical organization up to the level of tissues. Light and electron microscopy.

name: Biomedical Engineering Design I
description: Engineering design process for medical technologies. Clinical practice, the healthcare system, medical approach to diagnosis, ethics and regulations for clinical trials, medical technology management, medical device development and standards, use of statistics for evaluating medical technologies. Credit will be granted for only one of BMEG 257 or BMEG 456.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of BMEG 101, BMEG 102 or (b) all of APSC 101, BMEG 200, PHYS 159.

name: Introduction to Bioinformatics
description: Principles behind the methods of bioinformatics. The use of bioinformatics databases and tools for solving problems in genomics, proteomics, structural biology and evolutionary biology.

name: Bioengineering Feedback Systems and Controls
description: Modelling, analysis and simulation of dynamic systems; system modelling by state space; linearization; feedback, stability and sensitivity; control system design. Examples from biological systems, assistive systems and biomedical equipment
prerequisite: Either (a) BMEG 220 or (b) all of ELEC 221, ELEC 201, ELEC 202.

name: Biomedical Instrumentation
description: Fundamental principles of operation and types of medical equipment used for measurements of respiratory and circulatory systems, and biopotential signals, as well as open, minimally-invasive, and robotic surgery. Other topics include medical imaging, image processing, and simulations. Credit will only be granted for one of BMEG 321, ELEC 371.
prerequisite: Either (a) MATH 256 or (b) all of MATH 265, MATH 267; and either (a) all of BMEG 220, BMEG 257 or (b) all of ELEC 202, ELEC 292.

name: Biomechanics II
description: Principles and common elements of sports-, orthopaedic-, injury- and cellular length-biomechanics. Improving sports performance and preventing overuse injuries through sports biomechanics, designing orthopaedic implants through orthopaedic biomechanics, preventing injuries through injury biomechanics and identifying and filtering cancerous blood cells through cellular biomechanics. Students who have received credit for MECH 435 cannot also receive credit for BMEG 230 or BMEG 330.

name: Human Structure/Function from Cells to Systems
description: Human anatomy, histology and physiology with examples from biomedical engineering. Anatomical compartmentation and function regulation; homeostatic control systems, sensors and effectors; intercellular communication strategies; and cellular and organ function assessment.

name: Biomedical Engineering Design II
description: Creating innovations in medical technologies. Case studies in need clinical identification. Supervised design process, building and testing prototypes with potential users.

name: Biomedical Materials and Drug Delivery
description: Biomaterials science/engineering applied to design and synthesis of drug delivery systems. Biomaterial types, synthesis and testing; the use of biomaterials; biological response; biocompatibility and degradation; drug delivery systems; nanocarriers; modification of polymers; liposomes and micelles; nucleic acid, transdermal and oral delivery.

name: Cellular Bioengineering: Laboratory and Design
description: Fundamental genetic, molecular, and tissue engineering techniques. Design of experiments and tools related to these essential cellular bioengineering techniques.

name: Topics in Biomedical Engineering - MDRN BME OPT IMG
description: Lectures or projects on specialized topics in Biomedical Engineering.

name: Microfluidics
description: Advantages and disadvantages of miniaturization of complex fluid flow processes. Manipulating liquid flow; electrophoretic velocity and mobility; serial dilution; capillary electrophoresis; integrated microfluidic platforms; and blood and the motility of bacteria.

name: Topics in Biomedical Engineering - CLNCL INFRMTCS
description: Lectures or projects on specialized topics in Biomedical Engineering.

name: Topics in Biomedical Engineering - TPCS BIOMED ENG
description: Lectures or projects on specialized topics in Biomedical Engineering.

name: Economics of Healthcare Solutions
description: Canadian and USA engineering economics in BME and healthcare systems.  Economic equivalence, cost estimation, risk assessment, regulatory frameworks, economic optimization, intangible factors, ethics, sustainability, financial tools, commercialization and regulator regimes.

name: Biomedical Equipment, Physiology, and Anatomy
description: Principles and operation of biomedical equipment for cardiovascular system, respiratory system, renal dialysis, endoscopy, surgery, and imaging. Functional relationships of biomedical equipment to physiology and anatomy of major body systems. Credit will be granted for only one of BMEG 410 or BMEG 510.

name: Medical Imaging
description: Physical principles of ultrasound, magnetic resonance, computed tomography, X-ray projection imaging and molecular imaging in medical imaging for diagnostics, therapeutics and interventions.

name: Professionalism and Ethics in Biomedical Engineering
description: Ethical, equity, and diversity issues and professionalism in Biomedical Engineering practice and design. Case studies and design projects will be used to expand on the foundation of biomedical engineering design, applying real-world ethical dilemmas including professional, medical, and research ethics.

name: Clinical and Industrial Biomedical Engineering
description: Principles of clinical practice, Canadian healthcare system, medical approach to diagnosis, ethics and regulations for clinical trials, medical technology management, medical device development and standards, biostatistics. Credit will be granted for only one of BMEG 257, BMEG 456, BMEG 556.

name: Biomedical Engineering Design Project
description: Capstone design and development of a practical biomedical device or system. Projects provided by local industry and engineering research laboratories.

name: Stem Cells and Regenerative Medicine
description: Biology and applications of stem cells in regenerative medicine. Modelling human biology and disease in vitro and in vivo. Regulatory and commercialization pathways for regenerative medicine innovations.

name: Orientation to Clinical Environment
description: Operation of biomedical and clinical engineering facilities at hospitals. Daily activities of healthcare workers. Patients experience.

name: Interdisciplinary Team Project in Medical Technology Innovation
Anatomy and Physiology with Applications to Biomedical Devices
description: Anatomical structures and physiological principles of major body systems.  Functional connections to operation of diagnostic and therapeutic equipment.  Exploration of recent advances. Credit will be granted for only one of BMEG 410 or BMEG 510.

name: Transport Phenomena within Cells and Tissues
description: Fluid flow and mass transport analysis within healthy and diseased cells and tissues using mathematics. Drug delivery and tissue engineering.
prerequisite: One of MATH 253, MATH 217 and either (a) MATH 256 or (b) all of MATH 255, MATH 257.

name: Fundamentals of Applied Pathophysiology in Biomedical Engineering
Directed Studies in Biomedical Engineering - DR STD BIOMD ENG
Directed Studies in Biomedical Engineering - DR STD BIOMD ENG
Directed Studies in Biomedical Engineering - DR STD BIOMD ENG
Statistical Methods for Evaluating Medical Technologies
Clinical and Industrial Biomedical Engineering
description: Principles of professional engineering practice, the Canadian healthcare system, medical approach to diagnosis, principles and management of common medical devices, ethics and regulations for clinical trials, codes and regulations of medical devices, applications of biomedical engineering. Credit will be granted for only one of BMEG 456 or BMEG 556.

name: Topics in Biomedical Engineering - GNM INFRMTCS
description: Lectures or projects on specialized topics in Biomedical Engineering.

name: Biomedical Engineering Topics at the Interface of Medicine and Engineering
Biomedical Engineering Professional Skills
description: Formulate and implement a professional skills development plan involving workshops on topics such as writing, presentation, teaching, finance, marketing, equity, ethics.  Pass/Fail grading.

name: Topics in Biomedical Engineering - CLNCL INFRMTCS
Topics in Biomedical Engineering - MDRN BME OPT IMG
Topics in Biomedical Engineering - GNM INFRMTCS
Topics in Biomedical Engineering - MMLN SYNTH BIO
Topics in Biomedical Engineering - TPCS BIOMED ENG
Master of Engineering Project
description: Supervised industrial, clinical, or research project for students registered in Biomedical Engineering program.

name: Biomedical Engineering Seminar
description: Presentation and discussion of current topics in biomedical engineering research and development. A required course for all graduate students in Biomedical Engineering.

name: Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC
description: Investigation and report of a problem.

name: Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC
description: Investigation and report of a problem.

name: Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC
description: Investigation and report of a problem.

name: Graduating Paper
description: Pass/Fail.

name: Introduction to Microscopic Human Anatomy
description: Organ system development, structure and function at the microscopic level.
prerequisite: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001. (BIOL 200 is recommended.)

name: Laboratory in Human Physiology (Honours)
description: Techniques and principles of human physiology. This course must be taken in conjunction with CAPS 301. Restricted to Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences and Pharmacology Honours students.

name: Human Physiology
description: Organ systems function with particular reference to mammalian and human physiology.  See credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414
prerequisite: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) all of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 100, PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 233, CHEM 260.

name: Cooperative Work Placement
description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Option in Honours Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences (B.Sc.).

name: Introduction to Gross Human Anatomy
description: Structure and function of body regions at the macroscopic level.
prerequisite: One of BIOL 121, SCIE 001, KIN 190, KIN 191.

name: Cooperative Work Placement II
description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for  a minimum of 13 weeks full-time. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Option in Honours Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences (B.Sc.).

name: Mammalian Cardiovascular and Respiratory Physiology
description: The control and integration of cardio-pulmonary function in mammals. Intended for Honours students in Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences or other life sciences.
prerequisite: (A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program and a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301 or PHYL 301 or its equivalent. Permission of the course director is also required.)

name: Advanced Cellular and Molecular Physiology
description: Recent advancements in cellular and molecular physiology that have revolutionized our understanding of cell function in health and disease.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of ANAT 390, PHYL 301 or (b) all of CAPS 301, CAPS 390. (and third-year standing.)

name: Mammalian Renal and Gastrointestinal Physiology
description: Control of mammalian renal and gastrointestinal systems. Role in homeostasis. Intended for Honours students in Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences or other life sciences.
prerequisite: (A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program and a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301 or PHYL 301. Permission of the course director is also required.)

name: Mammalian Endocrinology
description: Hormonal control of homeostatic, metabolic and reproductive function. Intended for Honours students in Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences or other life sciences.
prerequisite: (A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program and a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301 or PHYL 301. Permission of the course director is also required.)

name: Physiological Basis of Central Nervous System Functions
description: An integrated study of the structural and functional organization of the central nervous system with special emphasis on neurophysiological mechanisms.
prerequisite: (A cumulative average of 75% over at least 90 credits attempted in the first three years of a student's program and a minimum mark of 75% in CAPS 301 or PHYL 301. Permission of the course director is also required.)

name: Advanced Laboratory in Physiology
description: Methods, techniques, and use of instruments required for physiological investigation. CAPS 303 or PHYL 303 and the consent of the department are required and enrolment will be limited.

name: Directed Studies in Physiology - DIRECTED STUDIES
Directed Studies in Physiology - DIRECTED STUDIES
Directed Studies in Physiology - DIRECTED STUDIES
Cooperative Work Placement III
description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks full time. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Option in Honours Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences (B.Sc.).

name: Graduating Essay
description: Written report and presentation on an independent investigaton approved by the department head.

name: Cooperative Work Placement IV
description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks full time. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Option in Honours Cellular, Anatomical and Physiological Sciences (B.Sc.).

name: Case Studies in Museum and Gallery Exhibitions
description: A case study approach to analyzing museum and gallery exhibitions that are historically significant either because they raised issues and stimulated public debate, or because of radical features that proved influential on subsequent exhibitions. Course not offered every year.

name: Graduate Practicum and Major Paper in Curatorial Studies
description: Practical on-site teamwork to produce exhibitions or other public displays in a museum, gallery, or alternative situation, offering opportunities for comparison, collaboration, and interdisciplinarity. Students concurrently produce a major paper from the ideas and research which generate the exhibition.

name: Seminar in Interdisciplinary Frameworks in Museum and Curatorial Studies
description: Theoretical and historical foundations of visual representations and expressive culture. It explores the history of museums and galleries, and changes in the meaning of art and material culture as debates about cultural property intensify.

name: Canadian Studies - CDN STUDIES
description: An interdisciplinary introduction to Canadian studies. Required of all Canadian Studies Majors.

name: Senior Seminar in Canadian Studies - SR SEM CDN STUD
description: The Canadian experience from a variety of disciplinary perspectives. Offered by the McLean Chair in Canadian Studies. Required of all Canadian Studies Majors.

name: Energy and the Environment
description: Energy/environment/society interactions; development of energy resources; energy demand and its determinants; policy dimension of energy and climate change; impacts on ecosystems; life cycle analysis; impact assessment and other tools for quantitative and qualitative evaluation of alternative energy sources.

name: Energy Policy
description: Energy policy process and governance. Sustainable energy as a social and political challenge, formal government structures and process, actors in the policy, policy analysis, policy instrument, and energy planning and approval processes, including environmental assessment. Introduction to demand-side energy policy.

name: Energy System Fundamentals
description: Thermodynamic analysis of energy conversion processes, power cycles and refrigeration cycles. Exergy analysis of conventional energy systems. Thermal conversion technologies.
prerequisite: (3 credits of thermodynamics at the second- or third-year level.)

name: Project and Report
description: For M.Eng. students. Carry out a project and prepare an engineering report under the supervision of a faculty member.

name: Energy Efficiency and Conservation
description: Engineering concepts of demand side management (DSM), energy auditing, analysis of buildings and industrial equipment, measurement and verification, and system data analysis. Energy efficient technologies for green buildings and industrial processes. Behavior and energy use. DSM policy concepts.

name: Current Topics in Cellular Communication
description: Cellular communication within tissues by direct contact and by modulating and responding to the microenvironment.

name: Current Topics in Developmental Biology
description: Cellular and molecular mechanisms of development from the earliest stages of axis formation to organogenesis.

name: Cell and Developmental Biology Research Literature
description: Development of written communication and critical thinking skills.

name: Current Topics in Cytoskeleton and Cell Motility
description: Structure and function of the cytoskeleton, and its involvement in various forms of cell and intracellular motility.

name: Current Topics in Intracellular Trafficking
description: Organization of membranes and organelles within cells and how molecules are targeted to intracellular sites.

name: Fluorescence Microscopy
description: Principles and applications in biological research.

name: Molecular Genetic Analysis
description: Methodologies and resources for genetic analysis of cellular function.

name: Cell Systems Biology
description: The integration of basic cellular processes to produce a functioning cell.

name: Special Techniques and Protocols in Cell and Developmental Biology
Cellular and Molecular Mechanisms of Human Disease
description: Cell biology in the age of evidence-based medicine.

SubjectName: Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies
