name: Great Works of Literature from Central, Eastern and Northern Europe (in English).
description: Major works of Central, Eastern and Northern European literature from the eighteenth century to the present in their European context.

SubjectName: Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies
name: Contrasts and Conflicts: The Cultures of Central, Eastern and Northern Europe (in English)
description: An introduction to the cultural history of the peoples of Central, Eastern and Northern Europe as reflected in their literature, art and music.

SubjectName: Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies
name: Representations of the Holocaust (in English) - REPRESENTNS HOLO
description: The Nazi Holocaust in film and literature from Central, Eastern, and Northern European Countries.

SubjectName: Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies
name: Representations of the Holocaust (in English) - REPRESENTNS HOLO
description: The Nazi Holocaust in film and literature from Central, Eastern, and Northern European Countries.

SubjectName: Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies
name: Gender and Nation: Women's State in Modern Central, Eastern and Northern European Literatures and Cultures
description: Cultural and social discourses of gender in literary works written in Central, Eastern and Northern Europe roughly between 1850 - 1930.

name: Founding Principles in Chemical and Biological Engineering II
description: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering profession with emphasis on the biological sciences that form the founding principles of the discipline.

name: Founding Principles in Chemical and Biological Engineering I
description: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering profession and the physical sciences that form the founding principles of the discipline.

name: Integrated Technical Communication
description: Written and oral communication in chemical and biological engineering: business correspondence, laboratory reports, technical description, and poster presentations. Restricted to students in second year of the Chemical and Biological Engineering programs.
prerequisite: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150.

name: Material and Energy Balances
description: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering; units; stoichiometry; phase equilibria; material balances; energy balances.

name: Computational Methods
description: Mathematical formulation of chemical and biological engineering problems; standard techniques of numerical analysis and their application to chemical, environmental and biotechnological systems; program development; use of commercial numerical analysis software.

name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Thermodynamics I
description: Energy and the first law; second law of thermodynamics; entropy; availability (energy) analysis; thermodynamic properties of fluids, application to power generation, refrigeration, and liquefaction, as well as biological, environmental, and electrochemical systems.

name: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering Laboratory Practice
description: Introduction to Chemical and Biological Engineering laboratory practice with topics in physical, inorganic and organic chemistry.

name: Transport Phenomena I
description: Fluid Mechanics. Momentum-transfer in fluids in laminar and turbulent flow; microscopic and macroscopic material; momentum and energy balances; rheology; dimensional analysis; flow in conduits; pumps; fluid metering.

name: Introduction to Unit Operations
description: Characterization of particles, droplets, and bubbles; comminution, screening and classification; filtration, sedimentation, centrifugal separations and fluidization; thermal operations including evaporation and crystallization.

name: Unit Operations II
description: Stage-wise mass transfer operations; extraction and absorption; single and stage-wise binary and multi-component distillation; principles and equipment design for continuous contact mass transfer operations including absorption, binary distillation and others such as extraction, drying, and humidification.

name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Thermodynamics II
description: Volumetric and thermodynamic properties of fluids; equations of state; heat effects; ideal and non-ideal mixtures; fugacities and activity coefficients; vapor-liquid and liquid-liquid phase equilibrium; solubility of gases and solids in liquids; chemical reaction equilibrium; equilibrium partitioning of pollutants.

name: Mass Transfer Bridge Module
description: Mass transfer; molecular diffusion; convective transfer; analogies among heat, mass and momentum transfer; mass transfer coefficients; interphase mass transfer.

name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Laboratory
description: Laboratory experiment in 2nd year Chemical and Biological Engineering

name: Transport Phenomena II
description: Heat and mass transfer; conduction and molecular diffusion; convective transfer; analogies among heat, mass and momentum transfer; heat exchanger design; mass transfer coefficients; interphase mass transfer.

name: Kinetics and Reactor Design
description: Kinetics of homogeneous chemical and biological reactions, isothermal ideal reactor design, analysis of non-ideal reactors using residence time distribution and mixing models.

name: Process Dynamics and Control
description: Introduction to modelling of chemical processes; transient response analysis; design of feedback control systems; stability analysis; frequency response analysis; process control applications; instrumentation; advanced control techniques; distributed control systems.

name: Environmental Engineering Laboratory
description: Laboratory experiments to illustrate key concepts and measurement techniques in environmental engineering as used by  engineers.

name: Process and Environmental Engineering Laboratory
description: Experiments to illustrate and use material presented in 200 and 300-level CHBE courses.  Field trips may be required.
prerequisite: All of CHBE 201, CHBE 241, CHBE 251, CHBE 264.

name: Fundamentals of Sustainable Engineering
description: Introduction to sustainable practice for Chemical and Biological Engineers.  Pollution prevention, cleaner production, green chemistry and engineering, and sustainable design; environmental impact assessment including life-cycle assessment, total cost analysis and environmental systems analysis; applications in chemical and biological process industries.

name: Biological Engineering Laboratory
description: Laboratory experiments to illustrate key concepts and measurement techniques in biotechnology as used by engineers. Field trips may be required.
prerequisite: All of CHBE 201, CHBE 241, CHBE 264, CHBE 221.

name: Chemical Engineering Laboratory
description: Experiments to illustrate and use material presented in 300-level Chemical Engineering program courses. Field trips may be required.
prerequisite: All of CHBE 201, CHBE 241, CHBE 251, CHBE 264.

name: Water Pollution Control
description: Legal, environmental and physicochemical aspects of industrial water pollution and its abatement will be surveyed; techniques for design of wastewater treatment processes currently used in industry; case studies from chemical and process industries will be considered in detail.
prerequisite: One of CHBE 251, CIVL 215, MECH 280, MTRL 263.

name: Computer Flowsheeting and Unit Operation Design
description: Theory and practice of computer flowsheeting in chemical plant design; hands-on use of modern process simulators, prediction of thermodynamic properties of fluids; behaviour of single and multiphase systems. Design of unit operations.

name: Bioprocess Engineering I
description: Biological process engineering in the fields of biotechnology and biomedical engineering; enzymatic and cellular kinetics; cell culture, process development and product recovery; bioreactor design and operation. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 381, CHBE 560.
prerequisite: All of CHBE 221, BMEG 245 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105. (Third or fourth year standing.)

name: Biomass Fractionation Technology
description: Process and unit operations in the conversion of wood chips to pulp and green bio-products. Biorefinery concepts and emerging technologies for the production of biomaterials, biochemicals and bioenergy.

name: Industrial Biotechnology Laboratory
description: Modern bioreactor technology, upstream and downstream processing of biotechnology products. Restricted to students in the Joint Degree in Biotechnology.

name: Engineering Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
description: Classical thermodynamic relations from a molecular perspective. Pressure-volume-temperature relations; chemical equilibria by Gibbs' method; vapor-liquid equilibria; thermodynamic calculations based on macroscopic and statistical methods; nonequilibrium processes; molecular simulations. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 451, CHBE 551.

name: Biological Process and Product Design
description: 8-month project-based course, integrating chemical and biological engineering concepts with economics, life cycle analysis and health and safety considerations in the design of major biological processes.
prerequisite: All of BIOL 112, CHBE 241, CHBE 344, CHBE 346, CHBE 351, CHBE 356, CHBE 376, CHBE 381.

name: Heterogenous Catalysis and Advanced Reactor Design
description: Definition of heterogeneous catalysis; properties of catalysts; kinetics of catalytic reactions; ideal heterogeneous reactors; non-isothermal reactor design; mass and heat transfer effects in heterogeneous reactors; examples of industrial reactors.

name: Process Synthesis
description: Strategy for the conceptual design of industrial chemical and biological processes; rules of thumb for chemical engineers, simulation to assist process synthesis, reactor-separator network synthesis, introduction to product design and molecular structure design, efficiency and sustainability in the chemical industry.
prerequisite: All of CHBE 241, CHBE 346, CHBE 376, CHBE 344.

name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Economics
description: Estimation of capital and operating costs; interest calculations; taxes; economic comparison of alternatives; economic optimization.

name: Chemical and Biological Engineering Laboratory
description: Experiments in unit operations relating to process, environmental and biological engineering. Experiments are designed to provide experience in instrumentation and control. Field trips may be required.
prerequisite: All of CHBE 345, CHBE 355, CHBE 356, CHBE 362 and one of CHBE 365, CHBE 366.

name: Process Control Engineering
description: Frequency response analysis; advanced control techniques; multivariable control systems; mathematical tools for computer control systems; design of computer control systems; engineering design of industrial control applications; plant wide control concepts; distributed control systems concepts.

name: Modelling and Optimization in Chemical Engineering
description: Mathematical modelling of chemical plants and processes; computer simulation; introduction to numerical optimization techniques.

name: Fuel Cell and Electrochemical Engineering
description: Stoichiometry, thermodynamics and kinetics of electrode reactions; conductivity and mass transport in electrolytes; material, energy and voltage balances; design of  electrosynthesis, electrorecovery of metals, and energy generation of batteries and fuel cells. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 477, CHBE 577.

name: Chemical Process and Product Design
description: 8-month project-based course, integrating chemical engineering concepts with economics, life cycle analysis and health and safety considerations in the design of major chemical processes.
prerequisite: All of CHBE 241, CHBE 344, CHBE 346, CHBE 351, CHBE 356, CHBE 376.

name: Bioprocess Engineering II
description: Bioprocess flowsheeting; production-scale fermenter design; product recovery and purification; bioseparations; chromatography; viral inactivation and removal; process validation.

name: Petroleum Refining Process Modelling and Simulation
description: Petroleum feed stocks testing methods, pseudocomponents, and property methods. Design and simulation of separation and reaction systems. Steady state and dynamic simulation.

name: Energy Engineering
description: Supply and use of conventional and alternative fuels and energy.  Design and operation of unit operations for processing of fossil fuels, biomass, and other energy sources.  Environmental considerations of energy use. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 483, CHBE 583.

name: Air Pollution Prevention and Control
description: Impacts of air pollutants on health, visibility, smog formation, ozone depletion and global warming; air quality and emission standards; atmospheric dispersion of air pollutants; prevention and control technologies for particulates, SOx, NOx, VOCs, and CO2. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 485, CHBE 575.

name: Waste Management for Resource Recovery
description: Physico-chemical, thermal, and biological methods for purification of solid waste and wastewater, and conversion to bioproducts/industrial products, energy and clean water.

name: Interfacial Phenomena
description: Outline of the physics and chemistry of interfaces; discussion of the part played by surface effects in technical processes. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 357, CHBE 487, CHBE 587.

name: Carbon Capture, Conversion and Sequestration Technologies
description: Examination of carbon capture technologies, and CO2 conversion and sequestration options. Technical foundations on carbon cycle, thermodynamics, transport, absorption, adsorption, sequestration, process control, mineralization and conversion. Analysis of cases in the context of technology, policy and regulatory framework. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 488 or CHBE 588.
prerequisite: One of CHBE 346, MTRL 350 and one of CHBE 351, MTRL 263.

name: Thesis Proposal
description: Literature searching, planning, equipment design, experimental design for an individual research project leading to a written proposal and oral presentation.

name: Thesis Proposal-Environmental Topic
description: Literature search, planning, equipment design for an individual research project leading to a written proposal and oral presentation. Topic to be chosen from a selection of environmental topics offered by the department.

name: Thesis
description: Research project under the direction of a staff member.

name: Thesis-Environmental Topic
description: Environmental engineering research topic.

name: Thesis Proposal-Biotechnology Topic
description: Literature search, planning, equipment design for an individual research project leading to a written proposal and oral presentation. Topic to be chosen from a selection of biotechnology topics offered by the department.

name: Thesis Biotechnology Topic
description: Biotechnological engineering research topic.

name: Introduction to Chemical Engineering for Non-Chemical Engineers
Advanced Reactor Design
description: Topics vary from year to year, and may include kinetics of fluid-solid reactions of single particles, packed, moving, fluidized and transported bed reactors; rotary kilns; gas-liquid reaction kinetics and reactor design; reactor design for gas-liquid-solid and non-catalytic processes.

name: Engineering Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
description: Classical thermodynamic relations from a molecular perspective. Pressure-volume- temperature relations; chemical equilibria by Gibbs' method; vapor-liquid equilibria; thermodynamic calculations based on macroscopic and statistical methods; nonequilibrium processes; molecular simulations. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 451, CHBE 551.

name: Momentum, Heat and Mass Transfer
description: Prediction of velocity, temperature, and concentration profiles for flowing fluids; unifying concepts and analogies in momentum, heat, and mass transport; streamline flow and turbulence, molecular and eddy conduction and diffusion, boundary layers, smooth and rough conduits and other boundaries.

name: Mathematical Operations in Chemical Engineering
description: Topics vary from year to year. Amongst these will be dimensional analysis and model theory; treatment and interpretation of chemical engineering data; formulation and solution of differential and finite difference equations; graphical, numerical and statistical methods.

name: Biological Engineering
description: Biological process engineering in the fields of biotechnology and biomedical engineering; enzymatic and cellular kinetics; cell culture, process development and product recovery; bioreactor design and operation. Critical analysis of recent biological engineering research articles. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 381 or CHBE 560.

name: Applied Heterogeneous Catalysis
description: Techniques for characterizing catalysts and their surfaces. Commercial methods of preparing catalysts. Chemistry of catalytic reactions and the impact of catalyst properties, mechanisms and kinetics on reactor engineering. Applications of catalytic oxidations, hydrogenations, C-C bond formation and cracking.

name: Industrial Biotechnology Laboratory
description: Modern bioreactor technology, upstream and downstream processing of biotechnology products. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 564 or MICB 419.

name: Advanced Process Control
description: Discrete-time chemical system modelling; model-based predictive control; predictive controller design; analysis of design parameters; controller stability; robustness and performance analysis; selected topics from current developments in the literature.

name: Environmental Engineering and Sustainability
description: Topics may include: design of pollution control technologies, fate and transport of pollutants, function and rehabilitation of natural ecosystems, life cycle assessment, and industrial ecology and waste management.

name: Air Pollution Control
description: Characteristics of various air pollutants, their behaviour in the atmosphere, monitoring problems, technology of particle collection and control of pollutant gases. Particular problems of regional interest are discussed. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 485 or CHBE 575.

name: Electrochemical Science, Engineering and Technology
description: Electrochemical interfaces; electrode reactions; thermodynamics; kinetics and transport processes in electrochemical systems; experimental techniques. Electrochemical reactors and processes; modelling, design and economics. Electrochemical technologies; electrosynthesis, batteries and fuel cells. Electro-metallurgy; electrowinning and refining of metals, corrosion, leaching and cementation. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 477 or CHBE 577.

name: Energy Engineering
description: Supply and use of conventional and alternative fuels and energy. Design and operation of unit operations for processing of fossil fuels, biomass, and other energy sources. Environmental considerations of energy use. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 483 or CHBE 583.

name: Interfacial Phenomena
description: Outline of the physics and chemistry of interfaces; discussion of the part played by surface effects in technical processes. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 357, CHBE 487, CHBE 587.

name: Carbon Capture, Conversion and Sequestration Technologies
description: Examination of carbon capture technologies, and CO2 conversion and sequestration options. Technical foundations on carbon cycle, thermodynamics, transport, absorption, adsorption, sequestration, process control, mineralization and conversion. Analysis of cases in the context of technology, policy and regulatory framework. Credit will be granted for only one of CHBE 488 or CHBE 588.
prerequisite: One of CHBE 346, MTRL 350 and one of CHBE 351, MTRL 263.

name: Engineering Report
description: For M.Eng. students. Carry out a literature review, conduct a research or design project and prepare an engineering report under the supervision of a faculty member.

name: M.A.Sc. Thesis Proposal Development
description: Techniques for preparation of a critical literature review and focussed research proposal for M.A.Sc. candidates. Students perform oral and written critiques of published research in their area of study, define research questions and hypotheses, and develop a focussed research proposal.

name: Ph.D. Thesis Proposal Development
description: Techniques for preparation of a critical literature review and focussed research proposal for Ph.D. candidates. Students perform oral and written critiques of published research in their area of study, define research questions and hypotheses, and develop a focussed research proposal.

name: Seminar
description: Current topics in chemical and biological engineering research. A required seminar for all thesis graduate students (M.Sc., M.A.Sc., and Ph.D.) in the Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering.

name: Thesis
description: For M.A.Sc.

name: Thesis for Master of Arts in Children's Literature
Structure, Bonding and Equilibrium in Chemistry (Lecture)
description: Fundamentals of bonding theories, structural chemistry and equilibrium with applications relevant to modern society.
prerequisite: (Not open to students with credit for Chemistry 12. A satisfactory score on the UBC Chemistry Basic Skills Test.)

name: Foundations of Chemistry
description: Atomic and molecular properties, chemical reactions, bonding, nomenclature, kinetics, equilibrium processes, acids and bases, oxidation and reduction.  Intended for students who do not receive a satisfactory score on the UBC Chemistry Basic Skills Test, and need to establish a foundation of chemistry skills before proceeding to other first year chemistry courses.
prerequisite: (Not open to students with credit for Chemistry 12. Permission of the department head.)

name: Introductory Chemical Laboratory I
description: An introduction to the principles and techniques of the chemistry laboratory.

name: Structure and Bonding in Chemistry (Lecture)
description: Fundamentals of bonding theories, structural chemistry, with applications relevant to modern society.

name: Structure and Bonding in Chemistry
description: Fundamentals of bonding theories and structural chemistry, with applications relevant to modern society.

name: Thermodynamics, Kinetics and Organic Chemistry (Lecture)
description: Fundamentals of chemical reactivity: thermodynamics; kinetics; organic chemistry, including stereochemistry; applications relevant to modern society.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121.

name: Introductory Chemical Laboratory II
description: An introduction to the principles and techniques of the chemistry laboratory.

name: Chemistry for Engineering
description: Chemical bonding, properties of matter. Chemical thermodynamics with applications to phase equilibria, aqueous equilibria and electrochemistry. Processes at surfaces.

name: Introduction to Organic Chemistry
description: Structure, bonding and physical properties of aliphatic and aromatic compounds; mechanistic analysis of chemical reactivity of common functional groups with a focus on carbon-heteroatom bond formation; functional group interconversion and oxidation/reduction reactions. Only open to students in Chemistry or Biochemistry specializations. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 203 or CHEM 223, CHEM 225 or CHEM 233, 235.
prerequisite: Either (a) CHEM 113 or (b) all of CHEM 130, CHEM 135 or (c) SCIE 001.

name: Physical Chemistry
description: Chemical kinetics and thermodynamics and spectroscopy useful in biological, medical, agricultural, earth, and related sciences.
prerequisite: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184 and one of CHEM 130, CHEM 123, CHEM 154.

name: Coordination Chemistry
description: Fundamental concepts and principles governing bonding and reactivity of coordination complexes: ligand field theory; symmetry and point groups; frontier molecular orbital theory.

name: Introduction to Chemical Analysis
description: Quantitative chemical analysis; chemical and physical principles of spectrophotometry, potentiometry, and chromatography.
prerequisite: Either (a) CHEM 123 or (b) all of CHEM 130, CHEM 135 or (c) SCIE 001.

name: Structure, Bonding, and Equilibrium in Chemistry
description: Fundamentals of bonding theories, structural chemistry and equilibrium with applications relevant to modern society.
prerequisite: Not open to students with credit for CHEM 12. (A satisfactory score on the UBC Chemistry Basic Skills Test.)

name: Introductory Analytical Chemical Laboratory
description: An introduction to the principles and techniques in the analytical chemistry laboratory.
prerequisite: CHEM 210 and one of CHEM 123, CHEM 135.

name: Organic Chemistry
description: Spectroscopy of organic compounds.  Mechanistic analysis of chemical reactivity of common functional groups with a focus on carbon-carbon bond formation; functional group interconversion.  Preference will be given to students in Chemistry or Biochemistry specializations.
prerequisite: Either (a) one of CHEM 203, CHEM 223 or (b) a score of 76% or higher in CHEM 233.

name: Introduction to Chemical Analysis (Lecture)
description: Quantitative chemical analysis; chemical and physical principles of spectrophotometry, potentiometry, and chromatography. This course is not eligible for Credit/D/Fail grading.

name: Fundamentals of Reactivity in Inorganic Chemistry
description: Chemical reactivity of inorganic systems: oxidation/reduction chemistry; multiply-bonded systems; main group chemistry.

name: Introductory Synthetic Chemical Laboratory
description: An introduction to the principles and techniques in the synthetic organic and inorganic chemistry laboratory.

name: Introduction to Organic Chemistry (Lecture)
description: Structure, bonding and physical properties of aliphatic and aromatic compounds; mechanistic analysis of chemical reactivity of common functional groups with a focus on carbon-heteroatom bond formation; functional group interconversion and oxidation/reduction reactions. Only open to students in Chemistry or Biochemistry specializations. Students should consult the Credit Exclusion List for credit exclusions relating to second-year organic chemistry courses.

name: Organic Chemistry for the Biological Sciences
description: Reactions and properties of carbonyl compounds, carbohydrates, amino acids, nucleic acids. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 233 or CHEM 203 or CHEM 223.

name: Organic Chemistry Laboratory
description: Techniques of organic chemistry. To be taken in conjunction with, or in the term following, CHEM 233. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 235 or CHEM 203.

name: Intermediate Synthetic Chemistry Laboratory
description: Techniques in synthetic organic and inorganic chemistry. Open only to students in Chemistry or Biochemistry specializations.
prerequisite: Either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) all of CHEM 223, CHEM 225 or (c) all of CHEM 233, CHEM 235.

name: Inorganic Chemistry for Engineers
description: Chemistry of selected groups of inorganic compounds, considered in relation to industrial processes.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 130, CHEM 154, SCIE 001.

name: Communicating Chemistry
description: Effective argumentation and communication skills in chemistry. Only open to students in a Chemistry specialization.

name: Aqueous Environmental Chemistry
description: Properties of natural waters, including gas and solid equilibria, pH, redox, complexation analysis, corrosion treatment, ion exchange, colloids and microbial transformations.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 130, CHEM 220. (and Third year standing.)

name: Organic Chemistry for Engineers
description: A description of the properties and reactions of organic compounds.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 130, CHEM 154, SCIE 001.

name: Atmospheric Environmental Chemistry
description: Introduction to structure, composition and chemical processes occurring in Earth's atmosphere, including interactions with solar radiation, stratospheric ozone layer, photochemical smog and acid rain.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 130, CHBE 220. (and Third year standing.)

name: Biophysical Chemistry
description: Diffusion and transport phenomena; interaction of radiation and matter. Methods for determining molecular weight, size, and shape of molecules in solution.
prerequisite: One of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253 and either (a) a score of 76% or higher in CHEM 205 or (b) CHEM 304 or (c) PHYS 203.

name: Fundamentals of Thermodynamics and Statistical Mechanics
description: Principles of chemical thermodynamics; introduction to statistical mechanics; phase equilibria; electrochemistry.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 130 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

name: Instrumental Analytical Chemistry
description: Theory, design, and application of instrumental methods of chemical analysis including spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, electroanalysis, and chemical separations..

name: Advanced Organic Chemistry for the Life Sciences
description: Chemistry of organic substances having particular relevance to the life sciences.

name: Chemistry Integrated Laboratory I
description: Principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 203, CHEM 208, CHEM 211, CHEM 215, CHEM 225, CHEM 235.

name: Principles of Catalysis
description: Fundamental aspects of chemical catalysis: kinetic models; catalytic processes in biochemistry and industry; emerging topics in catalysis.

name: Practical Skills for Chemical Research
description: The nature of scientific research; practical skills for chemical research; communicating science.  Restricted to Honours students with third year standing and, with permission of the department Head, to Major students with satisfactory third year standing.

name: Integrated Chemistry Laboratory I
description: Principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry. Open only to students in Chemistry specializations.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 211, CHEM 215 and all of CHEM 208, CHEM 213, CHEM 245.

name: Research Ethics and Data Analysis Skills
description: Research ethics; data analysis skills for chemical research. Restricted to Honours students with third year standing and, with permission of the department Head, to Major students with satisfactory third year standing.

name: Introduction to Materials Chemistry
description: Basic principles of materials chemistry: classification; nomenclature; synthetic methods; characterization.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 208, CHEM 250 and one of CHEM 203, CHEM 223, CHEM 233, CHEM 260.

name: Advanced Organic Chemistry
description: Application of carbonyl group chemistry, cyclization reactions, conformational analysis and rearrangement reactions in organic synthesis.

name: Chemistry Integrated Laboratory II
description: Further development of principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry.

name: Global Challenges: A Chemical Perspective
description: Importance of chemistry in society. Detailed case studies drawn from modern chemistry: human health, energy, commodity chemicals, materials, green chemistry, agriculture.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 203, CHEM 223, CHEM 233, CHEM 260.

name: Integrated Chemistry Laboratory II
description: Further development of principles and techniques of modern chemistry applied by integrating experiments chosen from organic, inorganic, physical, and analytical chemistry.   Open only to students in Chemistry Major or Honours specializations.

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the winter term of the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the summer following the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

name: Principles of Spectroscopy
description: Rotational, vibrational, electronic and magnetic resonance spectroscopy and associated techniques; group theory.

name: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics and Spectroscopy
description: Principles of quantum mechanics; atomic wavefunctions; angular momentum; spin; atomic term symbols.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 113, CHEM 123, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

name: Diffraction Methods
description: Crystal structures; point and space groups; X-ray diffraction, neutron diffraction, electron diffraction of gases and surfaces. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 402 or CHEM 514.

name: Surface Chemistry and Surface Analysis
description: Surfaces and phenomena occurring at surfaces and interfaces: adsorption, thermodynamic treatments, technological applications. Methods for characterization and modification of surfaces. Dynamic electrochemistry and its application to understanding fuel cells.
prerequisite: CHEM 304 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 226, MATH 253, MATH 263.

name: Computational Chemistry
description: Application of numerical techniques to study chemical systems; molecular simulation. Computer programming experience is not required.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 130, CHEM 154 and one of PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 108, PHYS 117, PHYS 118, PHYS 170 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121. (and Third-year standing.)

name: Biophysical Chemistry
description: Interactions of macromolecules in solution: ligand, antibody and ion binding to macromolecules; thermodynamics of polymer solutions; excluded volume effects; phase separation; partition in two phase polymer solutions.

name: Polymer Chemistry
description: Structure and availability of monomers; Propagation mechanisms; synthesis of polymers with predetermined properties; measurement and interpretation of physical properties of polymers.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 213, CHEM 260 and one of CHEM 205, CHEM 304, CHBE 220.

name: Statistical Mechanics in Chemistry
description: Introductory concepts of statistical mechanics and statistical thermodynamics. Applications to chemistry with emphasis on understanding chemical reactivity. Credit will be granted  for only one of CHEM 503/CHEM 407 or PHYS 455.

name: Properties of Materials
description: Electromagnetic, optical, thermal and mechanical properties, and chemical reactivity of solids; electrons in periodic systems: bands, zones; excitations: excitons, phonons, plasmons, polaritons; crystalline order and disorder; ionic conductivity. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 410 or CHEM 502.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 304, PHYS 203 and one of CHEM 312, PHYS 304.

name: Synthesis and Chemistry of Natural Products
description: Methods and tactics for the synthesis of biologically active natural products and analogs, particularly alkaloids, polyketides, steroids and terpenes. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 411 or CHEM 566.

name: Electronic Structure of Atoms and Molecules
description: Introduction to variational methods; many-electron systems; semi-empirical methods; perturbation theory; computational methods.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 312, PHYS 304 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

name: Bioorganic Chemistry
description: Enzyme catalysis; mechanistic enzymology; chemistry of cofactors; biosynthetic transformations; natural product biosynthesis; topics in chemical biology. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 413, CHEM 569, or BIOC 403.

name: Organometallic Chemistry
description: The chemistry of compounds containing organic groups directly bonded to metals and metalloids. Emphasis will be placed on the structure and bonding of the compounds and their use in synthetic chemistry. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 418 or CHEM 524.

name: Applications of Materials Chemistry
description: Contemporary materials chemistry, including design and synthesis of materials for energy, electronics, and health applications.

name: Principles of Chemical Separation
description: Unified theory of separation science; liquid and gas chromatography; capillary electrophoresis; electrochemical and spectroscopic detection; separation methods coupled with mass spectrometry and tandem mass spectrometry; biochemical applications. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 434 or CHEM 534.

name: Projects in Experimental Chemistry - PROJCTS EXP CHEM
description: Principles of experimental design, practice and problem solving in chemistry, including the opportunity to pursue projects in a research setting.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 345, CHEM 335. (Students satisfying the prerequisite requirement using CHEM 335 must have fourth-year standing in a Chemistry Combined Major specialization.)

name: Nuclear Chemistry and Radiochemistry
description: Basic treatment of the nucleus, with analogy to concepts in chemistry. Nuclear stabilities and associated radioactive decay processes. Nuclear structure. Applications of radioisotopes in chemistry. The interaction of radiation with matter.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 123, CHEM 130. (and Third year standing. CHEM 312 is recommended.)

name: Projects in Experimental Chemistry - PROJCTS EXP CHEM
description: Principles of experimental design, practice and problem solving in chemistry, including the opportunity to pursue projects in a research setting.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 345, CHEM 335. (Students satisfying the prerequisite requirement using CHEM 335 must have fourth-year standing in a Chemistry Combined Major specialization.)

name: Projects in Experimental Chemistry - PROJCTS EXP CHEM
description: Principles of experimental design, practice and problem solving in chemistry, including the opportunity to pursue projects in a research setting.
prerequisite: One of CHEM 345, CHEM 335. (Students satisfying the prerequisite requirement using CHEM 335 must have fourth-year standing in a Chemistry Combined Major specialization.)

name: Directed Studies in Chemistry - T1 DST CHEMISTRY
description: Students will undertake an investigation of a specific topic as agreed upon by the student and the faculty supervisor. Open to third- and fourth-year chemistry students.

name: Directed Studies in Chemistry - T2 DST CHEMISTRY
description: Students will undertake an investigation of a specific topic as agreed upon by the student and the faculty supervisor. Open to third- and fourth-year chemistry students.

name: Directed Studies in Chemistry - DST CHEMISTRY
description: Students will undertake an investigation of a specific topic as agreed upon by the student and the faculty supervisor. Open to third- and fourth-year chemistry students.

name: Seminar and Thesis
description: Original research work under the direction of a faculty member. Weekly seminar. Required of all Honours students. Open to Majors students with a satisfactory standing and permission of the department head.

name: Organic Synthesis: A Mechanistic Approach
description: Presentation, mechanistic discussion and analysis of modern synthetic methods using principles of physical organic chemistry. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 460 or CHEM 560.

name: Synthetic Chemical Biology
description: Synthetic, mechanistic, and biochemical approaches to chemical biology, including the design of drugs, probes, and catalysts. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 461 or CHEM 561.

name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the fall term of the fifth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

name: Co-operative Work Placement III
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Taken during the summer following fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Chemistry.

name: Structure Determination and Reaction Analysis
description: Application of mass spectrometry and modern spectroscopic techniques, including multidimensional NMR spectroscopy, to reaction analysis and detailed characterization of complex organic and organometallic molecular structures.
prerequisite: CHEM 245 and one of CHEM 313, CHEM 318, CHEM 330.

name: Advanced Physical Chemistry of the Solid State
description: Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 502 or CHEM 410.

name: Equilibrium Statistical Mechanics in Chemistry
description: Introductory principles of Statistical Mechanics with illustrations of chemical importance. Applications to molecular gases, liquids, solids, independent particle statistics, electric and magnetic moments, radiation, chemical equilibrium and reaction rates. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 407/CHEM 503 or PHYS 455.

name: Polymer Chemistry
description: Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 506 or CHEM 406.

name: Topics in Biophysical Chemistry - BIOPHYSICAL CHEM
Crystal Structures
description: Crystal structures and structural analysis by the methods of X-ray diffraction and neutron diffraction. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 402 or CHEM 514.

name: Topics in Molecular Spectroscopy - TOP MOL SPECTROS
Advanced Applications in Organometallic Chemistry
description: Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 418 or CHEM 524.

name: Principles of Chemical Separation
description: Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 534 or CHEM 434.

name: Topics in Analytical Chemistry - TPCS ANALYT CHEM
Seminar in Chemistry - INORGANIC SEMINR
description: Pass/Fail.

name: Organic Chemistry: Building Molecules and Understanding Reactivity
description: Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 460 or CHEM 560.

name: Advanced Chemical Biology
description: Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 461 and CHEM 561.

name: Advanced Organic Synthesis
description: Discussion of modern synthetic methods and applications to the synthesis of complex organic molecules. Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 566 or CHEM 411.

name: Application of Spectroscopy to Organic Structural Determinations
description: A problem solving course to illustrate the application of NMR, mass spectrometry, ORD, CD, etc. to elucidation of structures of organic and organometallic compounds.

name: Advanced Bioorganic Chemistry
description: Credit will be granted for only one of CHEM 569, CHEM 413, or BIOC 403.

name: Basic Chinese I: Part 1 (Non-Heritage)
description: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Mandarin Chinese, an active vocabulary of about 250 Chinese words, and basic grammar. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 131 or CHIN 101 or CHIN 134.

name: Basic Chinese I: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)
description: Continuation of CHIN 131. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 133 or CHIN 103 or CHIN 134.

name: Basic Chinese I: Part 1 (Heritage)
description: Skills in listening to and speaking Mandarin and reading and writing modern written Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 141 or CHIN 111 or CHIN 144.

name: Basic Chinese I: Part 2 (Heritage)
description: Continuation of CHIN 141. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 143 or CHIN 113 or CHIN 144.

name: Basic Chinese II: Part 1 (Non-Heritage)
description: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing Mandarin Chinese, active vocabulary of about 750 Chinese words, and basic grammar. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 231 or CHIN 105 or CHIN 234.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 103, CHIN 104, CHIN 133, CHIN 134.

name: Basic Chinese II: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)
description: Continuation of CHIN 231. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 233 or CHIN 107, or CHIN 234.

name: Basic Chinese II: Part 1 (Heritage)
description: Skills in listening to and speaking Mandarin and reading and writing modern written Chinese. Emphasis on reading and writing. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 241 or CHIN 115 or CHIN 244.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 113, CHIN 114, CHIN 143, CHIN 144.

name: Basic Chinese II: Part 2 (Heritage)
description: Continuation of CHIN 241. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 243 or CHIN 117 or CHIN 244.

name: Intermediate Chinese I: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)
description: Continuation of CHIN 331. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 333 or CHIN 203 or CHIN 334.

name: Intermediate Chinese I: Part 1 (Non-Heritage)
description: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 331 or CHIN 201 or CHIN 334.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 107, CHIN 108, CHIN 233, CHIN 234.

name: Intermediate Chinese II: Part I (Non-Heritage)
description: Skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 335 or CHIN 205 or CHIN 338.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 203, CHIN 204, CHIN 333, CHIN 334.

name: Intermediate Chinese II: Part 2 (Non-Heritage)
description: Continuation of CHIN 335. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 337 or CHIN 207 or CHIN 338.

name: Intermediate Chinese I: Part 2 (Heritage)
description: Continuation of CHIN 341. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 343 or CHIN 213 or CHIN 344.

name: Intermediate Chinese I: Part 1 (Heritage)
description: Integrated skills in modern Chinese. Focus on reading, writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 341 or CHIN 211 or CHIN 344.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 117, CHIN 118, CHIN 243, CHIN 244.

name: Intermediate Chinese II: Part I (Heritage)
description: Integrated skills in modern Chinese. Focus on reading, writing, and better understanding of Chinese culture. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 345 or CHIN 215 or CHIN 348.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 213, CHIN 214, CHIN 343, CHIN 344.

name: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing I (Non-Heritage)
description: Reading and writing skills addressing social, cultural, and economic issues. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 405. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 401 or CHIN 301 or CHIN 404.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338.

name: Intermediate Chinese II: Part 2 (Heritage)
description: Continuation of CHIN 345. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 347 or CHIN 217 or CHIN 348.

name: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing II (Non-Heritage)
description: Continuation of CHIN 401. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 407. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 403 or CHIN 303 or CHIN 404.

name: Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing I (Non-Heritage)
description: More formal styles of oral and written communication. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 401. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 405 or CHIN 305 or CHIN 408.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 207, CHIN 208, CHIN 337, CHIN 338.

name: Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing II (Non-Heritage)
description: Continuation of CHIN 405. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 403. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 407 or CHIN 307 or CHIN 408.

name: Media Chinese I (Heritage)
description: Reading and understanding Chinese as used in newspapers, radio/TV, and the internet news. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 415 or CHIN 309.

name: Introduction to Classical Chinese I (Non-Heritage)
description: The basics of classical Chinese grammar, with short illustrations from texts of the Warring States and early Han Period. Credit will be granted for only one of CLCH 389 or CHIN 388.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 107, CHIN 108, CHIN 233, CHIN 234, JAPN 103, JAPN 151, JAPN 201, JAPN 260, KORN 200. (Or placement approval.)

name: Business Chinese I (Heritage)
description: Reading, writing, and presentation skills in business documentation, focusing on technical Chinese as used in the workplace. Emphasis on specialized vocabulary and development of communicative competence as relevant to advertising, the stock market and E-commerce. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 435 or CHIN 321.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

name: Business Chinese II (Heritage)
description: Reading, writing, and presentation skills in business documentation, focusing on technical Chinese as used in the workplace. Emphasis on specialized vocabulary and development of communicative competence as relevant to legal and financial documents such as contracts, investments, and insurance. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 437 or CHIN 323.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

name: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing II (Heritage)
description: Continuation of CHIN 441. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 437 and/or CHIN 447. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 443 or CHIN 313 or CHIN 444.

name: Advanced Chinese Reading and Writing I (Heritage)
description: Transition from language to literature. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 435 and CHIN 445. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 441 or CHIN 311 or CHIN 444.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 217, CHIN 218, CHIN 347, CHIN 348.

name: Advanced Chinese Speaking and Writing II (Heritage)
description: Continuation of CHIN 445. Can be taken concurrently with CHIN 437and/or CHIN 443. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 447 or CHIN 317 or CHIN 448.

name: Early Classical Chinese Poetry (to Han)
description: Readings in classical poetry from the pre-Qin to the end of the Han Dynasties, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 461 or CHIN 464.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Early Classical Chinese Poetry (Han to Tang)
description: Readings in classical poetry from the Six Dynasties to early Tang, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 463 or CHIN 464.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Later Classical Chinese Poetry (after Tang)
description: Readings in classical poetry from the Song to the Qing dynasties, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any CHIN courses lower than 400-level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 473 or 474.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Later Classical Chinese Poetry (Tang)
description: Readings in classical poetry from the time of Du Fu (712-770) to the end of the Tang Dynasty, at an advanced level. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 471 or 474.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Modern Chinese Literature I (Heritage)
description: Selected readings from the May Fourth Era to present. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 481 or CHIN 484.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Contemporary Chinese Fiction in Film
description: Contemporary Chinese films from the 21st century adapted from literary works.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448. (Or placement approval.)

name: Modern Chinese Literature II (Heritage)
description: Historical continuation of CHIN 481. Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 483 or CHIN 484.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Classical Chinese I (Heritage)
description: The development of early Chinese from the classical period through the Six Dynasties (5th century BCE to 6th century CE). Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 491 or CHIN 431 or CHIN 494.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Classical Chinese II (Heritage)
description: Focus in on the Tang and Song dynasties (617 - 1279). Not to be taken concurrently with any of the following CHIN 400-level language courses: CHIN 441/ 443/ 444/ 445/ 447/ 448/ 435/ 437. Credit will be granted for only one of CHIN 493 or CHIN 433 or CHIN 494.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 313, CHIN 314, CHIN 317, CHIN 318, CHIN 323, CHIN 437, CHIN 443, CHIN 444, CHIN 447, CHIN 448.

name: Greek and Roman Mythology
description: Greek and Roman mythology and its interpretation. Emphasis on ancient texts read in English translation.

name: Greek and Latin Roots of English
description: Greek and Latin roots of English vocabulary and grammar, with an introduction to language history and Greek and Roman culture.

name: Greek Philosophy I
description: The Pre-Socratics; Socrates; Sophists; Plato. Recommended as preparation for CLST/PHIL 212 and PHIL 310.

name: Greek Philosophy II
description: Aristotle; selections from Hellenistic and Late Antique Philosophy. Recommended as preparation for PHIL 310 and PHIL 311.

name: Ancient Greece
description: A survey of the ancient Greek world from the Minoan and Mycenaean (about 2000-1000 BCE) to the Hellenistic Period (323-30 BCE).

name: Gladiators, Games, and Spectacle in the Greek and Roman World
description: History, development, and social function of various forms of spectacle in ancient Greece and Rome, from the Olympic games to the Roman arena.

name: Ancient Rome
description: A survey of the ancient Roman world from the foundation of the city to the death of Constantine.

name: The Technical Terms of Medicine and Biological Science
description: Acquaints the student with the Greek and Latin elements from which most specialized terms of modern medicine are constructed. Intended primarily for students planning to enter the medical, pharmaceutical, or biological sciences.

name: Ancient Technology: Greece and Rome
description: The origins, achievements, and social impacts of applied technology in the Greek and Roman world from the Bronze Age to Late Antiquity (c. 1500 BCE - 400 CE), with special attention to archaeological evidence.

name: Roman Law
description: The development of Roman private law during the classical period with special attention to family law, contract and delict.

name: Women in the Bronze Age, Classical Greek and Hellenistic Cultures
description: The images projected in mythology, literature, and art are compared with realities of women's lives insofar as they can be reconstructed from historical, legal, and archaeological records.

name: Greek Epic
description: Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, in translation.

name: The Roman Army
description: Rome's military from the early Republic to the Imperial period. Topics range from those of a military nature such as equipment and strategy to social topics such as policing and marriage of soldiers.

name: Greek Art and Architecture
description: The visual culture of the ancient Greek world in the second and first millennia BCE, especially from c. 1000 to 30 BCE.

name: Roman Art and Architecture
description: The visual culture of the ancient Roman world from the 8th century BCE to the 4th century CE.

name: Roman Religion
description: Roman religions between the ninth century BCE and the fourth century CE, including mystery religions, magic, emperor worship, and early Christianity, with particular attention devoted to the primary sources. Some knowledge of ancient Rome is recommended.

name: The Roman Republic
description: Rome from the foundation to the Augustan settlement. Constitutional development; the workings and failure of the Republican political system; acquisition and growth of Empire; the political, social, and economic consequences of imperialism.

name: The Athenians and their Empire
description: The sources (literary, epigraphical and other) for Athens' emergence as one of the two leading city-states in late archaic and classical Greece and the stages by which her empire grew.

name: Alexander the Great and his Empire
description: The rise of Macedon under Philip II leading to its domination of Greece and the overthrow of the Persian Empire by his son, Alexander; the subsequent spread of Greek civilization in the East.

name: Life and Society in Classical Antiquity - LF SOC CLAS ANTQ
description: Topics in Greek and Roman life and society.

name: Seminar in Classical Art and Archaeology - SEM CLS ART&ARCH
description: Selected topics in Greek or Roman art and archaeology, with an emphasis on research. Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, GRNE, CNRS.

name: Seminar in the Reception of the Classical World - RECPTN CLAS WRLD
description: Selected topics in the reception of the classicial world in its own time and in later eras, with an emphasis on research. Prerequisite: at least one 3-credit upper-level course of content appropriate for the topic of the seminar (to be established by individual instructors). Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, GRNE, CNRS.

name: Topics in Greek Art and Archaeology - TPC GREEK A & A
Seminar in Classical History - SEM CLASSCL HIST
description: Selected topics in Greek or Roman history, with an emphasis on research. Restricted to majors and honours students in CLST, CLAS, CLAH, ARGR, GRNE, CNRS.

name: Basic Interviewing Skills
description: Development of basic interviewing skills for counselling and guidance.

name: Family Education and Consultation
description: Examination of current theories and practices in family education and consultation.

name: Career Counselling
description: Critical survey of career counselling theory and practice.

name: Introduction to Theories of Counselling
description: An overview of selected theories of counselling.

name: The Role of the Teacher in Guidance
description: This course is designed to assist the teacher in understanding and using guidance techniques for day-to-day use in the classroom. The emphasis will be on techniques for working with people towards better self-understanding and better perspectives of alternatives.

name: Guidance: Planning and Decision-making
description: The work of the beginning counsellor and guidance worker in assisting students with educational, vocational, and personal planning and decision-making.

name: The Personal and Social Development of the Adult
description: Personal and social adjustment issues for professional counsellors; basic skills necessary for effective group counselling.

name: Counselling Adolescents
description: Theory, research, and practice of counselling adolescents.

name: School Counselling
description: Theory and practice of school counselling.

name: Counselling Adults
description: Major issues and problems of adult development. Selection of appropriate counselling interventions for use in education and other counselling settings.

name: Psychological Assessment in Counselling - PSYC ASSESS CNSL
description: The use of standardized measures of mental ability, achievement, aptitude, interest and personality.

name: Gender and Sex Role Issues in Counselling
description: Theory, research, and practice in the area of gender and sex role issues related to counselling.

name: Group Counselling
description: Understanding, designing and knowledge of groups and how to conduct them for use in counselling and guidance services.

name: Family Counselling - Interventions and Research
description: Main theoretical and therapeutic approaches of contemporary family counselling with emphasis on intervention and critical research issues in educational and other counselling settings.

name: Career Planning and Decision-Making Counselling
description: Theory, research, and practice of career planning and decision counselling.

name: Individual and Family Counselling Theories and Interventions - IND&FAM CNSL T&I
description: Major counselling theories, interventions for change and corresponding skill development.

name: Research in Counselling Psychology
description: Assumptions and methods of major research paradigms.
prerequisite: One of EDUC 500, EPSE 481 and one of EPSE 482, EPSE 483.

name: Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC 1
description: Investigation and report of a problem.

name: Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC 2
description: Investigation and report of a problem.

name: Problems in Education - PROB IN EDUC
description: Investigation and report of a problem.

name: Ethics in Counselling Psychology
description: Ethical decision-making and legal issues in counselling psychology research and practice.

name: Program Development and Professional Practice in Counselling
description: Designing, implementing and assessing counselling programs in schools, colleges, universities, and other counselling settings.
prerequisite: One of EDUC 500, EPSE 481 and one of EPSE 482, EPSE 483.

name: History and Systems of Psychology - HIST SYST PSYC
Stress, Coping and Adaptation Related to Trauma and Addictions
description: Theories, research, and applications of psychosocial stress and coping processes, with a particular focus on counselling issues and contexts related to trauma and addictions.

name: Cross-Cultural Counselling
description: Critical analysis of cross-cultural counselling theory, research and practice.

name: Supervised Training in Counselling - SUPRVSD TRAINING
description: Initial counselling experience under faculty supervision in department training centres.

name: Field Experiences - FIELD EXPERIENCE
description: For students in the master's program. Pass/Fail.

name: Field Experiences - FIELD EXPERIENCE
description: For students in the master's program. Pass/Fail.

name: Advanced Assessment
description: Counselling psychology research and practice in adult personality assessment, including ethics of testing and use with special populations.
prerequisite: One of PSYC 303, EPSE 528 and CNPS 532.

name: Theoretical Perspectives in Counselling Psychology - THRTCL PRSP CNPS
description: Major theoretical traditions in Counselling Psychology and illustration of the links among theory, research and practices; perspectives on Counselling Psychology as a distinct field of specialization.

name: Research Approaches in Counselling Psychology - RES APPR TO CNPS
Supervision of Counselling Practice
description: Supervision requires both knowledge of supervision models and practices, and skills to implement them. This course involves a seminar and practicum to integrate the two requirements of the subject. (For those on the Doctoral program.) Pass/Fail.

name: Pre-Doctoral Internship
description: A 1600-hour supervised internship in Counselling Psychology. Internship sites offer counselling services as detailed in the "Speciality Guidelines for the Delivery of Services by Counselling Psychologists" (APA). Pass/Fail.

name: Doctoral Dissertation
description: Pass/Fail.

SubjectName: Classical, Near Eastern and Religious Studies
name: The Archaeology of Ancient Cyprus
description: An overview of the archaeology of ancient Cyprus from the island's initial colonization in the 10th millennium BCE through the period of its rule as part of the Roman Empire (4th century CE).

SubjectName: Classical, Near Eastern and Religious Studies
name: Temples, Tombs, and Tyrants: The Archaeology of the Middle East, Greece, and Rome
description: The rise of civilizations, cultural interconnections, and power dynamics in the ancient Middle East (including Egypt), Greece, and Rome (10,000 BCE - 300 CE). Archaeological methods and interpretation, and analysis of ancient artifacts in UBC collections.

SubjectName: Classical, Near Eastern and Religious Studies
name: Theories of Myth
description: Origins, nature, and transmission of myth in the Western tradition, with particular attention devoted to the interpretation of myth from ancient times up to the present. Some background in myth is recommended.

SubjectName: Classical, Near Eastern and Religious Studies
name: Honours Essay

SubjectName: Classical, Near Eastern and Religious Studies
name: Pro-Seminar in Ancient Mediterranean Studies: Selected Topics - SEM MEDITER STDY

SubjectName: Classical, Near Eastern and Religious Studies
name: Studies in Law and Society - STUDIES LAW

SubjectName: Classical, Near Eastern and Religious Studies
name: Master's Thesis

SubjectName: Classical, Near Eastern and Religious Studies
name: Doctoral Dissertation
Basic Cantonese II
description: Elementary level (part II) Cantonese for non-heritage learners. Continuation of CNTO 301. Focus on training for basic listening, conversational, and reading skills.

name: Basic Cantonese I
description: Elementary level (part I) course in Cantonese for non-heritage learners with no prior exposure to or background in Cantonese. Focus on training for basic listening and conversational skills in Cantonese. Heritage speakers of Mandarin are NOT eligible.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 107, CHIN 233, CHIN 108, CHIN 234. (Or placement approval.)

name: Basic Cantonese for Mandarin Speakers
description: Basic oral and presentation skills in Cantonese. This is an accelerated course that covers content and topics similar to CNTO 301 and CNTO 303, but is structured specifically for heritage speakers of Mandarin.
prerequisite: One of CHIN 243, CHIN 244. (Or placement approval.)

name: Intermediate Cantonese I
description: Intermediate lower level (part I) Cantonese for non-heritage learners.
prerequisite: One of CNTO 303, CNTO 311. (Or placement approval.)

name: Advanced Cantonese through Popular Culture
description: Popular culture in Hong Kong from media such as television, cinema, popular music, literature, social media, etc., through advanced authentic Cantonese listening and reading materials.  Open to non-heritage and heritage speakers of Mandarin and/or Cantonese.
prerequisite: CNTO 401. (Prior to registration, a minimum of 9 credits of 300-level ASIA coursework is strongly recommended.)

name: Financial Accounting
description: Construction and interpretation of financial reports prepared primarily for external use. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 293 or COMM 293.

name: Market Research
description: The process of marketing research including problem/opportunity formulation, research objectives, data sources, research instrument design, sampling, data collection and processing and methods of data analysis.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of ECON 315, ECON 316 or (b) ECON 308.

name: Managerial Accounting
description: Introduction to the development and use of accounting information for management planning and control and the development of cost information for financial reports. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 294 or COMM 294.

name: Corporate Finance
description: Corporate enterprise decisions including capital budgeting; capital structure choice; and financial policies, tools, and valuation.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of ECON 315, ECON 316 or (b) ECON 308.

name: International Financial Markets and Institutions
description: Structure, nature and institutions of foreign exchange markets, including spot, forward, futures, options, and offshore currency markets. Factors affecting exchange rates are also discussed. Credit will be granted for only one of ECON 456, COEC 377, or COMM 377.

name: Investment Theory
description: Basic concepts of finance, including security valuation, security markets, and financial decisions concerning risk and return. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 371 or COMM 371.
prerequisite: Either (a) ECON 308 or (b) all of ECON 315, ECON 316.

name: The Economics and Policy of the Environment, Energy, and Natural Resources
description: Economic analysis of environmental problems, energy systems, and natural resources. Policy options to help resolve these issues. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 475 or COMM 487.
prerequisite: ECON 315 and one of ECON 316, ECON 308.

name: Strategic Management
description: Concepts and processes for the strategic management of single- and multi-business unit private sector enterprises, analyzed using the case method. Integrates methodologies from economic and organizational theory to form the foundations for strategic analyses.

name: Database Technology
description: Theory and technology of database management from an applications perspective; database design; database administration. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 437, COMM 437, or CPSC 304.

name: New Enterprise Development
description: The particular problems and experiences encountered in starting, developing, and managing new enterprises. The course includes lectures, guest speakers, and case studies.

name: International Business Management
description: Development of general environmental framework for international business studies by drawing on international and development economics, research into government-business relations and studies in comparative socio-cultural systems and political systems. Credit will be granted for only one of COEC 498 or COMM 498.

name: Technical Communication in Civil Engineering
description: Written and oral communication in civil engineering.  Business correspondence, business meetings, poster presentations, oral presentations and technical reports.  Restricted to students in second year of the Civil Engineering program.
prerequisite: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150.

name: Introduction to Civil Engineering
description: The design process; graphical, visualization and computational tools; civil engineering disciplines; decision-making; teamwork; conceptual design project reflecting community, economic, environmental, sustainability and technical considerations.
prerequisite: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150.

name: Fluid Mechanics I
description: Fluid properties, hydrostatics, kinematics, and fluid dynamics: energy and momentum methods with applications. Dimensional analysis, modelling, introduction to flow in pipes and forces on immersed objects.

name: Soil Mechanics I
description: Soil classification, principle of effective stress, analysis of seepage, filter criteria, introduction to shear strength and slope stability analysis.

name: Solid Mechanics
description: Stress and strain, Hooke's law, axially loaded members, torsion, shear forces and bending moments in beams, bending and shear stresses in beams, composite members, introduction to inelastic and statically indeterminate problems.

name: Structural Mechanics
description: Deflection of beams and structural systems; analysis of determinate structures; combined axial load and bending; beam- columns; buckling (stability); biaxial stresses and strains; construction and testing of model structures.

name: Plane Surveying
description: Theory and application of plane surveying methods. Introduction to and use of compass, transit, tape, and level. Construction and topographic surveys. Reduction of field data and construction of drawings. Demonstration of modern instruments, remote sensing methods and geographical information systems (GIS).

name: Engineering and Sustainable Development
description: Implications of a finite biosphere and the complexities inherent in environmental decision-making. Credit will only be granted for only one of CIVL 200 or CIVL 250.

name: Construction Engineering and Management
description: Project delivery systems: traditional; construction management; turnkey; project management. Network planning methods. Activity planning, including construction methods selection. Estimating, bidding and bonding. Project control tools and procedures. Human resources, including equity considerations; occupational health and safety and quality control.

name: Modelling and Decision-Making in Civil Engineering
description: Introduction to systems engineering; applications of decision-making, modelling, and programming, including probabilistic analyses and optimization, to civil engineering projects; review of numerical methods

name: Civil Engineering Impacts
description: The social and biophysical context of infrastructure and the impact of civil engineering on people, the economy, and the environment. Specific topics vary from year to year.

name: Computational Tools in Civil Engineering
description: Computational and numerical solutions to civil engineering problems; application to a civil engineering design project that reflects community, economic, environmental and technical considerations.
prerequisite: All of CIVL 201, CIVL 210, CIVL 215, CIVL 231 and one of MATH 255, MATH 256.

name: Introduction to Environmental Engineering
description: Environmental legislation; risk assessment; urban water; mass balance; water and wastewater treatment; environmental impact assessment.

name: Soil Mechanics II
description: One-dimensional compression and stress-strain response of soils with application to estimation of the settlements and capacities of foundations and of retaining walls.

name: Fluid Mechanics II
description: Two dimensional flow around immersed objects; velocity and pressure fields; lift and drag on cylinders and aerofoils; fluid loads on structures and structural response; pumps and turbines; analysis and design of pipeline systems; unsteady flow in pipes; frictionless waterhammer analysis.
prerequisite: All of CIVL 203, CIVL 215 and one of MATH 255, MATH 256.

name: Fundamentals of Environmental Engineering
description: Environmental engineering issues and projects; application of scientific and engineering principles to addressing these; soil, water and air pollution, and remediation.

name: Hydrology and Open Channel Flow
description: Introduction to open channel hydraulics, engineering hydrology, and water resource systems; estimation of design discharge; flood statistics; nonuniform steady open channel flow; energy and momentum principles, backwater analysis; culvert and bridge hydraulics.

name: Civil Engineering Materials
description: The structure and properties of common Civil Engineering materials: aggregates, Portland cement, concrete, wood, steel and other construction materials. The emphasis is on the relationship between the structure of materials and their mechanical and durability properties.

name: Steel and Timber Design
description: Introduction to limit states design of steel and timber structures: design objectives, design loads and load combinations, structural safety, material properties, design of tension and compression members, beams, columns, and connections.

name: Transportation Engineering I
description: The analysis and design of the elements of transportation facilities in development of transport technology; vehicle motion; vehicle/pavement interaction; elements of road design; principles of queuing and roadway capacity; rail transit performance and capacity analysis; economics as applied to transport.

name: Professionalism and Law in Civil Engineering
description: The Engineers and Geoscientists Act; professional ethics, conflicts of interest, confidentiality and accountability; health and safety; sustainable development and environmental stewardship; equity considerations; design and construction contracts, specifications and tendering; labour and employment law; dispute resolution; evidence and expert witnesses; torts and legal liability.

name: Engineering Economic Analysis
description: Time value of money; cash flow analysis; comparing options; depreciation, taxes, and inflation; financial accounting; company structures; public sector projects; decision-making.

name: Water Treatment and Waste Management
description: Processes used in water and wastewater treatment. Conditions which necessitate treatment of water or wastewater, water and wastewater treatment processes and plant design. Municipal services required and associated with solid waste management.

name: Geo-Environmental Engineering
description: Environmental contamination, regulatory requirements, site investigation, migration of contaminants, containment systems, site remediation technologies, design considerations related to soil-contaminant interactions, hydrogeology, geochemistry and types of contaminants. Design and performance case histories.

name: Municipal Engineering
description: Design of municipal infrastructure, including streets, water supply networks, and sewers, garbage collection and solid waste management. Focus is on solutions for providing an adequate water supply, collecting and disposing of stormwater and sewage, and managing excess stormwater flow.

name: Structural Analysis
description: Introduction to indeterminate structural analysis; approximate analysis of structures; calculation of displacements using virtual work; flexibility (force) method; stiffness method for frames; moment distribution method; influence lines, introduction to structural dynamics.

name: Design of Earth Dams and Containment Structures
description: Purpose and types of dams; design criteria; construction sequence; compaction; seepage; filter design; factors influencing the design of earth dams; stability and deformation under static and earthquake loading; slope protection; field instrumentation.

name: Foundation Engineering II
description: Aspects of Geotechnical Engineering. Design considerations illustrated by case histories pertinent to BC. Topics include: site investigation, terrain analyses, in situ testing, groundwater problems, deep foundations, tie back walls and bracing, tailings impoundments, Northern construction, ground ice, dikes and dams engineering. Many case histories presented in part by prominent consulting engineers in BC.

name: Foundation Engineering I
description: An introduction to the process of foundation engineering. Empirical and analytical approaches used in current professional practice.
