description: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

name: Co-operative Work Placement.
description: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

name: Co-operative Work Placement.
description: Supervised work experience in an approved organization for a minimum of 15 weeks. Restricted to students in the Co-operative Education Program in the Faculty of Forestry. Final work term report required.

name: Directed Studies in Forestry - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in forestry.

name: Directed Studies in Forestry - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in forestry.

name: Directed Studies in Forestry - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in forestry.

name: Directed Studies in Forestry - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in forestry.

name: Directed Studies in Forestry - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in forestry.

name: Directed Studies in Forestry - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: In special cases and with the approval of the instructor concerned, a student may carry on directed studies of specific problems in forestry.

name: Coastal Field School
description: Site diagnosis and preparation of management options in coastal forests. Extrasessional course; fees will be assessed to meet expenses.
prerequisite: (Third or fourth year-standing in the B.S.F. program.)

name: Visual Resource Management and Planning for Aesthetics
description: Methodologies for visual analysis, perceptions, planning and management of urban, natural and working landscapes, and implications for sustainable land-use management and community engagement.  Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 490 or FRST 551.

name: Environmental Perception
description: How individuals perceive their environment.  Emphasis will be given visual perception in the context of natural resource issues and the effects of those perceptions on individuals including issues of human wellbeing.

name: Biological Diversity and Forest Management
description: Principles, problems, and practices of managing  forests and nature reserves for biological diversity; integration of forestry and wildlife with particular emphasis on diversity of all life forms.

name: B.Sc. Thesis in Forestry
description: An independent study or research project of a subject of special interest to the student under the direction of a staff member. Available only to students in the BSFS Honours specialization.

name: Communications and Professionalism
description: Preparing professional reports and presentations; professionalism and professional ethics.

name: B.S.F. Thesis
description: An independent study or research project on an approved topic, developed under the guidance of a Faculty member. Available only to students in their graduating year.

name: Teaching and Learning in Forestry
description: An evidence-based examination of teaching and learning in forestry, focusing on instructional design, classroom practices and field instruction.

name: Advanced Forest Pathology
description: Hereditary, physiological, anatomical, environmental, and microbiological factors influencing forest tree diseases.

name: Topics in Forest Science - TPS FRST SCIENCE
Advanced Forest Insect Ecology
description: Role of climate and climate change in the population dynamics, outbreak potentials and resultant impacts to forest ecosystems associated with herbivorous forest insects.

name: Forests and Society
description: Emphasis on tropical and sub-tropical countries, where the majority of forest-dependent people live.

name: Environmental Perception
description: Perceptual processes mediating behaviour in humans, with special attention given to the emotional processing of visual stimuli.

name: Directed Studies in Forest Management - DIR STDY FOR MGM
Multivariate Statistical Methods
description: Multivariate analysis of variance, cluster, principal components, factor, canonical and discriminant analysis. Theory and conceptual background are presented but emphasis is on selection of appropriate analysis and interpretation of results. Examples from forestry and related fields are analysed by computer programs at UBC.

name: Problems in Statistical Methods - PROBS STAT METHD
description: Directed studies in problems of advanced statistical techniques as a tool in forest research.

name: Topics in Forest Management - TPCS FRST MGMT
International Forestry Institutions, Diplomacy and Negotiation
Technical Communication Skills II
description: Theory and practice of technical communication necessary for preparation of effective scientific reports, reviews, grant proposals, journal articles and theses.

name: Technical Communication Skills I
description: Principles and practice of oral presentations.

name: Major Essay - MAJOR ESSAY
description: For non-thesis master's degree programs.

name: Major Essay - MAJOR ESSAY
description: For non-thesis master's degree programs.

name: Landscape Planning for Sustainability
description: Analysis, perception, planning of landscapes, and integration of social acceptability with sustainability.  Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 490 or FRST 551.

name: Fundamentals of Sustainable Forest Land Management
description: Concepts and principles at the site and landscape scale.

name: Land Information Acquisition and Analysis
description: Principles and application of data acquisition and use.

name: Site-Level Forest Land Management
description: Design and implementation of site-level plans that integrate ecological, social, and economic components: silviculture, forest operations, and forest health.

name: Landscape-Level Forest Land Management
description: Preparation of landscape-level sustainable forest management plans that integrate ecological, social, and economic components.

name: Topics in Forest Business and Management - TPC FRST BUS&MAN
Topics in International Forestry
description: Contemporary and emerging issues in international forestry.

name: Intermediate German I
description: Competence and fluency in everyday situations; ability to report and narrate past events fluently and to express opinions; familiarity with contemporary issues in the German-speaking societies.

name: Beginners' German II
description: Introduction to the language. Ability to communicate accurately in a variety of everyday situations, speak about past events and express ideas and hypotheses in German. See also GERM 433.

name: Beginners' German I
description: Introduction to the language.  Ability to communicate accurately in a variety of everyday situations.  See also GERM 433.

name: Exile, Flight and Migration (in English)
description: Transnational narratives about exile, migration and integration in the German-speaking countries.

name: Intermediate German II
description: Competence and fluency in everyday situations; ability to report and narrate past events fluently and to express opinions; familiarity with contemporary issues in the German-speaking societies; introduction to German for professional purposes.

name: Intermediate German III
description: Fluency in many relevant situations; competence in the most important areas of cultural life; familiarity with study resources and study skills. Review and expansion of grammar; fostering of speaking and writing skills.

name: German Literature after 1945 (in English)
description: Reading and discussion of selected literary works from West, East, and the United Germany, as well as from Austria and Switzerland.

name: German Literature 1900 - 1945 (in English)
description: Reading and discussion of selected works against the background of literary, social, and political developments in twentieth-century Germany with special emphasis on plays and novels dealing with the First World War and Nazism.

name: German Literature Before 1900 (in English)
description: Reading and discussion of translated works from the German-speaking countries from the Middle Ages to 1900.

name: German Cinema (in English)
description: Screening, discussion, and critical analysis of German cinema from the silent era to the 21st century.

name: Conversational German II
description: Emphasis on the study of oral communication skills and strategies. Fluency in many situations, communicative competence in important areas of cultural life, ability to participate in discussions of current as well as controversial issues to express ideas clearly in spoken word.

name: Intermediate German IV
description: Fostering of the ability to discuss controversial issues, express ideas clearly in writing and write essays on selected topics in German. Ongoing grammar review and expansion.

name: Business German
description: Review of the most important grammatical patterns in application to business geography, import-export trade, marketing, finance, accounting, taxation, workplace conditions and requirements; oral and written forms of presentation for work with German business.

name: Reason and Revolution: Studies in the 18th Century
description: Masterpieces and major trends of eighteenth-century German literature against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period.

name: German Translation
description: Theory, methodology, and practice of translation from German into English.

name: Progress and Disaster: Studies in the 20th and 21st Centuries
description: Masterpieces and major trends of 20th and 21st-century German literature against the larger background of the political and social developments of the period.

name: Religion and German Literature (in English)
description: Religion and literature in Germanic cultural history.

name: Selected Issues in German Culture
description: In depth study of one topic from German cultural history, varying from year to year. Possible topics: Germany of the New Europe; Gender and nation in German culture; topics from theory, such as the Frankfurt School.

name: Major Controversies in German Culture (in English)
description: Selected debates and controversies in the German-speaking countries.

name: German Media Studies (in English)
description: Major themes and methods in German media studies.

name: Business German
description: Review of the most important grammatical patterns in application to business geography, import-export trade, marketing, finance, accounting, taxation, workplace conditions and requirements; oral and written forms of presentation for work with German business. Formerly GERM 314.

name: German Representations of the Holocaust (in English)
description: The German Nazi Holocaust in German literature and film.
prerequisite: (Third Year Standing or permission of instructor.)

name: German for Reading Knowledge I
description: A multimedia introduction to reading skills in German leading to a second year reading knowledge in just one term. Students are expected to work largely independently. Course restricted to beginners or to students with no more than one term of beginner's German (or equivalent).

name: German Studies Research Methods - GERM RSRCH MTHDS
Literary Theories - LITERARY THEORY
description: This course is taught in English.

name: Studies in the Literature of the 18th Century - LIT OF 18TH CENT
Studies in Literature after 1945 - LIT AFTER 1945
Special Topics - SPECIAL TOPICS
description: This course is taught in English.

name: Beginning Ancient Greek I
description: Classical and Hellenistic Greek, Part I.

name: Beginning Ancient Greek II
description: Classical and Hellenistic Greek, Part II.

name: Intermediate Ancient Greek I
description: Completion of the grammatical foundations of Ancient Greek, Part I.

name: Intermediate Ancient Greek II
description: Completion of the grammatical foundations of Ancient Greek, Part II; introduction to the reading of unadapted passages of Greek literature.

name: Reading Ancient Greek: Prose
description: Readings in the major authors in Greek prose.

name: Reading Ancient Greek: Verse
description: Readings in the major authors in Greek verse.

name: Greek Prose - GREEK PROSE
description: History, philosophy and/or oratory.  Credit will not be given for both GREK 401 and GREK 501.

name: Greek Prose - GREEK PROSE
description: Studies in history, philosophy and/or oratory. It is recommended that the corequisite course be completed prior to GREK 401.

name: Studies in Ancient Greek Prose and Verse - ANCNT GREK P&V
description: Advanced thematic studies using both Greek prose and Greek verse. May be repeated for up to 6 credits.

name: Global Issues in Cultural Context
description: Students interact face-to-face and online as a community of learners to discuss global issues in agriculture, food, and natural resources in cultural context. Typically taken prior to studying abroad.
prerequisite: (Open only to students in the B.Sc. (GRS) program.)

name: Regional Directed Field Studies - REG DIR FLD STUD
description: Participating students may be assessed a fee.

name: Global Issues in Cultural Context
description: Students interact face-to-face and online as a community of learners to discuss global issues in agriculture, food, and natural resources in cultural context. Typically taken while studying abroad.

name: Regional Directed Field Studies - REG DIR FLD STUD
description: Participating students may be assessed a fee.

name: Global Issues in Cultural Context
description: Students interact face-to-face and online as a community of learners to discuss global issues in agriculture, food, and natural resources in cultural context. Typically taken after studying abroad.

name: Regional Directed Field Studies - REG DIR FLD STUD
description: Participating students may be assessed a fee.

name: Regional Directed Field Studies - REG DIR FLD STUD
description: Participating students may be assessed a fee.

name: The State of the Earth
description: The demographic, economic, ecological, and technological factors that underlie current environmental challenges, considering their effects to date and their possible impact in the future.

name: Geography, Environment and Globalization
description: Human geography of the modern world with particular attention to human-environment relationships, urbanization, and regional growth; trade and communications; environment and war; environmental governance and sustainability.

name: Geography, Modernity and Globalization
description: The human geography of the modern world since 1945: global interdependence in economic geography, geopolitics, and cultural geography; consequences of modernization, including demography, urbanization and environmental effects; regional case studies; reactions to modernization.

name: Cities
description: An interdisciplinary introduction to the city in the context of contemporary globalization. Analysis of urban patterns and processes from the theoretical perspectives of various disciplines and methodologies.

name: Geopolitics
description: Political geographic perspectives on todays interdependent world through three themes: borders, regions, and flows.

name: Introduction to the Geography of Canada
description: Selected topics in human geography focusing on the regional distribution of natural resources, population, urban systems, and economic activities.

name: Environment and Sustainability
description: Concepts of environment, resources and sustainability; the roles of physical and human geography in understanding the interaction of humans and the environment; introduction to management of environment-resource systems.

name: Urban Environments
description: The impact of urban development on the natural environment and vice versa. Study of the ecology and metabolism of cities and green urban design, using global and local case studies.

name: Climate Change: Science and Society
description: Climates over the geological, historical and instrument periods. Theories of climatic change. Monitoring and modelling the climate system. Impacts of change on environmental and socio-economic systems.
prerequisite: One of GEOG 102, GEOB 102, GEOG 200, GEOB 200, GEOG 204, GEOB 204, ATSC 201, EOSC 112. (3rd year standing.)

name: Environmental Justice and Social Change
description: Economic, social, political and cultural structures and institutions that shape contemporary socioecological challenges.

name: Geography of Natural Hazards
description: The role of geophysical events, human ecology, environmental perception, world social and political order in explaining the risk of natural disasters. Assessment of acceptable risk, disaster relief and reconstruction and contrasts between developed and developing nations.
prerequisite: Either (a) GEOG 101 or (b) all of GEOG 102, GEOG 103 or (c) all of GEOB 102, GEOB 103.

name: Analysing Environmental Problems
description: Concepts and techniques employed in environmental research; challenges in the areas of climate change, water use, knowledge translation and natural hazards.

name: Sustainability in a Changing Environment
description: Biophysical and human causes of short- and long-term environmental change at various spatial scales, including measurement, interpretation, and policy.

name: Environmental Impact Assessment
description: The principles, implementation, and role of environmental impact assessment in environmental management, in Canada and internationally.

name: Historical Geography of Urbanization: Cities, Space, and Power
description: From the origins of urbanism to the modern era.

name: Creating Canada
description: Canada from the beginning of European contact to the mid-19th century, stressing the changing geographical patterns of settlement, economy, and culture.

name: Constructing Canada
description: The construction of Canadian political space after Confederation, aboriginal-newcomer relations, regional development and conflict, industrialization, urbanization, and war.

name: Political Geography
description: The heritage of political geography; the spatial structure of political organization including regional and global structures.

name: Urban Worlds
description: City systems and theories of urban location; internal spatial structure of the city; commercial and industrial location; social areas; neighbourhood and land use change; urban trends and public policy.

name: Theory and Practice in Human Geography
description: A consideration of major intellectual issues and debates in the development of contemporary human geography, in relation to developments in other fields and changes in politics, culture and society.

name: Urbanization in the Global South
description: Urbanization in the developing countries of Latin America, Africa, and Asia; the role of cities in the development process and the features and problems of rapid urbanization.

name: Introduction to Social Geography
description: The development of social and behavioural geography, focusing on how places, landscapes, and enviromments both reflect and shape social life.

name: Geographies of Migration and Settlement
description: International regimes regulating migration, changes in global demographics, immigration policies of nation states, international migration patterns, settlement policies and outcomes.

name: Geography of Economic Development
description: Geographical approaches to economic development; models of economic development and spatial change; influences on spatial economic change; case studies from the developed, third, and socialist worlds.

name: Globalization, Cities, and Regions
description: Forms of economic development; changing location of economic activities and functions; implications for government and politics; local strategies for growth and equity.

name: Research Strategies in Human Geography
description: Formulating a research problem and selecting an appropriate research strategy. Research strategies range from social scientific survey methods to ethnography. Priority enrolment for honours and major students in Geography.

name: Statistics in Geography
description: Introduction to statistical techniques and their application to geographical problems. Priority enrolment for honours and major students in Geography. Consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

name: Geography of Asia
description: A comparative regional analysis stressing the historical development and changing cultural, economic, and political patterns of the area. Special reference to India, Indonesia, China, and Japan.

name: Environment and Society
description: Geographical analysis of society-environment relations. Relates resource management to environmental politics, political economy, and sustainable development. Perspectives drawn from political ecology and political economy, environmental history and environmental philosophy.

name: Water Management: Theory, Policy, and Practice.
description: Interdisciplinary analysis of critical water issues, in Canada and internationally.  Focus on social science perspectives.  Emphasis on presentation, research, and essay-writing skills.

name: Research in Environmental Geography
description: Details available from Geography Undergraduate Advisor. Not necessarily offered each year.
prerequisite: (Major or Honours in Geography with at least 75 credits, or permission of the instructor. GEOG 313 and 314 recommended.)

name: Development of Environmental Thought
description: An examination of how attitudes toward human nature and non-human nature have changed from Mesolithic times to the present in Western society.

name: Topics in Geography - TOPICS IN GEOG
description: See the departmental undergraduate advisor for details.

name: Directed Studies in Geography
description: For fourth-year students in Geography to permit investigation of a topic to be agreed upon by a member of the faculty and the student.
prerequisite: (Permission of the department head and supervising faculty member is required.)

name: Topics in Geography - TOPICS IN GEOG
description: See the departmental undergraduate advisor for details.

name: Geographies of the Middle East
description: Critical analysis of economic, social, and political development and processes defining the modern Middle East region.

name: Urban Research
description: Historical, legal, and quantitative analysis of urban research. Emphasis on spatial, racial, and political dynamics of urban inequality.

name: The Arctic
description: Physical and biological characteristics of the circumpolar Arctic, emphasizing terrestrial environments and the impacts on and by humans, including: glacial history; climatology; biogeography/ecology of arctic tundra; human-environment interactions, settlement and exploration; and current environmental, social and economic problems.

name: Topics in Environmental Geography - TPCS IN ENV GEOG
Themes and Interpretive Issues in Modern Human Geography
description: Themes and interpretive issues in modern human geography. Students from outside Geography require the permission of the Head of the department.

name: Directed Reading in Human Geography - HUMAN GEO DR RDG
Directed Reading in Human Geography - HUMAN GEO DR RDG
Research Strategies in Human Geography
description: A workshop-based seminar for Master's and PhD students in human geography concerned with the evaluation of alternative research strategies and the development of individual research proposals.

name: Advanced Concepts in Genome Science and Technology
description: Current approaches to high-throughput, system-wide analysis, and manipulation of biological systems.

name: Directed Studies in Genome Science and Technology
description: Advanced study under the direction of a faculty member composed of laboratory sessions and/or directed readings related to selected areas of genome science and technology.

name: Intensive Laboratory Course
description: Theory, application, and operation of instrumentation employed in modern genomics research: data analysis.

name: Statistical Methods for High Dimensional Biology
Beginning Biblical Hebrew I
description: Biblical Hebrew, with an introduction to vocabulary and grammar, and the reading of simple biblical texts in the original.

name: Beginning Biblical Hebrew II
description: Biblical Hebrew, with further introduction to vocabulary and grammar, and the reading of biblical texts in the original.

name: Ecosystem-Based Management Seminar
description: History, definitions, and applications of EBM; challenges of achieving both economic and environmental well-being with a focus on resource use and management on Haida Gwaii.  Part of the Haida Gwaii Fall Semester.

name: Introduction to Resilience Theory in Community
description: Theory of social-ecological resilience as  applied to cross-cultural community settings, using case studies from communities on Haida Gwaii and other exceptional cases of community resilience.

name: Re-Storying History: Indigenous Perspective
description: Exploration of the diversity of Indigenous peoples of British Columbia and Canada and their unique histories, beginning with origin stories and oral histories and moving on to the histories and relationships that Indigenous groups have with the federal, provincial and territorial governments.

name: Introductory Hindi-Urdu
description: Spoken and written Hindi and Urdu. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 100/101 or HINU 102.

name: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu
description: Conversation and grammar; an introduction to Hindi literature; an introduction to the Urdu script. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of HINU 201/202 or HINU 200.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Gender and Environmental Justice
description: An interdisciplinary and cross-cultural overview of contemporary environmental issues, as they relate to gender equality and social justice challenges and initiatives that respond to ecological crises.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Global Issues in Social Justice
description: Intersectional feminist theory and practice, focusing on contemporary issues in a transnational context. Credit will be granted for only one of WMST 100 or GRSJ 102.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Introduction to Social Justice
description: An overview of intersectional feminist debates and theoretical traditions. Credit will be granted for only one of WMST 100 or GRSJ 101.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Social Justice in Literature - GRSJ IN LIT
description: Techniques of literary study, with emphasis on intersectionality and the ways in which gender is represented in literature and contributions of feminism and gender studies to literary studies.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Social Justice in Literature - GRSJ IN LIT
description: Techniques of literary study, with emphasis on intersectionality and the ways in which gender is represented in literature and contributions of feminism and gender studies to literary studies.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Social Justice in Literature - GRSJ IN LIT
description: Techniques of literary study, with emphasis on intersectionality and the ways in which gender is represented in literature and contributions of feminism and gender studies to literary studies.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Representation in Modern Asia
description: The complex relationships between mechanisms of power, gender, and representation in Asia in different spaces examined through an interdisciplinary lens.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Social Structures in Modern Asia
description: Situates "Asia" in a global context and explores the complex relationships between gender, social structures, and social change.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Intersectional Approaches to Thinking Gender
description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the multiple intersections between gender and (neo)colonialism, racism, poverty, ableism, and heterosexism in a globalized world; historical and cross-cultural aspects, and the social construction of sex and gender, masculinity and femininity.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Gender, Race and Indigeneity in Canada
description: Gender and indigeneity in the documented histories and narrated lives of Indigenous people in Canada.
prerequisite: All of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102. (or third-year standing.)

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Gender, Race, Social Justice and the Law
description: A survey of feminist legal thought and recent developments in feminism and law, with a focus on Canada.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Social Justice Issues in Community and International Organizing
description: Critical examination and practical applications of concepts, theories, methods, and strategies of gender-aware organizing at the community and international levels.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Globalization and Social Justice: Gender, Race, and Sexuality in International Politics
description: Critical examination of the gender dimension of globalization and the theories, discourse, and practices in international politics using gender analysis.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Gender, Race, Sexuality, and Popular Culture
description: Critical examination of mainstream and alternative media images of gender, race, and sexuality in the context of networked social media, film, music, and television.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Gender, Race, Social Justice and Health
description: Interdisciplinary introduction to gender and health issues using selected theoretical frameworks.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Critical Racial Theories
description: Critical theories of racial and cultural difference. Initial formulations of theses against "scientific racism" and their later transformation by historical, social, and global-historical accounts of racial subjugation.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: African/Black Women in the Americas
description: An interdisciplinary survey of gender studies and histories of African/Black women in the Americas from the beginning of the slave trade to the present.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Queer and Trans of Colour Theorizing
description: The intellectual and political interventions of queer of colour theorizing in the gender and sexual politics of racial and imperial projects, including its engagements with women of colour feminisms, settler colonial and indigenous studies, and immigration and diaspora studies.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Feminist Anti-Racist Pedagogies
description: Feminist pedagogies and feminist debates about pedagogy in formal, nonformal, and informal educational settings.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Anti-colonial and Feminist Qualitative Methodologies
description: Data collection techniques, the politics of interpretation, and the formulation of a research proposal using a feminist, anti-racist framework.
prerequisite: All of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102. (or third-year standing.)

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: The Politics of Gender, Families, and Nation-Building
description: Investigation of historical and contemporary scholarship on the diversity of families, focusing on differences of gender, sexuality, race/ethnicity, and social class within and across national borders.
prerequisite: All of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102. (or third-year standing.)

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Theories of Representation and Difference
description: Feminist scholarship emphasizing languages and processes of representation and the construction of difference in cultural discourses and institutions.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Theories of Subjectivity
description: How feminist scholarship has shaped and reinterpreted accounts of the subject, drawing on such traditions as structuralism, poststructuralism, psychoanalysis, postcolonialism, postmodernism, and Queer Theory.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Religious Feminisms
description: Examines religious feminisms from three Abrahamic traditions. An in-depth study of challenges various doctrinal discourses and practices pose for feminist projects.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Body, Gender and Society
description: An interdisciplinary examination of the body, exploring how social relations and space are implicated in the constitution and experience of gendered bodies and identities, with an emphasis on feminist analyses of body-societal relations.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Critical Racial and Anti-Colonial Feminist Approaches
description: Critical anti-colonial and feminist analyses of colonial and racial subjugation, as well as the many modalities of indigenous and minority resistance.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Advanced Research Seminar
description: Critical theories, methodologies, ethics and practices appropriate for advanced feminist research.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 or (b) all of WMST 101, WMST 102. (or third-year standing.)

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under supervision of, a faculty member selected by the student and approved by the GRSJ Undergraduate Advisor. A written paper or equivalent will be required. Open to GRSJ majors or minors.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under supervision of, a faculty member selected by the student and approved by the GRSJ Undergraduate Advisor. A written paper or equivalent will be required. Open to GRSJ majors or minors.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under supervision of, a faculty member selected by the student and approved by the GRSJ Undergraduate Advisor. A written paper or equivalent will be required. Open to GRSJ majors or minors.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Decolonizing Praxis: A Practicum in Social Justice
description: Connects feminist and critical race theory and practice through placement in a community organization. As is the case with all UBC practice-related courses, this course requires a Criminal Record Check. Open to GRSJ Majors. This course is graded Pass/Fail.
prerequisite: All of GRSJ 101, GRSJ 102 and either (a) two of GRSJ 325, GRSJ 326, GRSJ 327, GRSJ 328 or (b) two of WMST 325, WMST 326, WMST 327, WMST 328. (Consult the department.)

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Intersectional Issues in Social Justice and Equality Studies

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Issues in Decolonizing and Feminist Methodologies

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Issues in Gender, Sexuality, and Critical Race Theories
