name: Extended Essay

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Critical and Creative Social Justice Studies Seminars - CRIT CREAT SJSS
description: The potential of creative work to disrupt ingrained ideas and representations by appealing to the senses. Study and engage with academics, artists, and activists interested in how art contributes to critical and engaged social justice work.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: Doctoral Dissertation
description: Pass/Fail.

SubjectName: Gender, Race, Sexuality and Social Justice
name: M.A. Thesis - M.A. THESIS
description: Pass/Fail.

name: Building Energy Systems Design
description: Designing the energy system for a high performance building. Heating, cooling and ventilation load estimation. Heating and cooling using solar, electrical and chemical energy. Air, water, and refrigerant distribution systems. Energy storage. System design project. Design performance assessment.

name: Green Building Contemporary Practice
description: Enhanced building environmental performance and the integration of green building principles, strategies and technologies.

name: Regenerative Development
description: The relationship between human and natural systems in the context of regenerative design. Provides an understanding of how regenerative approaches differ from green design and how they can offer new insights and directions for design.

name: Capstone: New Building Energy Systems Design
description: Students will take a building under design and work with the designers towards a high performance energy system. The project will be a proposed high performance building with a client, a design team, and energy performance objectives.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: In special cases, directed studies on certain aspects of nutrition may be arranged for graduate students in attendance.

name: Research Methods in Human Nutrition
description: Experimental design, methods of survey research, nutritional epidemiology, clinical research, and laboratory animal research. Issues such as animal models, ethics in animal and human research, statistical methods, and preparation of written reports and manuscripts, etc., will be addressed. Required of all M.Sc. and Ph.D. students in Human Nutrition.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: In special cases, directed studies on certain aspects of nutrition may be arranged for graduate students in attendance.

name: Intermediate Engineering Design
description: Intermediate level engineering design projects involving material in the curriculum of the Integrated Engineering program.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing in the Integrated Engineering program.)

name: Integrated Technical Communication
description: Written and oral communication in business correspondence, engineering design methods, report preparation, and oral presentations of technical material.  Restricted to students in second year of the Integrated Engineering Program.
prerequisite: One of APSC 176, ENGL 110, ENGL 111, ENGL 112, ENGL 120, ENGL 121, WRDS 150.

name: Introduction to Engineering Design
description: Introduction to engineering design methods, problem solving, working individually and in teams, and methods of communication of results. Engineering design projects will be assigned. Restricted to students in the second year of the Integrated Engineering program.

name: Advanced Engineering Design Projects
description: Projects involving all material in the curriculum of the Integrated Engineering Program. Students will be expected to propose a project and complete the design and construction of a prototype. Restricted to students in the fourth year of the Integrated Engineering program.

name: Pipeline Engineering
description: Pipeline materials and material selection; fracture mechanics; manufacturing and processing; welding and corrosion; soil-pipe interactions; surveying and site investigations; slope stability; natural hazards; pipeline loads and response.
prerequisite: Either (a) MECH 221 or (b) APSC 278 and one of CIVL 215, MTRL 263 and one of CIVL 230, MECH 260.

name: Pipeline Systems and Infrastructure
description: Energy infrastructure; pipe flows; equipment and facilities including compressors, pumping stations, coolers, and controls; terminals; pipeline integrity; corrosion control.
prerequisite: Either (a) MECH 221 or (b) APSC 278 and one of CIVL 215, MTRL 263 and one of CIVL 230, MECH 260.

name: Pipeline Design
description: Pipeline and pipeline system design reflecting technical, regulatory, environmental, societal, professional, and economic aspects; pipeline design project.

name: Interdisciplinary Studies: Thematic Seminars - GLOBAL HEALTH
description: Seminars, lectures, and discussions of topics involving several faculties. Contact the Interdisciplinary Studies Program for specific topics (www.isgp.ubc.ca).

name: Interdisciplinary Studies: Thematic Seminars - GENETICS ETHICS
description: Seminars, lectures, and discussions of topics involving several faculties. Contact the Interdisciplinary Studies Program for specific topics (www.isgp.ubc.ca).

name: Interdisciplinary Studies: Thematic Seminars - QUAL MET ETH RES
description: Seminars, lectures, and discussions of topics involving several faculties. Contact the Interdisciplinary Studies Program for specific topics (www.isgp.ubc.ca).

name: Interdisciplinary Studies: Thematic Seminars - INTERFACULTY THM
description: Seminars, lectures, and discussions of topics involving several faculties. Contact the Interdisciplinary Studies Program for specific topics (www.isgp.ubc.ca).

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: A series of directed readings related to student's area of interdisciplinary studies. This advanced course may be taken upon approval of the Program head.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: A series of directed readings related to student's area of interdisciplinary studies. This advanced course may be taken upon approval of the Program head.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: A series of directed readings related to student's area of interdisciplinary studies. This advanced course may be taken upon approval of the Program head.

name: Information Visualization
description: Basic theory and practice required to visually represent information. Introduces design principles and practical skills to create effective information visualizations. Examines effect of different visual representations on understanding and meaning.

name: Networks, Crowds, and Communities
description: Introduces network concepts and methods for exploring social and organizational connectivity for work, socializing, and knowledge production. Examines impact of social media on connections that span space and place; peer production on authority structures; ubiquitous mobile connectivity on daily life.

name: Information Policy and Society
description: Develops capabilities required to assess the need for information policies in professional contexts, evaluate relevant socio-technical dimensions and envision likely implications for specific communities and practice settings.

name: Land and Indigenous Self-Determination: Introduction to Theoretical Perspectives
description: Cultural, political, and economic context that informs the experiences of Indigenous people and communities. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s).

name: Special Topics in Indigenous Land-based Studies - INDIG L-BSD STS
description: Topics and location will vary from year to year. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s). For further information, email inlb.arts@ubc.ca.

name: Special Topics in Indigenous Land-based Studies - INDIG L-BSD STS
description: Topics and location will vary from year to year. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s). For further information, email inlb.arts@ubc.ca.

name: Land and Indigenous Self-Determination: Introduction to Methods and Application
description: Applied cultural, political, and economic land-based practices that inform and advance Indigenous self-determination. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s).

name: Introduction to Gender Justice and Indigenous Communities
description: Introduction to the politics of gender and sexuality from Indigenous perspectives, with a focus on intersectionality. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s).

name: Land and Indigenous Self-Determination: Advanced Theoretical Perspectives
description: Theorizing land and self-determination from Indigenous cultural, political, and economic perspectives. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s).

name: Advanced Special Topics in Indigenous Land-Based Studies - ADV SP TCS INDG
description: Topics and location will vary from year to year. Advanced experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s). For further information please consult the departmental website.

name: Land and Indigenous Self-Determination: Advanced Methods and Application
description: Advanced cultural, political, and economic land-based practices that guide decolonization and Indigenous self-determination. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s).

name: Advanced Special Topics in Indigenous Land-Based Studies - ADV SP TCS INDG
description: Topics and location will vary from year to year. Advanced experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s). For further information please consult the departmental website.

name: Gender Justice and Indigenous Resurgence
description: The theory and politics of gender and sexuality from Indigenous perspectives. Emphasis on decolonial and intersectional Indigenous feminisms and queer/two-spirit theory. Experiential, intensive land-based course designed and delivered in collaboration with academic faculty and Indigenous community partner(s). Students are eligible for Pass/Fail or percentage grading.

name: Interdisciplinary Seminar
description: Critical analysis of recent scientific literature that combines disciplines that students are integrating in their Integrated Sciences Curriculum.

name: The Size of Things
description: Scaling as a general approach to laws governing the geometry, kinematics and dynamics of systems. Dimensional analysis, isometry and allometry applied to topics from Biology, Physics, Earth Science and Economics. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.)

name: Symmetry
description: Recognizing symmetry; point groups in 2D and 3D; plane groups in 2D; space groups in 3D; the role of symmetry in the natural and human world.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.)

name: Research Development Project
description: Retreat to develop skills in writing scientific research proposals.  Emphasis on formulating and testing hypotheses to explain observations.  Course location will vary; fee payable prior to retreat.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.)

name: Topics in Integrated Sciences - TPCS INTEG SCIE
description: Interactive examination of a theme common to all areas of science. Themes will change from year to year. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science)

name: Topics in Integrated Sciences - TPCS INTEG SCIE
description: Interactive examination of a theme common to all areas of science. Themes will change from year to year. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science)

name: Darwinian Medicine
description: Using the Darwinian theory of natural selection to explore explanations of infectious diseases, allergies, cancer, mental illness, and other human diseases. Priority to students in the Integrated Sciences Program.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.)

name: Systems Approaches to Regional Sustainability
description: Application of systems science encompassing geological, hydrological, ecological, atmospheric sciences, and energy systems approaches to study regional sustainability.
prerequisite: (Third-year or higher standing in the Faculty of Science.)

name: Field Course: Systems Approaches to Regional Sustainability
description: Systems science approaches encompassing geological, hydrological, ecological, atmospheric sciences, and energy systems to investigate a selected region of the world.  Course location will vary; fee payable prior to field course.
prerequisite: ISCI 360. (or permission of the Integrated Sciences Director.)

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months. Normally taken in Winter Session of third year or Summer Session after third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students in the ISP Co-op program.

name: Ethical Issues in Science
description: Theoretical and practical consideration of ethics in the practice, reporting, public impact and accountability of science.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Permission of the Director is required.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in ISP.

name: Directed Studies - DIR STUDIES
description: Permission of the Director is required.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Permission of the Director is required.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Permission of the Director is required.

name: Directed Studies - DIR STUDIES
description: Permission of the Director is required.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Permission of the Director is required.

name: Comparative Field Research Course: Systems Approaches to Regional Sustainability
description: Systems science approaches encompassing geological, hydrological, ecological, atmospheric sciences, and energy systems to investigate, analyze and research two unique regions of the world. Course location may vary; course location must be different than ISCI 361; fee payable prior to field course.

name: Student Directed Seminars
description: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment and delivery methods will comply with the Handbook for Student Directed Seminars.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing in the Faculty of Science.)

name: Co-operative Work Placement III
description: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months.  Technical report required.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in ISP.

name: Co-Operative Work Placement IV
description: Industrial or academic work experience for a minimum of 4 months. Technical report required.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in ISP.

name: Elementary Italian I
description: Introduction to complex language structures used to communicate in a variety of situations by using different tenses and modes. Enhanced ability to comprehend, interact and express wishes or feelings in common personal and social contexts. Aligned with CEFR level A2 objectives.
prerequisite: ITAL 102. (Or successful completion of CEFR Level A1.)

name: Beginners' Italian II
description: Continuation of foundational elements of Italian language. Development of listening, reading, speaking and writing skills in the context of everyday situations in the present and past tenses. Aligned with CEFR level A1 objectives.

name: Beginners' Italian I
description: Introduction to the essentials of Italian vocabulary, expressions, grammar and cultural life. Focus on listening, reading, speaking and writing skills in everyday situations in the present tense. Aligned with CEFR level A1 objectives.

name: Intermediate Italian II
description: Expansion of and reflection on the use of complex grammatical structures in context to broaden lexical repertoire. Enhances proficiency through written communication and discussion of relevant cultural topics. Aligned with CEFR level B1 objectives.

name: Elementary Italian II
description: Expansion of fundamental notions and presentation of elaborate structures, present, past and future tenses and different modes. Enriched opportunities to explore Italian culture and develop intercultural skills. Aligned with CEFR level A2 objectives.

name: Intermediate Italian I
description: Advanced grammar structures in context, lexical repertoire and cultural elements to further increase learners ability to communicate in most situations, including complex conversations. Aligned with CEFR level B1 objectives.
prerequisite: One of ITAL 202, ITAL 203, ITAL 206. (Or successful completion of CEFR level A2.)

name: Upper-Intermediate Italian I
description: Continues building fluency, accuracy and proficiency at an autonomous level in spoken and written communication. Emphasis on culturally contextualized grammar structures and vocabulary, critical reading and discussion of a variety of texts. Aligned with CEFR level B2 objectives.
prerequisite: ITAL 302. (Or successful completion of CEFR level B1.)

name: Italian Literature and Culture of the Modern and Contemporary Age
description: The development of modern and contemporary Italian literature and culture against the background of social and historical events. Alternates with ITAL 303.

name: Italian Literature of the Middle Ages
description: Italian literature of the Middle Ages in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Dante and his contemporaries and/or immediate followers (may include Petrarch and Boccaccio). Precludes credit for ITST 414.

name: Masterpieces of the Novella in Italian Literature
description: A study of the genre of the novella as an expression of social and political contexts within and across cultures from its inception in feudal times to the post-modern age.

name: Introduction to Italian Culture II: From the Modern to the Post-Colonial Age
description: The debate around nation vs. empire vs. republic, from the Napoleonic age to our days, as captured in Italy's microcosm, condensing and often anticipating issues that have later become global.

name: "Made in Italy"
description: Where do Italy's glamour, lifestyle, traditions come from? This course introduces Italy's multifaceted ways of being and the cultural creations of the peninsula in their context.

name: Italian Cinema: Neorealism
description: A survey of the major classics of post-WWII Italian Neorealism in cinema emphasizing their historical, political, social, philosophical and technical contexts.

name: Italian Fascism in Interdisciplinary Perspective
description: The cultural, literary, philosophical roots of Fascism and its evolution: its policies in literature, sports, cinema, architecture, racial legislation, and colonial adventures.

name: Cultural Exchange between Modern Italy and China
description: Key moments and texts about intercultural exchange between Italy and China since the beginning of the twentieth century in their social, historical, and political contexts.

name: Topics in the Italian Literature and Culture of the Middle Ages in Translation
description: Italian literature of the Middle Ages in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Dante and his contemporaries and/or immediate followers (may include Petrarch and Boccaccio). Precludes credit for ITAL 404.

name: Topics in Modern and Contemporary Italian Literature and Culture in Translation
description: Italian literature of the 20th century in its intellectual, socio-political and cultural context. Precludes credit for ITAL 409.

name: Water and Wastewater Management Strategies
description: Chemical and microbiological quality and contaminations, techniques and analytical procedures for assessing and monitoring chemical and microbiological water quality; water and wastewater quality standards, pollution prevention strategies and policies; risk analysis; asset management.

name: Water Resources Systems Planning and Management
description: Art and science of modelling for integrated water resources planning and management; practice of developing and deploying simulation and optimization models to solve water problems; risk informed decision making frameworks and stakeholder processes for analysis of water resources systems.

name: World History from 1500 to the Twentieth Century
description: The civilizations of Asia, Europe, Africa and the Americas, with emphasis on the political, economic, ecological and cultural links among them, and the impact of oceanic contact, imperialism, warfare, migration, and globalization.

name: World History Since 1900
description: International relations; changes in the nation-state system; the emergence and impact of major political ideologies; genocide; decolonization; the globalization of trade; and the dynamics of economic, social, cultural, and environmental change in a global context.

name: What is History?
description: The discipline of history through the study of questions, sources, methods, and controversies. Includes case studies of key turning points in world history to examine what historians do and why it matters.

name: Topics in World History - STATE INTERVENTN
description: Thematically-organized topics will explore global aspects of human experience across time. Each section will examine a single theme. Check with the department for course offerings.

name: Topics in World History - COMMUNISM & AFTR
description: Thematically-organized topics will explore global aspects of human experience across time. Each section will examine a single theme. Check with the department for course offerings.

name: Topics in World History - GLOBAL MIGRATION
description: Thematically-organized topics will explore global aspects of human experience across time. Each section will examine a single theme. Check with the department for course offerings.

name: Topics in World History - FASCISM & ANTI
description: Thematically-organized topics will explore global aspects of human experience across time. Each section will examine a single theme. Check with the department for course offerings.

name: Topics in World History - CULTURES CONTACT
description: Thematically-organized topics will explore global aspects of human experience across time. Each section will examine a single theme. Check with the department for course offerings.

name: Topics in World History - KILLER COMMODTS
description: Thematically-organized topics will explore global aspects of human experience across time. Each section will examine a single theme. Check with the department for course offerings.

name: Topics in World History - TPCS WORLD HIST
description: Thematically-organized topics will explore global aspects of human experience across time. Each section will examine a single theme. Check with the department for course offerings.

name: Contemporary Global Issues in Historical Perspective - CONT GLBL ISSUES
description: Places issues and problems of current relevance such as disease, terrorism, drugs, or ethnic conflict in historical perspective. Each section will explore a single theme. Check with department for course offerings.

name: Global History of Capitalism
description: The history of capitalism in its global dimension from the beginnings to the age of industrialization.  An investigation of economies - in both their practices and cultures - around the world and across the ages from ancient times to the modern era.

name: Global Environmental History
description: The impact humans have had on the environment, and the ways in which the physical environment has shaped human history: climate, agriculture, energy use, and urbanization.

name: Gateway to the Middle Ages - MIDDLE AGES
description: Problems and themes of medieval European History through the close study of the people and cultures that produced them.

name: Public History in Canada: Memory, Representation, and Interpretation
description: An introduction to public history in Canada.  An exploration of the politics and practice of representing the past in a variety of sites, and questions of historical interpretation, memory, and audience.

name: History of Canada: Moments that Matter
description: An introduction to major turning points in Canadian history.  Exploration of the social, political, cultural, and environmental transformations/revolutions that have shaped Canada from early European colonialism to the twenty-first century.

name: History of Europe - HIST OF EURO
description: Selected themes and historical approaches in European history; may include Europe's history of religious conflict, state formation, colonialism, nationalism, industrialization, revolution, total war, globalization, genocide, or environmental change.

name: History of the United States - HISTORY OF USA
description: Survey from colonial period to present examining political system, slavery, Civil War, race relations and civil rights, westward expansion, industrialization, feminism, expanding international presence, Cold War, and modern culture.

name: Health, Illness and Medicine I: From the Ancient World to the Early Modern Period
description: History of western medicine, from the Ancient World to the Enlightenment, with a focus on social and cultural ideas surrounding the body, health, and disease, and the development of medical institutions.

name: Latin American History - LATN AMERCN HIST
description: Exploring themes of colonialism, indigenous life, national imaginaries, dictatorships and transitions to democracy through different forms of telling Latin American history. Includes epistolary writing, maps, eyewitness accounts, chronicles, actions, novels, films, built environment and city plans, testimonios, and plays.

name: History of Africa
description: An introduction to selected themes and historical approaches in African history. These may include African geography and identities, sources and methodology, pre-modern state formation, gender relations, world religions, labour systems, colonialism, and post-colonialism.

name: Health, Illness and Medicine II: The Modern World from 1700 to the Present
description: Western medicine from 1700 to the present, with a focus on social and cultural ideas surrounding the body, health and disease, and the development of medical institutions.

name: Science and Society in the Contemporary World
description: An introduction to the historical development, conceptual foundations, and cultural significance of contemporary science. Themes will vary from year to year.

name: Japan and Global History, 1550 - 1900
description: Thematic study of comparisons and relations between Japan and the world outside (primarily Europe and China). Commercial expansion, systems of world order, social institutions, religious and ideological expression, and state organization.

name: China in World History - CHINA WORLD HIST
description: The history of China in a global context, from the earliest times to the most recent past; how China has changed the world and how engagement with the world has changed China.

name: History of India
description: Societies, cultures, and politics of the Indian subcontinent from its ancient civilizations to the formation of the modern nation-states of South Asia.

name: Researching Local History from the Ground Up
description: Sources and methods for reconstructing local history that can be used by Social Studies teachers in B.C. The aim is to develop an appreciation of the formative processes and past experiences that created one's familiar community.

name: History of British Columbia
description: The social, political, cultural, environmental, and economic transformations that have made British Columbia. Topics include the histories of Indigenous and settler peoples, the modern state, migration, activism, and identity.

name: The British Empire to 1850
description: Rise of the British imperial system within a global context from its beginnings to 1850. Focuses on economic and social themes with emphasis on settlements in the southern hemisphere as well as the West Indies.

name: Africa from Imperialism to Independence
description: The history of Africa in the 19th and 20th Centuries: the growth of Islam and Christianity, the impact of European colonialism, the development of nationalism, and the variety of different political and social outcomes after independence.

name: Britain, 1850-1918
description: Britain from the Great Exhibition to the Great War: the creation of a mass electorate, the "New Imperialism," the "New Woman," and the ways that class, race, gender, and sexuality shaped modern Britain.

name: Britain, 1945 to the Present
description: Survey of recent British history, with emphasis on de-colonization, emergence of the welfare state, new social movements and patterns of immigration, and Britain's changing relationship with Europe.

name: Inventing Canada, 1840-1896
description: An examination of political, cultural and national developments within the British North American colonies in the second half of the nineteenth century. Credit will not be granted for both HIST 324 or 326, if 326 was taken before 2007W.

name: Empires, Wars, and Revolutions in Europe and the Americas,1763-1838
description: Political, social, cultural, and intellectual transformations that reshaped the Atlantic world between 1763 and 1838; special attention will be given to the American, French, and Haitian Revolutions, the Latin American Wars of Independence and Canadian rebellions.

name: Canada 1896-1945: Boom, Bust and War
description: Includes Aboriginal policy, immigration and national identity; Canada, Britain and the US; World Wars; economic modernization; the Great Depression; regionalism; political and social movements; and the creation of 'Canadian' culture.  Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 325 or 426, if 426 was taken before 2007W.

name: Canada Since 1945: Affluence and Anxiety in the Atomic Age.
description: Includes immigration policy; the welfare state; Aboriginal peoples; the Cold War; resource economies and national politics; continentalism and free trade; constitutional crises; conflicting nationalisms; and new social movements.  Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 326 or 426, if 426 was taken before 2007W.

name: Third-Year Honours Seminar - 3RD YR HONRS SEM
Third-Year Honours Seminar - 3RD YR HONRS SEM
Third-Year Honours Seminar - 3RD YR HONRS SEM
Medieval Jewish History
description: A survey of the political, social, economic, and cultural history of the Jews from the time of the Christianization of the Roman Empire to the expulsion of professing Jews from Spain and Portugal at the end of the fifteenth century.

name: History of Modern France
description: Political, social, and cultural history of France from the Revolution of 1789 to the present. France's journey toward democracy; particular focus on the changing nature of French culture and society.

name: The Soviet Union
description: Political, social, and cultural history of the Soviet Union and post-Soviet successor states from 1900 to the present.

name: East Central Europe in the 19th and 20th Centuries - E&C EURO 19/20 C
description: Covers the region between Germany and Russia as well as Southeast Europe. Emphasis on comparisons with Western Europe and features that make the area significant to Europe as a whole.

name: Twentieth-Century Germany
description: The political, social, and cultural history of Germany in the twentieth century.

name: History of Mexico
description: Examines themes in the last five hundred years of Mexican history, with an emphasis on the critical reading of primary sources and the use of a variety of texts that may include letters, diaries, paintings, photographs, novels, and movies.

name: Modern Middle Eastern Histrory
description: Politics, culture, society, war, and diplomacy; themes include colonialism, nationalism, and authoritarianism; emphasis on the 20th and 21st centuries.

name: State and Society in 20th century Cuba
description: The history and historiography of 20th century Cuba, with particular attention to changing state structures and their impact on everyday life.

name: Europe During the Renaissance
description: The interplay between new and traditional ideas, styles, and institutions from the fourteenth to the mid-sixteenth century, with emphasis upon the relationship of social, economic, and political factors to intellectual and cultural change.

name: Europe in the Early Middle Ages
description: A survey of the development of institutions, ideas and the economy in Europe from about 400 through about 1000 CE.

name: Europe During the Reformation
description: An examination of European history that place both the Protestant Reformation and the Catholic Reformation in the broader context of the political, social, cultural, and economic changes during the early modern era.

name: Europe in the 19th Century
description: An investigation of main themes in European history from the French Revolution to the beginning of the 20th century. Topics of particular importance are: domestic politics; the interaction of states; the formation of new states; social and economic transformations affecting the whole civilization; major cultural expressions of the century.

name: Europe, 1900-1950
description: Europe in the first half of the twentieth century. Themes include the imperialist system, two world wars and their aftermaths, political and social movements of the interwar years, the Depression, and the crisis of liberal democracy. Credit will only be granted for one of HIST 369 or 462.

name: Europe Since 1950
description: Europe since the middle of the twentieth century. Themes include the Cold War, the development of separate social and political systems in Western and Eastern Europe, the emergence of the welfare state, and the problems of European integration.

name: History of Hong Kong
description: History, culture, and identities of Hong Kong from the early 1800s to the present.

name: The Making of Modern China: Nationalism, War, Revolution - MODERN CHINA
description: The history of China from 1800 to the present including the decline of the Qing empire, the rise of modern nationalism, foreign invasion, and China's multiple revolutions.

name: Modern Japanese History Since 1800 - JAPAN SINCE 1800
description: The building of a modern state, its crisis in the 1930s, and its postwar recovery; topics include business institutions, politics, imperialism, intellectual syncretism, social change, and Japan's growing influence in the world.

name: Post-Colonial Southeast Asia
description: The history of the Japanese occupation, wars of independence, international relations of the independent nation-states, and internal armed conflicts. Special attention will be paid to the wars in Vietnam, Indonesia, and East Timor.

name: India from Raj to Republic
description: Exploration of the rise of the East India Company as territorial power, the formation of a colonial society in India, competing responses to British rule, the struggle for independence, and the legacies of partition.

name: Topics in History - TOPICS IN HIST
description: Small-group instruction in a seminar format on a variety of historical topics. Check with the department for course offerings. This course does not satisfy the History Majors Research Seminar (490) requirement.

name: Human Rights in World History
description: Changing ideas about humanity and rights. Considers the relationship between human rights and the nation-state, imperialism, and capitalism. Assesses the efforts to end large-scale human rights violations and the role of the United Nations.

name: Introduction to History and Philosophy of Science
description: An examination of historical, conceptual, and methodological conditions of scientific knowledge through detailed consideration of important episodes in the history of science.

name: Darwin, Evolution, and Modern History
description: Darwin and the science of evolution in nineteenth and early twentieth century.

name: Theory and Practice of History - THRY&PRCT HIST
description: Approaches to the history of historical inquiry, with particular attention to theoretical and methodo-logical debates among historians. Recommended for history majors. Not open to Department of History honours students.

name: Problems in International Relations - POSTCOLONIAL I/R
description: Selected topics such as trade, migration, diplomacy, war, migration, colonialism, and post- colonialism. Priority for registration to majors in History or International Relations.

name: Environmental History of North America
description: Overview of land use and environmental change in Canada and the United States; examines ideas and practices that shaped indigenous and non-indigenous resource exploitation, management, and activism to the end of the twentieth century.

name: Problems in International Relations - IRELAND IN I/R
description: Selected topics such as trade, migration, diplomacy, war, migration, colonialism, and post- colonialism. Priority for registration to majors in History or International Relations.

name: Seminar in the History of International Relations - INTL LAW & CDA
description: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or International Relations.

name: Seminar in the History of International Relations - ORIGINS OF WWI
description: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or International Relations.

name: Seminar in the History of International Relations - WAR STRATEGY
description: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or International Relations.

name: Seminar in the History of International Relations - GRAPHIC NOVEL
description: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or International Relations.

name: Seminar in the History of International Relations - MIGRTN AMERICAS
description: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or International Relations.

name: Seminar in the History of International Relations - MDRN NRTH AFRICA
description: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or International Relations.

name: Seminar in the History of International Relations - CONSTRUC OF RACE
description: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or International Relations.

name: Seminar in the History of International Relations - INTL COMMUNIST
description: Selected topics in the history of international relations. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or International Relations.

name: Diplomacy and Conflict in the Middle East, 1914 to the Present
description: International relations in the Middle East in the aftermath of the Ottoman Empire, with special attention to the conflicts between Jews of Palestine/Israel and their Arab neighbours.

name: U.S. Foreign Relations since 1945
description: U.S. foreign policy and international history.  Political, economic, and cultural relationships between the United States and other peoples, organizations, and states worldwide.

name: U.S. Foreign Relations from Independence to World War II
description: U.S. foreign policy and international history.  Examines the American rise to power and political, economic, and cultural relationships between the United States and other peoples, organizations, and states worldwide.

name: The Second World War
description: Precursors and consequences of the war; military, political, cultural, social, and economic histories of how the war shaped and reflected its global context. Themes include totalitarianism, genocide, and imperialism and decolonization.

name: Imagining the Nation: 19th- and 20th-Century Canada
description: The political and intellectual history of the concept of the nation in French and English Canada, and the different forms of nationalism it inspired from the middle of the nineteenth century to the 1995 Quebec Referendum.

name: Crime and Punishment in Canadian History
description: The relationship between law and society; the development of legal institutions and the evolving character of crime in Canada.

name: History of Vancouver
description: Selected themes in the history of Vancouver, exploring how the study of the past illuminates or explains major debates in the city today.

name: Topics in Canadian History - DRUGS IN CANADA
description: May include immigration, French-English relations, the growth of the state, health and welfare, or the family.

name: War and Society
description: Continuity and change in the relations of war and society, the connections between the economy, society, the military, and government in peacetime as well as war; not a course in military history.

name: International Relations in the Twentieth Century
description: History of international relations from the beginning of the twentieth century to the present. Questions of war, peace, balance of power, and the evolution of the international system in global economic, cultural, and social contexts.

name: History of the Holocaust
description: A study of the systematic attempt to destroy European Jewry during the Nazi regime, 1933-1945. Topics of special importance include: the motivations and behaviour of the perpetrators; the reactions of the victims; the roles of bystanders.

name: Selected Topics in Latin American History - SOCCER IN LAT-AM
description: A study in depth of one major topic (such as the Cuban Revolution or Peronismo) in the recent history of Latin America.

name: Revolution and Resistance in the Third World
description: Revolutionary movements in the Third World during the second half of the twentieth century; the radicalisation of anticolonial nationalism; the impact of anticolonial radicalism in the developed world; the decline of Marxism as a revolutionary inspiration.

name: Medieval Portraits and Personalities
description: The lives of leading and controversial figures in the Middle Ages and the means by which they have portrayed themselves and been portrayed by others.

name: Asian Migrant Communities in Vancouver
description: This course will examine the history of Asian migration to Vancouver and British Columbia, focusing on the development of local communities and provide a background in historical research methods that will enable the students to conduct research on the history of these communities.

name: Seminar for Majors in History - PWR & ENVIR NA
description: Selected problems in the theory and practice of historical work. Check with the department for course offerings. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or in the History and Philosophy of Science. Also open to History Honours students.

name: Seminar for Majors in History - USES OF PAST
description: Selected problems in the theory and practice of historical work. Check with the department for course offerings. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or in the History and Philosophy of Science. Also open to History Honours students.

name: Seminar for Majors in History - VIOLENCE & RACE
description: Selected problems in the theory and practice of historical work. Check with the department for course offerings. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or in the History and Philosophy of Science. Also open to History Honours students.

name: Seminar for Majors in History - EARLY MOD MEDTRN
description: Selected problems in the theory and practice of historical work. Check with the department for course offerings. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or in the History and Philosophy of Science. Also open to History Honours students.

name: Seminar for Majors in History - HIST OF EMOTIONS
description: Selected problems in the theory and practice of historical work. Check with the department for course offerings. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or in the History and Philosophy of Science. Also open to History Honours students.

name: Readings: Special Topics in History - SPEC TOPICS HIST
History of Health in the Modern West
description: Changing conditions of health in Europe and North America from the beginning of the modern mortality decline to the recent past.

name: Readings in International and Global History - INTL&GLBL READNG
Readings in International and Global History - INTL&GLBL READNG
Topics in Comparative History - COMP HIST TOPICS
Seminar for Majors in History - CNADA & THRD RCH
description: Selected problems in the theory and practice of historical work. Check with the department for course offerings. Restricted to fourth year students majoring in History or in the History and Philosophy of Science. Also open to History Honours students.

name: Intensive Beginning Japanese I
description: An introduction to modern spoken and written Japanese with emphasis on both form (grammar and syntax) and functions. Offered in Term 1. Not available for credit to students with JAPN 12. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 160 and 260 in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 160 or JAPN 150 or both JAPN 100, JAPN 101.

name: Beginning Japanese IB
description: Continuation of JAPN 100 (Non-intensive). Not available for credit to students with JAPN 12. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 101 or JAPN 160.

name: Beginning Japanese IA
description: An introduction to modern spoken and written Japanese with emphasis on both form (grammar and syntax) and functions (Non-intensive). Not available for credit to students with JAPN 11 and/or JAPN 12. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 100 or JAPN 160.

name: Beginning Japanese II B
description: Continuation of JAPN 200 (Non-intensive). Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 201 or JAPN 103 or JAPN 260.

name: Beginning Japanese II A
description: Continuation of JAPN 101 (Non-intensive). Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 200 or JAPN 102 or JAPN 260.

name: Intensive Beginning Japanese II
description: Continuation of JAPN 160. Offered in Term 2. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 160 and 260 in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 260 or JAPN 151 or both JAPN 102, JAPN 103 or both JAPN 200, JAPN 201.

name: Intermediate Japanese II A
description: It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 322 and JAPN 323 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 322 or JAPN 212 or JAPN 361.
prerequisite: One of JAPN 211, JAPN 250, JAPN 321, JAPN 360.

name: Intermediate Japanese I A
description: Integrated coverage of topics on culture and cross-cultural communication designed to develop competencies in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. It is strongly recommended that JAPN 320 and JAPN 321 be taken in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 320 or JAPN 210 or JAPN 360.
prerequisite: One of JAPN 103, JAPN 151, JAPN 201, JAPN 260.

name: Intermediate Japanese II B
description: A continuation of JAPN 322. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 322 and JAPN 323 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 322 and JAPN 212 or JAPN 361.

name: Intensive Intermediate Japanese I
description: Integrated coverage of topics on culture and  cross-cultural communication designed to develop competencies in speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Offered in Term 1. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 360 and JAPN 361 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 360 or JAPN 212 or both JAPN 210, JAPN 211 or both JAPN 320, JAPN 321.
prerequisite: One of JAPN 103, JAPN 151, JAPN 201, JAPN 260.

name: Advanced Modern Japanese: Reading and Writing I
description: Selected texts covering various aspects of Japanese cultural history and contemporary Japanese culture/society; emphasis on grammatical analysis and development of advanced competencies for reading and writing. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 400 and JAPN 401 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 400 or JAPN 300.
prerequisite: One of JAPN 213, JAPN 251, JAPN 323, JAPN 361.

name: Intensive Intermediate Japanese II
description: Continuation of JAPN 360. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 360 and JAPN 361 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 361 or JAPN 251 or both JAPN 212, JAPN 213 or both JAPN 322, JAPN 323.
prerequisite: One of JAPN 211, JAPN 250, JAPN 321, JAPN 360.

name: Advanced Modern Japanese: Reading and Writing II
description: Continuation of JAPN 301. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 400 and JAPN 401 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 401 or JAPN 301.

name: Advanced Modern Japanese: Conversation and Composition I
description: Improvement of speaking and writing skills through readings and discussions on a variety of social and cultural issues; emphasis on appropriate language use in formal situations. It is strongly recommended that students plan to complete both JAPN 402 and JAPN 403 within one year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 402 or JAPN 302.
prerequisite: One of JAPN 213, JAPN 251, JAPN 323, JAPN 361.

name: Classical Japanese I
description: The grammar, orthography, and literary style of pre-modern Japanese (bungo).  It is strongly recommended that students have 12 credits of JAPN, or equivalent, prior to registration. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 422 or JAPN 311.

name: Advanced Oral Communication I
description: Oral communication skills appropriate for studying and working in a Japanese-speaking environment either formal or informal. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 450 or JAPN 410.
prerequisite: One of JAPN 300, JAPN 400 and one of JAPN 302, JAPN 402, JAPN 314, JAPN 424.

name: Readings in Modern Japanese Essays
description: Advanced reading and analysis of scholarly texts in modern Japanese drawn from history, sociology, economics, etc. Advanced conversation, composition, and practice in the use of standard reference tools as preparation for independent research in Japanese. Students are recommended to complete JAPN 403 prior to taking JAPN 452. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 452 or JAPN 406.

name: Readings in Modern Japanese Literature
description: An advanced course in the reading and analysis of literary texts in modern Japanese. Advanced conversation, translation into English and practice in the use of standard reference tools as preparation for advanced research in Japanese. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 453 or JAPN 408.

name: Newspaper Japanese I
description: Developing fluency in reading contemporary Japanese newspapers; concentration on current and emerging vocabulary, evolving grammatical features, and style of presentation. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 456 or JAPN 416.
prerequisite: One of JAPN 301, JAPN 401 and one of JAPN 302, JAPN 402, JAPN 314, JAPN 424.

name: Intermediate Japanese I B
description: Continuation of JAPN 320. It is strongly recommended that JAPN 320 and JAPN 321 be taken in the same year. Credit will be granted for only one of JAPN 321 or JAPN 211 or JAPN 360.

name: New Media and Society - NEW MEDIA&SOCI
description: Development of new media technologies, their applications, and their cultural, political, and social impacts.

name: Decoding Social Media
description: Examines the challenges, opportunities and foundational research related to the emergence of social media platforms, services and tools as part of an evolving media ecosystem. Political, social, ethical and legal implications for media organizations, journalists and citizens.
prerequisite: (Restricted to fourth-year students. Prior to registration, a minimum of 12-credits of 300-level courses related to media, technology and/or communications recommended.)

name: Feminist Postcolonial Critique and Journalism in a Digital Age
description: Feminist postcolonial critique of journalism, and an examination of underlying democratic ideals in a rapidly evolving media landscape.

name: Integrated Journalism - INTEGRATED JOURN
description: Grammar and syntax of media across platforms; skills and knowledge-based model of learning with an emphasis on digital literacy.

name: Integrated Journalism - INTEGRATED JOURN
description: Grammar and syntax of media across platforms; skills and knowledge-based model of learning with an emphasis on digital literacy.

name: Journalism Practice and Standards - NWSRM STDRD I
Special Topics in Contemporary Journalism - DECDE SOC MEDIA
Special Topics in Contemporary Journalism - REPRT INDGENOUS
Special Topics in Contemporary Journalism - DATA JOURNALISM
Special Topics in Contemporary Journalism - INTERVIEWING
Special Topics in Contemporary Journalism - VISUAL JOURNALSM
Special Topics in Contemporary Journalism - IMAGINE JRNLSM
Final Research Project
description: Pass/Fail.

name: Readings in Korean Topics I
description: Readings in intermediate-level Korean on aspects of Korean culture, customs, and contemporary life, along with structured conversations based on those readings. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 301/302 or KORN 300.

name: Basic Korean
description: An introduction to the grammar and syntax of modern spoken and written Korean. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 100/101 or KORN 102.

name: Intermediate Korean
description: Reading and writing of modern colloquial Korean at an intermediate level. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 201/202 or KORN 200.

name: Modern Korean Short Fiction - MOD KORN SHRT FC
description: Reading and translating twentieth-century Korean short fiction.
prerequisite: Either (a) KORN 300 or (b) all of KORN 301, KORN 302.

name: Readings in Korean Topics II
description: Continuation of KORN 301. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of KORN 301/302 or KORN 300.

name: Modern Korean Short Fiction - MOD KORN SHRT FC
description: Reading and translating twentieth-century Korean short fiction.
prerequisite: Either (a) KORN 300 or (b) all of KORN 301, KORN 302.

name: Supervised Study in the Korean Language - SPRV STDY KORN
description: Seminar in Korean-to-English literary translation.  Primarily for, but not limited to,  students in Asian Studies and Linguistics.

name: Supervised Study in the Korean Language - SPRV STDY KORN
description: Seminar in Korean-to-English literary translation.  Primarily for, but not limited to,  students in Asian Studies and Linguistics.

name: Readings in Middle and Early Modern Korean
description: History and structure of the Korean language through targeted close readings in different editions of an illustrated text from the 15th and 18th centuries.
prerequisite: (Non-heritage speakers should have completed KORN 410 or be taking it concurrently. Heritage and native speakers of Korean welcome.)

name: Academic and Research Practices in Library, Archival and Information Studies
Advanced Seminar in Library, Archival and Information Studies Topics - ADVANCED SEMINAR
Health and Exercise Management
description: Role of physical activity in the maintenance of a healthy life. Application of basic physical fitness and exercise methods, exercise techniques and fitness appraisal.

name: Human Anatomy
description: Structure of the neural, muscular, and skeletal systems of the human body. Special emphasis on movement analysis and the physiological effects of exercise. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,352,1477.

name: Systems Physiology I
description: Structure and function of the skeletal system, muscular system, integumentary system, neuro-hormonal control, and endocrinology. Emphasis will be to develop an understanding of the integrative nature of the systems discussed. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,352,1477.

name: Systems Physiology II
description: Structure and function of the cardiovascular system, respiratory system, urinary system, digestive system, and immune system.  Emphasis will be to develop an understanding of the integrative nature of the systems discussed. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,253,1477.

name: Lifespan Motor Development
description: A lifespan approach to motor development that examines underlying factors affecting physical growth, physical activity behaviour, and human motor performance, while highlighting contemporary issues and trends in society.

name: Sport and Exercise Psychology
description: Psychological theories and research related to sport and exercise behaviour. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,352,1477

name: Leisure and Sport in Society
description: Introduction to the political, economic and social basis of leisure and sport; concepts, theories and problems.

name: Co-operative Work Placement
description: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program. Pass/Fail.

name: Research Methods in Kinesiology
description: Critical evaluation of research studies and methods with emphasis on the physical activity context. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,352,1477.

name: Introduction to Statistics in Kinesiology
description: Basic concepts and principles of descriptive and inferential statistics, and distribution-free statistical techniques. Please consult the School of Kinesiology Credit Exclusion Lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,205,253,1477.

name: Human Motor Behaviour I
description: Processes underlying human movement and learning motor skills and factors influencing acquisition, performance, and movement control.

name: Biomechanics I
description: Application of elementary principles of physics and math to a quantitative analysis of movement.  Analysis will also focus on the development of forces within muscles and their effect on initiating and controlling human movement.

name: Nutrition, Physical Activity, and Health
description: Study of nutrition and its application to physical activity and health.  Macro- and micronutrient classification and recommended daily intakes, their digestion, functions in the body and their role in supporting physical activity and health will be discussed.
prerequisite: All of KIN 131, KIN 132. (and second-year standing; similar courses to KIN 131 and KIN 132 can be considered.)

name: Exercise Physiology I
description: Acute and chronic effects of exercise on body systems; basic concepts of cardiovascular, respiratory and muscular responses to physical activity.

name: Health Policy and Society
description: Health policy and the social context in relation to active health.

name: Human Athletic Performance
description: An exploration of human movement and related issues pertaining to sports and athletic performance for non-Kinesiology students. Not for credit in the B.Kin. Program.

name: Co-operative Work Placement
description: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program. Pass/Fail.

name: Neuromuscular Integration of Human Movement
description: The neurophysiological and functional neuroanatomical processes involved in the sensory and motor control of movement, posture and balance in the human. Peripheral and central sensorimotor structures, and neurological diseases that affect human movement and balance control will be discussed.

name: Biomechanical Properties of Tissues
description: Mechanics of muscular contraction and how the mechanical properties of the muscle, ligaments, tendons, and bone work synergistically.

name: Exercise Testing and Prescription
description: Conditioning methods, exercise techniques and appraisal methods for fitness in physical activity and sport.

name: Advanced Applications of Exercise Physiology
description: Explore how the cardiovascular and respiratory systems are regulated and integrated during exercise.

name: Instructional Strategies for Including Persons with Disabilities in Physical Activity
description: Examining curricular and instructional adaptations for accommodating participants with disabilities in inclusive physical activity environments.

name: Creating Effective, Developmentally Appropriate, Physical Activity Learning Environments
description: The pedagogical skills and knowledge required to design, and implement, developmentally appropriate physical activities learning environments in a variety of settings.

name: Leisure Services for Persons with a Disability
description: Policy issues relating to leisure opportunities for persons with disabilities.

name: Movement Experiences for Young Children
description: The design and implementation of movement experiences for children in early childhood years.

name: Foundations of Coaching
description: Methods of athletic conditioning, planning the program, psychology of training and coaching, athletic evaluation.

name: Sport, Peace, and Conflict
description: Relationships that sport and leisure have with peace, conflict, and social inequality in Canada and internationally.

name: Leisure, Sport and Popular Culture
description: Selected aspects of leisure and sport examined in relation to modern social structures and cultures.

name: The Modern Olympics: Power, Politics, and Performance
description: Examination of the Modern Olympic Games as an event with important political, economic, environmental, and cultural ramifications.

name: Co-operative Work Placement
description: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

name: Indigenous Sport and Physical Culture in Settler Canada
description: Historical and contemporary issues in Canada that shape Indigenous sport and physical activity, health programs, and policies.

name: Neuroanatomy of Human Movement
description: Neuroanatomy of human motion in healthy and clinical populations.

name: Medical Aspects of Sport and Exercise
description: Training and safety strategies for the management and prevention of disorders of internal organs and central nervous system. Topics include environmental and nutritional factors in conditioning and pre-event preparation.

name: Sport Nutrition
description: Sport nutrition guidelines, physiological mechanisms of fuel use in the body, nutritional strategies to support weight change, hydration, and ergogenic aids the needs of special athlete populations.
prerequisite: All of KIN 131, KIN 132, KIN 232. (and third-year standing. Similar courses to KIN 131, KIN 132, and KIN 232 can be considered.)

name: Pulmonary Physiology of Exercise
description: Operation of the lungs, chest wall, and ventilatory control mechanisms during dynamic whole-body exercise.

name: Skeletal Muscle Physiology: From Generation to Regeneration
description: Cellular and molecular mechanisms of muscle adaptability to physical activity: muscle development, signaling cascades of hypertrophy and atrophy, and satellite cell contribution to muscle regeneration/repair; etiology of intramuscular fatigue.

name: Planning Physical Education, Sport and Exercise Programs
description: Processes, techniques and considerations in the planning, implementation and evaluation of physical education, sport and exercise programs in both public and private agencies.

name: Exploring Alternative Methods for Teaching Games and Sports
description: Examination of innovative, developmentally appropriate, conceptual and tactical approaches to team game instruction.

name: Prevention of Sports Injuries
description: Training and safety strategies for the prevention of injuries to the musculoskeletal system and sense organs.

name: Psychobiology of Physical Activity
description: Exploration of the role that physical activity and exercise play in modifying the neurobiological, autonomic, endocrine, and inflammatory responses to stress.

name: Aging, Health, and Society
description: Examination of current issues in the sociology of aging and health.

name: Health Promotion and Physical Activity
description: Current perspectives on health promotion and health education; design and implementation of health promotion strategies in a variety of arenas, particularly health promotion/education strategies aimed at encouraging physical activity.

name: Co-operative Work Placement
description: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

name: Sport Marketing and Communication
description: A seminar on the application of social science theories and methods to sport marketing and communication.

name: Co-operative Work Placement
description: Supervised, technical work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of three months. Technical report. Restricted to students meeting the requirements of the School of Kinesiology and the Co-operative Education Program.  Pass/Fail.

name: Advanced Seminar in Systems Biology, Exercise and Health - ADV SEM SYS BIO
description: Topics examine the roles of physical activity and fitness on physiological systems and underlying cellular and metabolic mechanisms.
prerequisite: Two of KIN 320, KIN 321, KIN 322, KIN 335, KIN 420, KIN 424, KIN 432, KIN 435, KIN 438. (Restricted to students in the BKIN program with fourth-year standing.)

name: Advanced Seminar in Indigenous Sport, Physical Activity and Health - ADV SEM INDG SPR
description: Topics explore the relationship between Indigenous physical cultures, physical activity, health and wellbeing.
prerequisite: (Restricted to students in the BKIN program with third- or fourth-year standing.)

name: Advanced Seminar in Psychology of Movement - ADV SEM PSYC MVM
description: Topics examines the application of psychology to understanding and supporting healthy sport, physical activity, and health behaviors.
prerequisite: (Restricted to students in the BKIN program with third- or fourth-year standing.)

name: Advanced Seminar in Interdisciplinary Research in Kinesiology
description: Topics will be approached from multiple perspectives in a course designed to explore the interdisciplinarity of the field of kinesiology.
prerequisite: (Restricted to students in the BKIN program with fourth-year standing.)

name: Directed Studies in Kinesiology
description: Opportunity for students to conduct an independent study in a subject area of interest to them, under the direction of a KIN faculty member.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing and permission of the Associate Director, Undergraduate Program.)

name: Undergraduate Research Experience in Kinesiology
description: Opportunity for independent study that includes original data collection, under the direction of a KIN faculty member.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing and permission of the Associate Director, Undergraduate Program.)

name: Special Topics in Kinesiology - SPEC TPCS KIN
Special Topics in Kinesiology - SPEC TPCS KIN

Psychology of Leadership and Group Processes
description: Contemporary theory, research and application with regard to leadership and group processes in the context of sport and exercise.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Topics selected by the student, with the approval of the Graduate Advisor, can be studied under the supervision of a member of the faculty.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Topics selected by the student, with the approval of the Graduate Advisor, can be studied under the supervision of a member of the faculty.

name: Bioenergetics of Physical Activity
description: Basic energy systems of the human body; primarily concentrating on the bioenergetics of the skeletal muscle cell, recovery from muscular work, substrate utilization, muscle fiber types, strength, endurance and the physiological assessment of maximal performance.

name: Human Motor Performance
description: Processes underlying the ability to learn and perform motor skills.

name: Psycho-Social Aspects of Physical Activity
description: Selected psycho-social considerations in sport: initial and continuing involvement in the competitive sport environment.

name: Research Methods in Kinesiology
description: Research methods applied to the study of sport and physical activity, the nature of scientific inquiry, the design of experiments, the survey as a research medium, the historical and philosophical methods of inquiry, the writing of the research report.

name: Qualitative Methods in Sport, Leisure, and Health Studies
description: Theoretical, methodological, and ethical debates about and approaches to qualitative methods; issues in and approaches to qualitative inquiry.

name: Research Methods for Sport and Health Sciences
description: Interpretation and evaluation of research methods and scientific findings related to coaching sciences and exercise and health-related professions.

name: Coaching Effectiveness
description: Analysis of athlete performance and appropriate design and application of coaching intervention and skill acquisition for athlete and coach development.

name: Performance Planning
description: Application of findings from sport profile and gap analysis to the planning and design of high performance training and coaching programs. Focuses on quadrennial, annual, meso and microcycle planning to integrate key factors that impact athlete performance and progression along the athlete development pathway.

name: High Performance Sport Inquiry
description: Blended learning approach in a problem-based setting. Students support their own research interests within the high performance sport arena.

name: Master's Thesis
description: Pass/Fail.

name: Directed Field Studies in Kinesiology
description: Pass/Fail.

name: Doctoral Dissertation
description: Pass/Fail.

name: Introduction to Law and Society
description: Ideas, concepts, and frameworks for thinking about the nature of law and legal processes in both Canadian and global contexts.

name: Against the Law
description: Competing approaches to law and legal authority shaped by conflicts over historical and contemporary inequalities, including the exercise of and challenges to coercive law enforcement and claims made for legal redress.

name: Topics in Law and Society - LAW & SOCIETY
description: Interdisciplinary approaches to topics such as the purpose of law, retribution and punishment, restorative justice, ethics, property ownership, human rights, gender equality, legal change, or civil disobedience.

name: Introduction to Latin American Studies
description: An overview of the culture and society of Latin America from ancient to contemporary times and from Argentina to Mexico.

name: Popular Culture in Latin America
description: The culture of everyday life, both rural and urban: issues of identity, popular memory, resistance, negotiation, as expressed through ritual, crafts, the body, social movements, films, music, and literature.

name: Indigenous Peoples of Latin America
description: Ethnohistory and contemporary cultures of the indigenous peoples of Mexico, Middle America, and South America. Different cultural areas or regions may be selected to illustrate the course's principal themes.

name: Intermediate Latin I
description: Completion of the grammatical foundations of classical Latin, Part I.

name: Beginning Latin II
description: Classical Latin, Part II.

name: Beginning Latin I
description: Classical Latin, Part I.

name: Latin Literature of the Classical Period (Prose)
description: Readings in Latin Prose.

name: Latin Literature of the Classical Period (Verse)
description: Readings in Latin Verse.

name: Latin Verse - LATIN VERSE
description: Studies in narrative verse, comedy, satire, elegiac and lyric poetry. May be repeated for up to 12 credits. It is recommended that the corequisite course be completed prior to LATN 402.

name: Studies in Latin Prose and Verse - LATN PRSE & VRSE
description: Thematic studies using both Latin prose and Latin verse. May be repeated for up to 6 credits.

name: Intermediate Latin II
description: Completion of the grammatical foundations of classical Latin, Part II; an introduction to the reading of unadapted passages of Latin literature and discussion of thier cultural contexts.

name: Latin Verse - LATIN VERSE
description: Narrative verse, comedy, satire, elegiac and lyric poetry.  Credit will not be given for both LATN 402 and LATN 502.

name: Studies in Latin Prose and Verse - LATN PROSE&VERSE
description: Advanced thematic studies using both Latin prose and Latin verse. May be repeated for up to 6 credits.

name: Landscape Technologies I: Site Engineering
description: Terrain design, drainage, and stormwater management. Open only to B. End. students. Credit will be granted for only one of LARC 431 or LARC 531.

name: A Behavioural Approach to Planting Design
description: Functional, ecological, and behavioural theory and practice applied to planting design at different scales.

name: Trees and Shrubs in Landscape
description: Culture and identification of landscape materials with emphasis on woody plants. Elementary principles of landscape composition.  Suitable for students of other faculties and departments interested in landscape materials and their uses, but priority given to  Agroecology and Landscape Architecture students.

name: SITE ANALYSIS AND PLANNING II
description: Site analysis and planning of relatively complex sites, emphasizing storm water management design. Open only to B.En.D. students. Credit will be granted for only one of LARC 440, LARC 540 or DES 231.

name: Landscape Architecture Design Studio I
description: Landscape design methods and processes. Restricted to M.L.A. students.

name: Green Network Planning
description: Theory and methods of long-range green space planning for urban areas.

name: Planting Design
description: Functional, ecological, and behavioural theory and practice applied to planting design at different scales.

name: Landscape Architectural History
description: History, principles, and theory of landscape architecture in Europe, America and Asia. Influence of cultural attitudes and societal change upon natural environments, parks, gardens, and town planning.

name: Landscape Architecture Theory
description: Theoretical positions in landscape architecture and their relation to designed landscapes.

name: Design Research Methods
description: Examination of various design research methods in contemporary practice in landscape architecture.

name: Landscape Technologies I
description: Terrain design, drainage and stormwater management. Credit will be granted for only one of LARC 531 or LARC 431.

name: Landscape Technologies II
description: Hard landscape materials.

name: Site Analysis and Planning
description: Site analysis and planning of relatively complex sites, emphasizing stormwater management design. Credit will be granted for only one of LARC 540, LARC 440 or DES 231.

name: Aesthetics and Sustainability
description: Analysis and planning of landscapes to communicate sustainability and to inform public awareness and design by exploring the relationship between aesthetics and sustainability.

name: Professional Practice
description: Ethical, legal and business context of professional practice, including contracts, project management.

name: Co-operative Education - COOP EDUC
description: Approved and supervised work experience in an established company or organization for a minimum of one academic term.  Technical report required.

name: Green Network Planning
