description: Intensive study of a major philosopher such as Wittgenstein, Russell, or Heidegger, or school, such as pragmatism or logical empiricism.

name: Philosophy of History - PHIL OF HISTORY
description: Concepts of history and historical explanation, historical progress, purpose, necessity, law and causation. Hegel, Marx, Vico, Spengler, Pareto, Collingwood, Croce, and Toynbee, as well as contemporary figures. Students will be expected to have an adequate knowledge of ancient or modern history.

name: Topics in Symbolic Logic - TOPICS:SYMB LOGI
description: Formal semantics, proof theory, incompleteness and decidability, axiomatic set theory, independence results. Consult the Department as to which topics are offered in a given year.

name: Topics in Social and Political Philosophy
description: Central concepts and problems in political life and thought including obligation, citizenship, representation, justice; equality; civil rights and liberty; disobedience.
prerequisite: (9 credits of PHIL/POLI at the 200-level or above.)

name: Topics in Epistemology
description: Analysis of the concept of knowledge; problems of justifying ordinary and basic empirical beliefs.

name: Philosophy of Perception
description: The contribution of the senses to knowledge of the external world; the nature of perception and its contribution to empirical knowledge.
prerequisite: Either (a) PHIL 240 or (b) COGS 200. (If COGS 200, accompanied by 3 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above.)

name: Topics in Continental Philosophy
description: A study of European philosophers from amongst Husserl, Heidegger, Habermas, Foucault, Derrida, Lacan, Levinas, and others. Credit will be granted for only one of PHIL 448 or PHIL 449.

name: Philosophy of Mind
description: The nature of the mental and physical; the relation between minds and bodies; the character of psychological explanation.
prerequisite: Either (a) PHIL 240 or (b) COGS 200. (If COGS 200, accompanied by 3 credits of PHIL at the 200-level or above.)

name: Topics in the Philosophy of Cognitive Science
description: Philosophical topics in the cognitive sciences, such as empiricism vs. nativism, consciousness, mental representation, cognitive architecture, language and thought, and situated cognition.
prerequisite: Either (a) PHIL 240 or (b) COGS 200. (If COGS 200, accompanied by 3 credits in PHIL at the 200-level or above. Recommended: PHIL 441 or PHIL 451.)

name: Philosophy of Biology
description: Methodological, historical, philosophical and social science questions about biology.
prerequisite: (Fourth-year standing in any degree program or 9 credits of philosophy.)

name: Comparative Conceptions of the Self
description: Ways in which the 'self' has been portrayed in eastern and western religious traditions. Thinkers to be considered include Aristotle, Mencius, Freud, Xunzi (Hsn-tzu), Nietzche, and Zhuangzi (Chuang-tzu).

name: Directed Reading
description: Same as PHIL 486-9.

name: Honours Tutorial
description: For students in fourth-year Honours.

name: Seminar for Majors in Philosophy
description: Selected problems in philosophy, with attention to methods of research. Check with the department for specific topics. Primarily for fourth-year Philosophy Major students, but also open to Philosophy Honours.

name: Early Modern Philosophy - ERLY MODERN PHIL
Philosophy of Language - PHIL OF LANGUAGE
Philosophy of Language - PHIL OF LANGUAGE
Philosophy of Mind - PHIL OF MIND
Philosophy of Science - PHIL OF SCIENCE
Medication Management I
description: Modules and integration activities focusing on: an introduction to infectious diseases; musculoskeletal disorders; dermatology; eyes, ears, nose, and throat disorders; and hematology.

name: Foundations of Pharmacy
description: Scientific concepts and pharmacy practice principles. Role of the pharmacist, patient assessment skills, professional identity, communication skills, and an understanding of legal and ethical responsibilities.

name: Study Design and Interpretation I
description: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on biostatistical foundations, randomized controlled trials, and systematic review of randomized controlled trials.

name: Seminar: Pharmacists in Practice I
description: Current and future roles for pharmacists and controversies in pharmacy practice.

name: Technology in Healthcare
description: Knowledge and skills related to the role and applications of technology in health care.

name: Medication Management II
description: Modules and integration activities focusing on respirology and cardiovascular disorders.

name: Medication Management III
description: Modules and integration activities focusing on nephrology, endocrinology, and neurology.

name: Study Design and Interpretation II
description: Principles of screening and diagnostic tests, clinical prediction rules, clinical practice guidelines, conflicts of interest, economic evaluation of therapeutics and medical technologies, harm-benefit analysis, and how to incorporate the best available evidence into practice.

name: Seminar: Pharmacists in Practice II
description: Current and future roles for pharmacists and controversies in pharmacy practice, focusing on the roles and training opportunities for pharmacists in specialty areas of outpatient and inpatient practice.

name: Nutrition for Pharmacists
description: Foundations of nutrition, nutrition for healthy individuals through the lifespan, and selected clinical applications of nutrition in pharmacy practice.

name: Institutional Practice Skills
description: Preparation for experiential learning in the hospital setting. Focuses on enhancing familiarity with the care environment and developing skills suited for students to apply to patient care during institutional experiential rotations.

name: Community Service Learning II
description: Service learning activities with external community partner sites and members. Pass/Fail.

name: Selected Topics - SELECTED TOPICS
description: Thesis or essay.

name: Selected Topics - SELECTED TOPICS
description: Thesis or essay.

name: Selected Topics - SELECTED TOPICS
description: Thesis or essay.

name: Selected Topics - SELECTED TOPICS
description: Thesis or essay.

name: Selected Topics - SELECTED TOPICS
description: Thesis or essay.

name: Selected Topics - SELECTED TOPICS
description: Thesis or essay.

name: Selected Topics - SELECTED TOPICS
description: Thesis or essay.

name: Selected Topics - SELECTED TOPICS
description: Thesis or essay.

name: Directed Studies in Clinical Pharmacy
description: Individual assignments involving library and clinical investigation of specific problems relating to drug utilization and information topics.

name: Directed Studies in Clinical Pharmacy - DIR CLINCL PHAR
description: Individual assignments involving library and clinical investigation of specific problems relating to drug utilization and information topics.

name: Directed Studies in Clinical Pharmacy - DIR CLINCL PHAR
description: Individual assignments involving library and clinical investigation of specific problems relating to drug utilization and information topics.

name: Directed Studies in Pharmacy Education - PHARMACY ED
description: Individual assignments involving library and scholarly inquiry related to pharmacy education.

name: Directed Studies in Pharmacy Education - PHARMACY ED
description: Individual assignments involving library and scholarly inquiry related to pharmacy education.

name: Directed Studies in Pharmacy Practice - DIR STDY PHAR PR
description: Individual assignments involving library and field work investigations of problems associated with pharmacy practice.

name: Medication Management IV
description: Modules and integration activities focusing on psychiatry; gastroenterology disorders; and oncology and palliative care.

name: Medication Management V
description: Modules and integration activities focusing on reproductive health, sexual health, and genitourinary disorders; special infectious diseases; and toxicology.

name: Pharmaceutical Care in Indigenous Health
description: Indigenous health in Canada and the role pharmacists' cultural humility and safety can play when collaborating with other health professionals and Indigenous communities to provide care and healing.

name: Travel Health
description: Providing a consultative service to patients based on patient medical and travel history. Recommending and administering vaccinations according to guidelines. Making recommendations regarding oral medications needed for safe travel.

name: Clinical Pharmacokinetics
description: Lectures and discussions of topics on the application of pharmacokinetic principles and the use of therapeutic drug level monitoring in clinical pharmacy practice.

name: Renal Pharmacotherapeutics
description: Case-based approach to the pathophysiology, pharmacology, clinical pharmacokinetics, and pharmacotherapy in nephrology with emphasis on the integration and application of fundamental principles to clinical situations in class.

name: Toxicology and Precision Medicine
description: Basic principles of toxicology; toxicity of pharmaceuticals, and precision medicine approaches to mitigate toxicity.

name: Pharmacology of Drugs of Misuse and Abuse
description: Biological, pharmacological, and psychological aspects of drugs of misuse and abuse.

name: Leadership Experience Applied to Pharmacy (LEAP)
description: Leadership skills in preparation for the practice of pharmacy in direct or non-direct patient care settings and contexts.

name: Practical Applications of Pharmacoepidemiology and Health Economics
description: Principles and methods of collecting epidemiological and economic evidence used to assess the value of pharmaceuticals and services provided by pharmacists.

name: Pharmacy Practice in Acute and Critically Ill Patients
description: Pharmaceutical care concepts for managing acute and critically ill patients.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing and a combined grade average of 70% in PHRM 211 and PHRM 212.)

name: Pharmacotherapy in Oncology
description: Common oncological diseases and their drug treatment.

name: Seminar: Pharmacists in Practice III
description: Current and potential roles for pharmacists, and contemporary issues in pharmacy practice. Focus on the role of pharmacists as patient educators, researchers and collaborators in interprofessional teams.

name: Pain Research and Therapy
description: Basic mechanisms and the clinical management of acute and chronic pain.

name: Practice Management and Leadership
description: Application of management and leadership principles and skills to pharmacy operations.

name: Clinical Skills: Administration of Injections
description: Training for authorization to administer injections.

name: Introductory Pharmacy Practice Experience - Outpatient III
description: Direct patient care activities in an outpatient setting. Building on existing pharmaceutical knowledge and problem solving ability. Increased involvement in diverse patient care situations. Pass/Fail.

name: Seminar: Advanced Topics in Pharmacy Practice
description: Pharmacists in practice, emerging pharmacy practice issues and pharmacists as preceptors. Pass/Fail.

name: Critical Appraisal of Pharmacotherapy Literature
description: Principles of clinical study design, focusing on randomized controlled trials, systematic reviews, epidemiologic studies (cohort, case-control), pharmacoeconomic analyses, clinical prediction rules, and guidelines. Pass/Fail.

name: PharmD Seminar
description: Seminar course about current and potential roles for pharmacists. Students will also deliver an individual and a group seminar. Pass/Fail.

name: Patient Assessment Skills
description: Principles and practices of patient assessment, applied to the monitoring of drug efficacy and toxicity. Pass/Fail.

name: Pharmacotherapeutics 2
description: Respirology, dermatology, and ears, eyes, nose, and throat. Pass/Fail.

name: Pharmacotherapeutics 3
description: Cardiovascular disorders. Pass/Fail.

name: Pharmacotherapeutics 4
description: Infectious diseases. Pass/Fail.

name: Pharmacotherapeutics 6
description: Gastroenterology and musculoskeletal disorders. Pass/Fail.

name: Outpatient Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience
description: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in outpatient settings. Patient care will be provided for a wide range of therapeutic areas. Pass/Fail.

name: Inpatient Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience
description: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in inpatient settings. Patient care will be provided for a wide range of therapeutic areas. Pass/Fail.

name: Healthcare Quality Improvement
description: Builds on the foundation of patient care and management learning with knowledge about healthcare system improvement. Focuses on principles of quality measurement and quality improvement in health. Pass/Fail.

name: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Outpatient
description: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in a variety of outpatient settings. Pass/Fail.
prerequisite: All of PHRM 451, PHRM 452, PHRM 453, PHRM 461.

name: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Inpatient
description: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in a variety of inpatient settings. Pass/Fail.
prerequisite: All of PHRM 451, PHRM 452, PHRM 453, PHRM 461.

name: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Specialized Outpatient
description: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in a variety of specialized outpatient settings.
prerequisite: All of PHRM 451, PHRM 452, PHRM 453, PHRM 461.

name: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Ambulatory/Primary Care
description: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in a variety of ambulatory or primary care settings. Pass/Fail.
prerequisite: All of PHRM 451, PHRM 452, PHRM 453, PHRM 461.

name: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Selected Direct Patient Care
description: Application of integrated problem-solving skills to resolve increasingly complex drug-therapy problems in outpatient or inpatient settings. Pass/Fail.
prerequisite: All of PHRM 451, PHRM 452, PHRM 453, PHRM 461.

name: Advanced Pharmacy Practice Experience - Selected Direct Patient Care or Non-Direct Patient Care
description: Options available in such domains as patient care (various settings), research, health policy, education, and others. The available placement options will vary from year to year depending on site/practice educator availability. Pass/Fail.
prerequisite: All of PHRM 451, PHRM 452, PHRM 453, PHRM 461.

name: Clinical Decision Making V
description: Pass/fail.

name: Orthopaedic Clinical Reasoning and Skills
description: Restricted to students in the Graduate Certificate in Orthopaedic Manipulative Physical Therapy program.

name: Evidence and Theory in Manipulative Therapy
description: Restricted to students in the Graduate Certificate in Orthopaedic Manipulative Physical Therapy program.

name: Seminar in Mammalian Physiology - MAMMALIAN PHYL
Sensory Physiology II; Vestibular System, Somatic
description: Offered in odd numbered years.

name: City Visuals
description: An exploratory journey through the vast world of visualizing the city and ways of representing the built environment, including how to both interpret and use visualizations to read the city.
prerequisite: (Second-year standing or above in any program.)

name: City-Making: A Global Perspective
description: Contemporary city development trends, policies, and practices across the globe as explored against the backdrop of culture and technology. Includes hands-on learning.
prerequisite: (Second-year standing or above in any program.)

name: The Just City in a Divided World
description: Considers the city as a terrain for the manifestation and mediation of social justice. Explores how the allocation of land, goods, and services in cities (re)produces social stratification, and how institutions and civil society negotiate just and unjust outcomes.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.)

name: Urban Planning Issues and Concepts
description: Evolution, practice and future of urban planning and development, with emphasis on institutional arrangements, housing, transportation, urban design and development control. For third- and fourth-year undergraduate students interested in urban planning.

name: Smart Cities: Concepts, Methods and Design
description: Rapid transformation of cities by information technology and socio-economic innovation; growth in citizen-generated data and the internet of things; emerging theory, methods, and frameworks for understanding "Smart Cities".
prerequisite: (Third-year standing or above in any program. Second year students may be admitted with permission of instructor.)

name: Planning for Community Economic Development
description: Theories of community economic development planning. Concepts of community wealth, income, growth and development. Models of the formal and informal community economy.

name: Foundations of Planning Theory and History
Environment and Sustainability Concepts for Planning Practice
Theory and Methods of Urban Design
description: Application of urban design theory to a neighbourhood design.

name: Selected Topics in Experimental Learning: The Planning Studio
Internship - INTERNSHIP
description: Pass/Fail.

name: Internship - INTERNSHIP
description: Pass/Fail.

name: Indigenous Planning: Ways of Being, Knowing and Doing
description: Indigenous world views; history of colonization in Canada; contemporary resurgence of Indigenous modes of planning.

name: Current Issues in Planning - PRAC LEGAL BASCS
description: Each year the school may offer one or more courses on a topical issue covering recent advances in the field.

name: Master's Thesis - MASTERS THESIS
description: Research and preparation of a thesis on a topic in public policy or professional practice.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: With the approval of the Chair of the program.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: With the approval of the Chair of the program.

name: The Role of Theory in Planning Research
description: This course will be taken in the first term of the Master's program.

name: Design of Planning- and Policy-Oriented Research
description: Research design for SCARP thesis-based Master's students. Approaches for designing research methodologies and thesis structure. Selection processes for research focus; linking research problems to methodological sources; logics of structuring the thesis.

name: Seminar in Real Property Development and Planning
description: Topics will vary.

name: Public Health, Transportation, and the Built Environment
description: Health issues associated with transportation and the built environment; design of urban form for non-motorized transportation for the improvement of personal and environmental health; factors that impact transportation choices; applying findings from research to specific transportation planning processes and projects. Credit will be granted for only one of PLAN 579 or SPPH 571.

name: Enriched Physics II
description: Electricity and magnetism, electrical circuits, induction, electromagnetic waves, Maxwell's equations and applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414
prerequisite: Either (a) one of PHYS 106, PHYS 107 or (b) a score of 85% or higher in one of PHYS 101, PHYS 131 or (c) a score of 85% or higher in PHYS 117.

name: Enriched Physics 1 (lecture)
description: Classical mechanics including conservation laws, angular momentum of rigid bodies and simple harmonic motion, wave phenomena, with an introduction to special relativity, quantum mechanics, nuclear physics, statistical mechanics and solid state physics. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion lists: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414
prerequisite: Either (a) a score more than 85% in one of PHYS 12, MATH 12 or (b) a score more than 85% in one of PHYS 12, PREC 12 or (c) a score more than 85% in one of PHYS 12, CALC 12 or (d) a score more than 85% in PHYS 100.

name: Introductory Physics
description: Kinematics, force, energy, momentum, use of graphs and vectors in physics; thermal energy, heat transfer, Earth's energy balance; electricity. Students with credit for Physics 12 may not obtain credit for this course unless they took AP, IB, or A-level Physics and were offered advanced credit for PHYS 100.
prerequisite: Not open to students with credit for PHYS 12. (Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12 is required; Physics 11 is required for first-year students, strongly recommended for others.)

name: Dynamics and Waves
description: Kinematics including curvilinear motion. Forces and Newton's laws of motion. Work-energy theorem, conservation of energy. Conservation of momentum, collisions. Torque, rotational dynamics, angular momentum. Oscillations and waves. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

name: Enriched Experimental Physics
description: A laboratory course accompanying PHYS 108 with emphasis on data collection and analysis and experimental techniques.

name: Electricity, Light and Radiation
description: Optics, electricity and magnetism, electric circuits, radioactivity, including biological applications. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 157 and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

name: Experimental Physics Lab
description: Introductory laboratory course, with emphasis on data collection, data analysis techniques, and scientific reasoning. Please consult the Faculty of Science credit exclusion list: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

name: Energy and Waves (Lecture)
description: Fluids, harmonic oscillator, travelling waves, standing waves, sound, and interference of light waves, including diffraction. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: [Link to:www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414 ]

name: Introductory Physics for Engineers II
description: Electricity and magnetism, DC and AC circuits, optics. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

name: Introductory Physics Laboratory for Engineers
description: A laboratory course with emphasis on experimental design, measurement and analysis techniques. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414

name: Introductory Physics for Engineers I
description: Heat, thermodynamics, oscillations, waves, and sound. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

name: Mechanics I
description: Statics of particles, equilibrium or rigid bodies, rigid body statics and internal forces, trusses; kinematics: rectilinear motion; dynamics:  Newton's second law, friction, impulse, momentum, work and energy.  Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100 and one of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

name: Introduction to Computational Physics
description: Introduction to UNIX/Linux; software tools for processing, fitting and displaying data; numerical methods and application in the physical sciences.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.

name: Thermal Physics I
description: Fundamentals of thermodynamics and statistical physics; entropy, laws of thermodynamics, heat engines, free energy, phase transitions, Boltzmann statistics, quantum statistics.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153, SCIE 001.

name: Intermediate Mechanics
description: Review of kinematics, Newton's laws, angular momentum and fixed axis rotation. Rigid body motion, central forces, non-inertial frames of reference. Introduction to Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 170, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

name: Intermediate Experimental Physics I
description: Analog electronics and amplifiers, digital electronics, analog-to-digital converters and an introduction to use of computers in data analysis and simulations.
prerequisite: Either (a) one of PHYS 108, PHYS 118 and one of PHYS 109, PHYS 119; or (b) PHYS 102 or (c) all of PHYS 158, PHYS 159 or (d) SCIE 001.

name: Relativity and Quanta
description: Special relativity: Lorentz transformation, dynamics and conservation laws. Quantum physics: the experimental evidence for quantization; a qualitative discussion of the concepts of quantum mechanics and their application to simple systems of atoms and nuclei.
prerequisite: Either (a) one of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 158, PHYS 153 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121; or (b) SCIE 001.

name: Co-operative Work Placement I
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the winter term of the second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

name: Intermediate Experimental Physics II
description: Thermodynamics experiments, modern physics experiments and use of computers in data analysis.

name: Co-operative Work Placement II
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

name: Electricity and Magnetism
description: Maxwell's equations and their applications, electrical fields and potentials of static charge distributions, current, fields of moving charges, magnetic fields, electromagnetic induction.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255.

name: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics
description: Principles and applications of quantum mechanics, wave mechanics, the Schroedinger equation, expectation values, Hermitian operators, commuting observables,  one-dimensional systems, harmonic oscillators, angular momentum, three dimensional systems. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.

name: Introduction to Biophysics
description: Physical principles involved in biological systems at the microscopic and molecular scales. Diffusion, low Reynolds number dynamics, the physicist's view of biomolecular structure, models of molecular motors and membranes.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and either (a) PHYS 203 or (b) one of ENPH 257, CHEM 201, CHEM 205 and one of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 302.

name: Electrical Laboratory
description: Selected experiments in electromagnetism and electronics; computer data acquisition; advanced data analysis and simulation.

name: Advanced Mechanics
description: Variational calculus, Lagrangian dynamics, rigid body motion including free and forced precession, Hamiltonian mechanics, Poisson brackets, canonical coordinates, Hamilton-Jacobi theory, action angle variables. Introduction to dynamical chaos: determinism, Lyapunov exponents.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 216, ENPH 270 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255, MATH 256, MATH 258.

name: Introduction to Mathematical Physics
description: The application of ordinary and partial differential equations to physical problems; boundary and initial value problems associated with heat, wave and Laplace equations. Fourier analysis; expansions in Bessel and Legendre functions. Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 312 and MATH 316.

name: Electronics Laboratory
description: A project-oriented lab introducing the design and construction of microprocessor-controlled devices.

name: Physics of Music
description: An introduction to the physical principles important to the production, transmission and perception of musical sounds. The treatment will be non-mathematical; with emphasis on demonstrations. Topics may include the description of sound waves, resonances, scales, physics of hearing, examination of specific musical instruments, etc. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science.

name: Energy and Climate
description: The fundamental physics behind global issues of energy use and climate change.
prerequisite: Either (a) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 102, PHYS 107, PHYS 108, PHYS 117, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, PHYS 158; or (b) SCIE 001.

name: Frontiers in Physics and Astronomy
description: Current research topics in physics and astronomy are investigated and explored. Technical communication and research skills are studied and developed via oral presentations and written scientific reports on these current research topics.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing in a physics honours program or fourth-year standing in a physics or astronomy major program.)

name: Directed Research Project in Physics
description: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a written report. This course requires  approval of the course instructor  and  program  advisor in the Department of Physics and Astronomy.

name: Applications of Classical Mechanics
description: Review of principles. Particle mechanics: Euler's equations, tops and gyroscopes, motion of the Earth, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian methods. Variational principles in optics and mechanics, Liouville's theorem and statistical mechanics. The relationship between classical and quantum mechanics.

name: Co-operative Work Placement III
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

name: Introduction to Elementary Particles
description: Standard model, classification of elementary particles and forces of nature, symmetries, conservation laws, quark model, quantum electrodynamics, quantum chromodynamics, and the theory of weak interactions.

name: Electromagnetic Theory
description: Applications of Maxwell's theory. Wave propagation in dielectrics, conductors and plasmas, wave guides, radiation, antennae, and special relativity.

name: Applications of Quantum Mechanics
description: Spin and angular momentum addition, perturbation methods, and applications in the fields of Atomic, Molecular, Nuclear, and Solid State Physics.

name: Statistical Mechanics
description: Principles and applications of  statistical mechanics. Ideal gases, degenerate Fermi gases, Bose-Einstein condensation, black body radiation, fluctuations and phase transitions. Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 403 or PHYS 455. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 203, ENPH 257, PHYS 257, CHEM 201, CHEM 304 and one of PHYS 304, PHYS 450, CHEM 312. (One of MATH 302, MATH 318, STAT 241, STAT 251, STAT 302 is recommended.)

name: Introduction to Medical Physics
description: Radiotherapy, X-ray imaging, nuclear medicine, magnetic resonance imaging and biomedical optics.
prerequisite: (Third year standing in Science or Applied Science is required. MATH 200 (or MATH 217 or MATH 226) is recommended.)

name: Radiation Biophysics
description: Physical and chemical interactions of ionizing radiations and their biological effects at the cellular, tissue and whole-animal levels. Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 405 or PHYS 536. See the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 102, PHYS 108, PHYS 118, PHYS 153, PHYS 158, SCIE 001. (and third year standing in Science or Applied Science.)

name: Introduction to General Relativity
description: Physical consequences of Einstein's equations, including the principle of equivalence, curved space-time, geodesics, the Schwarzschild solution, deflection of light, black holes, and gravitational radiation.
prerequisite: One of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255. (PHYS 301 and one of PHYS 206, PHYS 306 are recommended.)

name: Optics
description: Principles and applications of optical physics. Interference, diffraction, coherence, polarization, Fresnel relations, optical coatings, waves in dielectric media, Gaussian beams, waveguides, optical cavities, lasers, fibre optics, and Fourier optics.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 301, PHYS 354 and one of MATH 215, MATH 255.

name: Experimental Physics - EXPTL PHYSICS
description: A laboratory course with a wide choice of experiments for fourth year Honours and Major students. Topics include solid state, nuclear, classical, quantum, electromagnetic and low temperature physics. For six credits, two weekly laboratory periods and completion of a project in second term are required.

name: Physics Demonstrations - PHYS DEMONSTRATS
description: The students will prepare, under the supervision of a faculty member, a demonstration or series of demonstrations intended to illustrate physical principles to diverse audiences. Intended for third- or fourth-year Physics Majors and Math/Science Education students.

name: Computational Physics
description: Scientific programming applied to problems in physics. Fundamentals of numerical analysis for continuum problems. Solution of linear and non-linear algebraic systems, ordinary differential equations and stochastic problems.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 312, MATH 257, MATH 316 and one of PHYS 210, EOSC 211, CPSC 110, CPSC 103, APSC 160.

name: Advanced Topics in Physics - ADV TPCS PHYS
description: Directed studies available to students in Honours Physics with approval from the Head of the Department.

name: Zoological Physics
description: Animal systems viewed from a physicist's perspective. Topics include sensory systems, energy budgets, locomotion, internal flows, physical advantages of grouping.
prerequisite: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, SCIE 001. (BIOL 325 is recommended.)

name: Experimental Physics - EXPTL PHYSICS
description: A laboratory course with a wide choice of experiments for fourth year Honours and Major students. Topics include solid state, nuclear, classical, quantum, electromagnetic and low temperature physics. For six credits, two weekly laboratory periods and completion of a project in second term are required.

name: Advanced Topics in Physics - ADV TPCS PHYS
description: Directed studies available to students in Honours Physics with approval from the Head of the Department.

name: Honours Thesis
description: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a thesis.

name: Advanced Topics in Physics - ADV TPCS PHYS
description: Directed studies available to students in Honours Physics with approval from the Head of the Department.

name: Applied Nuclear Physics
description: Radioactive decay and radiations, nuclear properties, interactions of neutrons, physical principles of power reactors, nuclear fusion, radiation monitoring, and safety.

name: Student Directed Seminar
description: Self-directed, collaborative studies, in a group-learning environment, initiated and coordinated by senior undergraduate students with the supervision of a faculty advisor. Course structure, enrolment, and delivery methods will comply with the "Handbook for Student Directed Seminars".  Cannot be used as a specialization requirement in any PHYS and/or ASTR specialization.

name: Applied Solid State Physics
description: Symmetry of crystal structures, reciprocal lattice, band theory, conduction in metals and semiconductors, phonons and superconductivity.

name: Co-operative Work Placement V
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the summer following the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

name: Quantum Mechanics I
description: Non-relativistic quantum mechanics with applications to atomic, nuclear and particle physics. Perturbation theory, multielectron atoms, molecular structure, WKB, scattering theory.

name: Co-operative Work Placement IV
description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial research setting for a minimum of 3.5 months. Normally taken during the fall term of the fourth year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Program in Physics.

name: Quantum Mechanics II
description: Time-dependent perturbation theory, density matrix formalism, NMR, emission and absorption of radiation. Elementary field theory techniques for many body systems. Quasiparticles, phonons, magnons, holes. Relativistic Klein-Gordon and Dirac equations.

name: Condensed Matter Physics I
description: One-electron theory of solids, energy bands, lattice vibration, transport theory.
prerequisite: (A background in undergraduate solid state physics such as covered in PHYS 474 is highly recommended.)

name: Special Relativity and Classical Electromagnetism
description: Boundary-value problems, Green's functions and multipole expansions, magnetostatics, Faraday's law of induction, retarded potentials, Poynting's theorem and conservation laws, gauge invariance. Propagation of electromagnetic waves. Presentation of radiation from moving charges, classical electron theory.
prerequisite: (A background in electricity and magnetism such as covered PHYS 401 is highly recommended.)

name: Statistical Mechanics
description: Mean field theory, Landau theory of phase transitions, critical phenomena, renormalization theory. Monte Carlo method, linear response theory, fluctuations.

name: Theory of Measurements - MEASUREMNT THEOR
description: Estimation of parameters from experimental measurements; maximum likelihood; least squares; tests of significance (chi square, etc). Noise properties of common devices. Extracting signals from noise; signal averaging; auto and cross-correlation, etc.

name: Teaching Techniques in Physics and Astronomy - TEACH PHYS&ASTR
description: Foundations of physics and astronomy education research, lesson plans, development of grading, effective questioning, effective presentations, methods in peer evaluation, and peer teaching.

name: Teaching Techniques in Physics and Astronomy - TEACH PHYS&ASTR
description: Foundations of physics and astronomy education research, lesson plans, development of grading, effective questioning, effective presentations, methods in peer evaluation, and peer teaching.

name: Advanced Condensed Matter Physics - ADV COND MATTER
description: Current issues in condensed matter theory.

name: Quantum Electronics and Nonlinear Optics - QNTM ELEC&NLNR
description: Macroscopic and microscopic treatments of linear and non-linear response to electromagnetic fields.

name: Elementary Particle Physics - TP ELEM PARTICLE
Topics in Quantum Theory - TPS QUANTUM THRY
Topics in General Relativity Theory - GEN RELATIVITY
Radiotherapy Physics I
description: Principles of dosimetry of ionizing radiation with emphasis on applications to radiotherapy and radiobiology.

name: Radiotherapy Physics II
description: A continuation of PHYS 534, including an extension of the topics discussed in that course.

name: Advanced Radiation Biophysics
description: Credit will be granted for only one of PHYS 536 or PHYS 405.

name: Anatomy, Physiology and Statistics for Medical Physicists
description: Restricted to graduate students in the M.Sc. (Medical Physics) Specialization.

name: Clinical Experience in Medical Physics
description: Clinical treatment planning techniques, quality assurance of treatment equipment and clinical decision making for radiation therapy. Quality assurance and decision making for medical imaging. Pass/fail.

name: Directed Studies in Physics - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: With approval of the department head, advanced studies under the direction of a staff member may be arranged in special cases.

name: Directed Studies in Physics - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: With approval of the department head, advanced studies under the direction of a staff member may be arranged in special cases.

name: Directed Studies in Physics - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: With approval of the department head, advanced studies under the direction of a staff member may be arranged in special cases.

name: Directed Studies in Physics - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: With approval of the department head, advanced studies under the direction of a staff member may be arranged in special cases.

name: Physics and Engineering of Particle Accelerators
description: Injectors, radio frequency acceleration, superconducting acceleration elements, beam dynamics, and applications of electron accelerators.

name: Beginner's Polish
description: Introduction to contemporary Polish. Oral practice, grammar, reading, writing.

name: The German Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and Film (in English)
description: The German Nazi Holocaust in Polish Literature and film.

name: First-Year Portuguese I
description: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 101 or PORT 110.

name: First-Year Portuguese II
description: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 102 or PORT 110.

name: Second-Year Portuguese I
description: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice, readings. Credit will be granted for only one of PORT 201 or PORT 210

name: Second-Year Portuguese II
description: Grammar, composition, translation, oral practice, readings. Credit may be granted for only one of PORT 202 or PORT 210.

name: Studies in Portuguese and Brazilian Culture (In English)
description: Selected topics. Please see the Department website for current course offering information.

name: Introduction to Politics
description: Political issues and case studies, drawn from Canadian and international contexts, will be used to introduce students to central debates and concepts of politics and political analysis.

name: Investigating Politics: An Introduction to Scientific Political Analysis
description: The logic, challenges, and major strategies of empirical political research. Core research tasks including: asking answerable questions, defining concepts, formulating hypotheses, gathering evidence, measuring variables, constructing comparisons, drawing causal inferences, and reporting findings.

name: The Government of Canada
description: An examination of the institutions and processes of Canadian government.

name: Introduction to Comparative Politics
description: A comparative analysis of foreign governments. Specific countries to be covered will vary according to section; consult the brochure issued by the Department.

name: Currents of Political Thought
description: A critical introduction to some major ideologies and traditions of Western political thought that examines their philosophical origins as well as their implications for political life.

name: Introduction to Global Politics
description: Applies conceptual tools to topics such as war, conflict management, the global economy, poverty, and civil society.

name: Federalism in Canada
description: Theory and practice of federalism; cultural duality, social stresses, and problems of flexibility. The constitution and role of the courts.

name: Issues in Canadian Politics - ISSUES CDN POLI
description: An examination of one or more major issues in Canadian politics (e.g., the Charter, electoral reform). Topics will vary from year to year.

name: Issues in Canadian Politics - ISSUES CDN POLI
description: An examination of one or more major issues in Canadian politics (e.g., the Charter, electoral reform). Topics will vary from year to year.

name: Issues in Canadian Politics - ISSUES CDN POLI
description: An examination of one or more major issues in Canadian politics (e.g., the Charter, electoral reform). Topics will vary from year to year.

name: Canadian Perspectives on Human Rights
description: Key issues in the theory and practice of human rights in Canada. Topics will vary from year to year.

name: Government and Politics of the United States of America - GOVRT&POLTCS USA
description: The distinctive political system of the U.S. Covers all major institutions and processes, focusing on contemporary issues. Comparisons with the Canadian system. Sources of political failure and possible reform.

name: Government and Politics of the United States of America - GOVRT&POLTCS USA
description: The distinctive political system of the U.S. Covers all major institutions and processes, focusing on contemporary issues. Comparisons with the Canadian system. Sources of political failure and possible reform.

name: Southeast Asian Government and Politics - S E ASIA GOVT
description: The political systems of contemporary Southeast Asia.

name: Chinese Politics and Development - CHIN POLIT DEVEL
description: The course will explore various aspects of Chinese politics and the dynamics of China's development since 1949.  Topics include: the Cultural Revolution, political reform and protest, and economic reform policies and their consequences.

name: Communist and Post-Communist Politics
description: An examination of the origins, development, and demise of Communist political systems, as well as the nature of post-Communist politics, with special emphasis on the Soviet Union and its successor states.

name: Topics in Comparative Politics - COMPARATIVE POLI
description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

name: European Integration
description: Post-1945 integration of Europe, comparison of national politics and attitudes to integration, and the history and institutions of the European Union.

name: Topics in Comparative Politics - COMPARATIVE POLI
description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

name: Topics in Comparative Politics - COMPARATIVE POLI
description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

name: Topics in Comparative Politics - COMPARATIVE POLI
description: Topics will vary from year to year. Consult the departmental website.

name: Comparative Democratization
description: Literatures and theories on regime democratization around the world; the roles of political, economic, social, and international factors in encouraging or impeding democratization.

name: Contemporary Political Theory - CONTMP POLI THRY
description: Topics may include freedom, colonialism, capitalism, Critical Theory and ideology, power and knowledge, social justice, rationalism, gender and identity politics, and the "political."

name: Contemporary Political Theory - CONTMP POLI THRY
description: Topics may include freedom, colonialism, capitalism, Critical Theory and ideology, power and knowledge, social justice, rationalism, gender and identity politics, and the "political."

name: Contemporary Political Theory - CONTMP POLI THRY
description: Topics may include freedom, colonialism, capitalism, Critical Theory and ideology, power and knowledge, social justice, rationalism, gender and identity politics, and the "political."

name: Theories of State and Society
description: Classical origins of contemporary theories of the state, market, and civil society, focused on the relationship between social order, politics, and democracy. Readings from Smith, Toqueville, Weber, and contemporary sources.

name: Social and Political Thought - SOC&POLI THOUGHT
description: An examination of some of the major concepts in political philosophy such as justice, equality, rights, obligation, liberty in the context of both classical and contemporary political thought.

name: Law and Political Theory - LAW & POLI THRY
description: An examination of law and political theory that considers topics such as sovereignty, constitutionalism, civil disobedience, rights and the political role of judges.

name: Political Theory and Public Policy - THRY&PUBL POLICY
description: Application of frameworks to policy questions that factor in debates about citizenship and social inclusion, and an examination of contemporary normative frameworks that fall along, and transcend, the left-right political spectrum.

name: Public Policy - PUBLIC POLICY
description: An introduction to public policy: rationales for government intervention, the influence of interest groups and political institutions on policy outcomes, and the various stages in the policy process.

name: Comparative Politics of Public Policy
description: Policy making across industrialized democracies, with a focus on North America and Europe.

name: Environmental Politics and Policy
description: Domestic and international determinants of environmental policy; alternative approaches to environmental protection. The sustainable development paradigm; public opinion and interest group pressures; risk assessment; mandatory, voluntary and market-based policy instruments.

name: Canadian Foreign Policy - CANADIAN FOREIGN
description: An analysis of Canadian foreign policy on important international issues since the 1960s and of the policy-making process. Issues may include defence commitments, economic relations, activities of international organizations, and relations with the US, Europe, USSR, Asia and the Third World.

name: International Political Economy
description: An analysis of governmental policies and international political bargaining in regard to such issues as international investment, trade, and monetary relations. Pre-requisite: ECON 100 or 309 are recommended.

name: Issues in International Security - ISS IN INTL SECU
description: An examination of issues such as interstate conflicts, terrorism, environmental change, international crime. Topics will vary from year to year.

name: International Relations Theory and the International System - INT REL TH&IN SY
description: The evolution of the international system and empirical and normative theories of international relations such as realism, liberalism, and Marxism.

name: Security Studies - SECURITY STUDY
description: The contemporary international security context: reorientation of the study of security, patterns of inter- and intrastate conflict and communal violence, dilemmas of international response and conflict management.

name: Issues in International Conflict Management - IS INTCNFT MNGT
description: Problems of managing conflict in the international system (e.g., intervention, mediation, sanctions). Topics will vary from year to year.

name: Multinational Corporations and Globalization - MULTIN CRPS GLOB
description: Multinational corporations and the state in the contemporary international system, including the impact of multinationals and foreign direct investment on governments, societies, and industry.
prerequisite: (Third year standing. Previous completion of an introductory course in international relations (e.g. POLI 260 or its equivalent) is very strongly recommended.)

name: Global Environmental Politics - GLOB ENV POLI
description: Ecological consequences of the global political economy.

name: Nuclear Weapons and Arms Control
description: Evolution and contemporary significance of nuclear weapons and arms control policy and technology from the perspective of the physical and life sciences and the social sciences and humanities.
prerequisite: (Third-year standing in B.A. or B.Sc. progrm, or second-year standing in B.A.Sc. program)

name: The Politics of Terrorism
description: Exploration of contemporary terrorism as a contested area of understanding and as a social construct.  Includes origins and motives, evolution of terrorist groups, strategies and tactics, and anti-terrorism and counter-terrorism responses.

name: Quantitative Methods in Political Science
description: An introduction to quantitative methods as utilized in the study of Political Science. Not available for credit in the Faculty of Commerce and Business Administration.

name: Honours Seminar
description: An examination of the dimensions of Political Science and the major debates within the discipline.

name: China in World Politics - CHINA WORLD POLI
description: Impact and implications of the rise of China in historical and contemporary perspective.
prerequisite: (Third year standing. Previous coursework on international relations or POLI 321 are recommended.)

name: Law and Politics of the Canadian Constitution - CANADIAN CONSTIT
description: Seminar on the origins and development of the Canadian Constitution: the political aspects of federalism and the legal consequences of the Charter of Rights.
prerequisite: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

name: Topics in Canadian Politics - TPC CANADA POLI
description: This seminar examines in depth some of the important issues in Canadian politics.
prerequisite: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

name: Topics in Canadian Politics - TPC CANADA POLI
description: This seminar examines in depth some of the important issues in Canadian politics.
prerequisite: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

name: Topics in Canadian Politics - TPC CANADA POLI
description: This seminar examines in depth some of the important issues in Canadian politics.
prerequisite: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

name: Topics in Canadian Politics - TPC CANADA POLI
description: This seminar examines in depth some of the important issues in Canadian politics.
prerequisite: POLI 101 and one of POLI 301, POLI 302, POLI 303, POLI 304, POLI 305, POLI 306, POLI 307, POLI 308.

name: Advanced Topics in Comparative Politics - ADV TPCS CMP PLI
description: Seminar in comparative analysis of politics in democratic systems. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
prerequisite: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

name: Advanced Topics in Comparative Politics - ADV TPCS CMP PLI
description: Seminar in comparative analysis of politics in democratic systems. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
prerequisite: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

name: Selected Problems in Comparative Politics - SELECT PROB POLI
description: A seminar devoted to intensive analysis of a contemporary political problem from a comparative perspective, e.g., ethnic politics, class politics, the politics of post-industrial society. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
prerequisite: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

name: Selected Problems in Comparative Politics - SELECT PROB POLI
description: A seminar devoted to intensive analysis of a contemporary political problem from a comparative perspective, e.g., ethnic politics, class politics, the politics of post-industrial society. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
prerequisite: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

name: Selected Problems in Comparative Politics - SELECT PROB POLI
description: A seminar devoted to intensive analysis of a contemporary political problem from a comparative perspective, e.g., ethnic politics, class politics, the politics of post-industrial society. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
prerequisite: Two of POLI 220, POLI 320, POLI 321, POLI 322, POLI 323, POLI 324, POLI 325, POLI 326, POLI 327, POLI 328, POLI 329, POLI 330, POLI 331, POLI 332, POLI 333, POLI 350, POLI 351.

name: Ethics in Democratic Politics
description: Ethics in politics, including citizenship and public service, and practices demanded by the institutions of democracy.

name: Comparative Public Management - COMP PUBL MGMT
description: Major changes in the structures and processes of government in advanced democracies, including the welfare state, citizenship, ethics, accountability, and institutional reform.
prerequisite: (Restricted to Major/Honour POLI or Combined Major with POLI.)

name: Contemporary Political Theory - CONT POLI THEORY
description: This seminar examines the political ideas of leading political philosophers of the twentieth century. Consult the departmental website.

name: Politics and Economic Growth - POLI & ECON GRTH
description: The relationship between politics, economics, and development. The role of the state, political institutions, economic policy, and foreign aid in development strategies.

name: Democratic Theory - DEMOCRATIC THRY
description: Overview of traditional democratic theory with close readings of several contemporary theories, such as those of Habermas, Rawls, and Arendt. Readings are drawn from complete original texts, and assessment is based on a research essay.

name: Topics in Political Theory - TPCS POLI THEORY
International Relations Theory
description: This seminar examines some of the major theoretical approaches to the study of international relations. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
prerequisite: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370.

name: Problems in International Relations - PROB INTRL RELTN
description: Content varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website. One section (of 3 credits) is reserved for fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

name: International Interdependence
description: This seminar analyses issues relating to the politics of international economic relations. For specific content in a given year, consult the brochure issued by the Department.
prerequisite: One of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370, POLI 375. (6 credits of ECON are recommended.)

name: Problems in International Relations - PROB INTRL RELTN
description: Content varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website. One section (of 3 credits) is reserved for fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

name: Foreign Policy Analysis - FRGN POLICY ANLY
description: A seminar devoted to the analysis of the foreign policies of one or more states, as well as to the study of literature pertaining to foreign policy analysis. For specific content in a given year, consult the departmental website.
prerequisite: Two of POLI 260, POLI 360, POLI 361, POLI 362, POLI 363, POLI 364, POLI 365, POLI 366, POLI 367, POLI 368, POLI 369, POLI 370.

name: Problems in International Relations - PROB INTRL RELTN
description: Content varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website. One section (of 3 credits) is reserved for fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

name: Problems in International Relations - PROB INTRL RELTN
description: Content varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website. One section (of 3 credits) is reserved for fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

name: Honours Thesis
description: In consultation with faculty, students develop a research project, report on their project during seminars, give feedback on their fellow students' projects, and write a thesis.

name: Problems in International Relations - PROB INTRL RELTN
description: Content varies from year to year. Consult the departmental website. One section (of 3 credits) is reserved for fourth-year students in the Major program in International Relations.

Topics in Canadian Politics - TOPS CDN POLITCS

Issues in Comparative Politics - COMPAR POLITICS

Quantitative Techniques of Political Analysis - TECH POLI ANLYS
Quantitative Techniques of Political Analysis - TECH POLI ANLYS
Measurement and Data Analysis for Policy
description: Fundamental quantitative tools for policy analysis and program evaluation, including measurement, data visualization, and regression analysis. Introduction of skills for the design and implementation of quantitative policy analysis.

name: International Macroeconomics
description: Introduces challenges of an interlinked global economy through modern macroeconomics. International linkages through labor, capital and goods markets, monetary and fiscal policy linkages, currency and debt crises. Theory and real-world applications. Credit will be granted for only one of PPGA 500 or both PPGA 501, PPGA 502 or both GPP 501, GPP 502.

name: Economics for Policy
description: Fundamental principles of economics applied to public policy and global affairs. Credit will be granted for only one of PPGA 500 or both PPGA 501, PPGA 502 or both GPP 501, GPP 502.

name: Policy Analysis and Evaluation
description: Fundamentals of policy analysis and program evaluation for a professional context. Standard tools of policy analysis, risk assessment, and evaluation to design policy interventions and implement monitoring and evaluation systems for effectiveness. Case studies for government, international organizations, and NGOs.

name: Domestic and Global Policy Processes
description: Theories and frameworks related to policy-making processes at both the domestic and global levels. Agenda setting, policy formulation and stakeholder engagement, decision-making, policy implementation, and policy evaluation.

name: Public Management
description: Governmental implementation and delivery of public policy. Variations in international practice, the growing interdependence of governments, firms and non-government organizations. Complexities of multi-level governance including control and accountability of governments.

name: Policy in Context
description: Analytical tools for assessing policy in different cultural contexts, inter-cultural communication skills, ethics, and effective community engagement in policy work.

name: Communicating Policy
description: The role of media, especially new media, in effectively communicating policy to stakeholders. Focus on communications formats including written, oral, and multimedia policy communications.  Examples include policy briefs, presentations, and intercultural communications.

name: Professional Practice in Public Policy and Global Affairs
description: Analysis of professional practice in policy and global affairs, including potential alignment with personal values, strengths, and education. Development of essential professional skills including teamwork and project management.

name: Leadership for Policy Professionals
description: Practical leadership skills and competencies for policy professionals bridging theory to principles and practices in an interactive studio setting.

name: Research Design and Qualitative Methods
description: Research design principles and ethics. Methods for qualitative data collection and analysis to inform policy decision making. Focus on participant-observation, interviewing, focus groups, content and gender-based analysis.

name: Economics of Poverty
description: Micro-scale processes of development, including the challenges posed by persistent poverty, and ground-level development solutions. Measurement and empirical evaluation of development interventions and outcomes.

name: Development and Institutions
description: Introduction to macro-level long-term development processes by which societies improve their standards of living. Development theories, historical drivers; present debates; when and how public policies can best enable economic development.

name: Development Discourses and Practices
description: The meaning of development and micro/macro aspects of policy planning and implementation for development. The rise of development thought; assessment of the outcomes of development for different countries and communities.

name: Corporate Social Responsibility
description: Policy debates surrounding Corporate Social Responsibility including: voluntary regulation initiatives; responsibility to stakeholders in global supply chains; public-private partnerships; socially responsible investing; transparency; and protection of human rights.

name: Policy Dimensions of Energy Systems
description: Energy sources, markets, and impacts critical to energy policy, including oil, natural gas and coal markets; electricity and utilities policy; local and global environmental impacts; renewable energy; nuclear power and security; energy efficiency; technological innovation; and energy poverty.

name: Science, Technology, and Public Policy
description: Role and influence of science and technology in society, and its relationship to public policy development including: history and economics of technological change.

name: Sustainable Water Systems
description: Valuing, managing and sustaining water systems for agriculture, industry, the built environment, recreation and ecosystems including: service delivery, government intervention and policy responses; interrelationship between water and sanitation, resource recovery, and relationships between water systems and human development.

name: Asia Policy Practice
description: Practice-oriented course focused on current topics affecting policy in Asia.

name: Economic Foundations of Environmental Policies
description: Environmental and natural resource economics: externalities, property rights, public goods, market failure, inter-generational trade-offs, and optimal extraction of biological and depletable resources. Environmental regulation, industrial competitiveness, and distribution of income and welfare.

name: Global Governance: Frameworks and Policy Debates
description: Policy-making at the global level, including theories and frameworks of global coordination and global governance. Global, regional, and sub-regional mechanisms. Trade, finance, climate, food regulation, developmental norms, and security.

name: Resource Governance, Environment and Human Security
description: International policy processes associated with themes of environmental security: disaster prevention; resource curse; institution building and conflict minerals and global expropriation. Issues to be considered include human rights advocacy and peacekeeping, food security and food sovereignty.

name: Nationalism, Religion, and Ethnic Conflict in Asia
description: Ethnic and religious conflict in Asia related to historical and dialectic development of different forms of nationalism; the confluence between religion, ethnicity, and nationalist ideologies in the escalation of conflicts in different Asian societies.

name: Behavioural Foundations for Public Policy
description: Basic concepts in social and cognitive psychology, judgment and decision-making and behavioral economics in shaping policy formation and implementation. Application of experimental findings and concepts emanating from behavioral research to the design and implementation of policy.

name: Policy Responses to Global Climate Change
description: Climate science and impacts including: carbon management options; mitigation and energy system changes; efficiency options; 'end-of-pipe' solutions; vulnerability and adaptation to climate change; carbon economics and organization-level strategies in a carbon-constrained world.

name: Global Policy Project - GLOBAL POL PROJ
description: Professional team-based project that incorporates training, feedback on project proposals, possible field work, engagement with client organizations, data gathering and analysis, and a major deliverable such as a policy report.

name: Special Topics in Public Policy - TOPS PUBLIC PLCY
description: Offerings respond to current policy debates, topics of emerging interest, availability of visiting scholars, and interest in non-traditional courses incorporating practitioner expertise, interest in particular disciplinary perspectives missing from core courses and electives, and interest in specific regions or countries.

name: Global Policy Project - GLOBAL POL PROJ
description: Professional team-based project that incorporates training, feedback on project proposals, possible field work, engagement with client organizations, data gathering and analysis, and a major deliverable such as a policy report.

description: Offerings respond to current policy debates, topics of emerging interest, availability of visiting scholars, and interest in non-traditional courses incorporating practitioner expertise, interest in particular disciplinary perspectives missing from core courses and electives, and interest in specific regions or countries.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Reading and study in particular fields of study and research in psychiatry.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Reading and study in particular fields of study and research in psychiatry.

name: Introductory Punjabi
description: Spoken and written Punjabi. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 100/101 or PUNJ 102. Students who have taken Punjabi 11 in high school cannot take PUNJ 102 for credit.

name: Advanced Punjabi
description: Advanced grammar and conversation. Major genres of Punjabi literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 301/302 or PUNJ 300.

name: Intermediate Punjabi
description: Study of the grammar and introduction to Punjabi literature. As of 2011W, credit will be granted for only one of PUNJ 201/202 or PUNJ 200.

name: Introduction to the Western (Abrahamic) Religions: Judaism, Christianity, and Islam
description: An overview of the three main western monotheistic (Abrahamic) religions, together with the concepts used in studying religion, The focus will be on the origins and representative texts along with some historical development and current experience of each religion.

name: Scriptures of the Near East
description: An introduction to the scriptures of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.

name: Archaeology and the Bible
description: The impact of archaeological research on understanding the history and religion of ancient Israel.

name: Near Eastern and Biblical Mythology
description: An introduction to the world of Near Eastern mythology, from the Gilgamesh Epic to the Book of Genesis and beyond.

name: Modern Jewish Ethics in Historical Perspective
description: Readings from key texts in English translation, tracing how Jewish approaches to ethical issues evolved from biblical times to the present.

name: The Origins of Christianity: Literary Contexts
description: The origins of Christianity as reflected in the New Testament and contemporaneous literature.

name: Sex, Lies, and Violence in the Hebrew Bible
description: An exploration of the Bible's "dark side," with emphasis on texts that center on sex, deceit, and murder.

name: Jewish Law
description: History, sources, theoretical issues and current state of research about early Jewish legal traditions, focusing on close readings of classic primary texts in English translations.

name: The Life and Thought of Paul of Tarsus
description: The life and literature of Paul in the Roman imperial world: letter writing, patronage and power; Roman imperial iconography; Paul and community formation.

name: Topics in Religion - TPCS IN RELIGION
description: Consult the course registration information each year for offered topics.

name: Topics in Biblical Studies - BIBLICAL STUDIES
description: Studies in the history, literature, canon and text, and the religious thought of the Old and New Testaments. This includes the study of the cultural and religious milieu out of which these documents arose. Such studies require a competence in the canonical languages (Biblical Hebrew and/or Koine Greek), usually achieved by not less than two years of study.

name: Resource and Environmental Workshop - RESRCE&ENV WKSHP
description: Faculty and students from different disciplines act as an interdisciplinary team studying specific resource problems with ecological, economic, demographic and social dimensions. Techniques and methods are emphasized to show their value in integrating knowledge, defining policy and facilitating communication. Several sections with different emphasis offered each year.

name: Resource and Environmental Workshop - RESRCE&ENV WKSHP
description: Faculty and students from different disciplines act as an interdisciplinary team studying specific resource problems with ecological, economic, demographic and social dimensions. Techniques and methods are emphasized to show their value in integrating knowledge, defining policy and facilitating communication. Several sections with different emphasis offered each year.

name: Resource and Environmental Workshop - RESRCE&ENV WKSHP
description: Faculty and students from different disciplines act as an interdisciplinary team studying specific resource problems with ecological, economic, demographic and social dimensions. Techniques and methods are emphasized to show their value in integrating knowledge, defining policy and facilitating communication. Several sections with different emphasis offered each year.

name: Master's Seminar on Resources and Environment
description: Environment and resource management goals and issues.

name: Survey Design in Interdisciplinary Environmental Social Science
description: Survey design focusing on stated and revealed environmental preferences, choices, behaviour and values.

name: Resource and Environmental Workshop - RESRCE&ENV WKSHP
description: Faculty and students from different disciplines act as an interdisciplinary team studying specific resource problems with ecological, economic, demographic and social dimensions. Techniques and methods are emphasized to show their value in integrating knowledge, defining policy and facilitating communication. Several sections with different emphasis offered each year.

name: Qualitative Methods in Interdisciplinary Contexts
description: Research design, data quality, analysis, representation, ethics review, structured and unstructured interviews, field observations, survey design.

name: Human Technological Systems
description: Critical analysis of harms and benefits, and anticipation of global technological innovations, as they interact with social behaviour.

name: Ecosystem Services
description: Fostering sustainable management of ecosystem-based activities, for the competing and complementary ends of sustaining and enhancing human well-being and protecting biodiversity.

name: Climate Change: Science, Technology and Sustainable Development
description: Interdisciplinary science of climate change and its impacts; options for mitigation and adaptation.

name: Social Ecological Systems
description: Dynamics of environmental issues across temporal and spatial scales using disciplinary and interdisciplinary approaches to integrating sociological, cultural, and ecological perspectives.

name: Doctoral Seminar on Resources and Environment
description: Environment and resource management goals and issues.

name: Topics in Religion, Literature, and the Arts - TPC RELG LIT ART
description: The topic is selected and announced annually by the RGLA Committee.

name: Theory and Method in the Study of Religion
description: Theories and methods for the critical study of religion as believed and practiced in different times and places. Explores methodologies for studying dimensions of religion such as space, bodily practices, cognition, and material culture.

name: Introduction to the Study of Religion
description: Study of religion through a comparative, cross-cultural, and interdisciplinary approach to humans' engagement with the sacred. Examines religions as complex systems that share certain fundamental common features.

name: Advanced Concepts for Rehabilitation Research
description: Issues relevant to clinical investigations in rehabilitation. Emphasis on research design, measurement issues, selection of analytical approaches, and relevant epidemiological concepts.

name: Elements of Neuroanatomy and Neurophysiology
description: An introduction to the structure and function of the human nervous system.

name: Directed Studies in Rehabilitation - DST REHABILIT'N
Rehabilitation Theory
description: The history, evolution and analysis of conceptual systems underlying practice in occupational therapy and physical therapy.

name: Directed Studies in Rehabilitation - DST REHABILIT'N
Directed Studies in Rehabilitation - DST REHABILIT'N
Measurement for Assessment, Planning, and Evaluation
Current Topics in Rehabilitation - CUR TPCS REHAB
Directed Studies in Pathology in Rehabilitation
Physical Activity in Health and Chronic Conditions
description: Epidemiology, measurement, physiology, and adoption of physical activity in the prevention and treatment of chronic conditions.

name: Research Proposal
description: Development, appraisal and formatting of a research proposal. Emphasis on research writing and critical analysis of a variety of research proposal formats.

name: Writing to Enhance Practice - WRITE ENHANCE PR
Applying Research to Practice - APPLY RSRCH PRAC
Applying Research to Practice - APPLY RSRCH PRAC

name: Major Project, Part II - MAJOR PROJ PRT 2
prerequisite: RHSC 587. (Permission of the project coordinator is also required.)

name: Literatures and Cultures of the Romance World II: Modern to Post-Modern
description: An introduction to the main themes that shaped the Western part of Europe in the age of the nation state, imperialism, colonization, and decolonization.

name: Literatures and Cultures of the Romance World I: Medieval to Early Modern - LIT&CULT RMNCE I
description: An introduction to the main themes that shaped the Western part of Europe as its different national identities emerged in the Mediterranean sphere.

name: Studies in Romance Languages and Cultures
Studies in Romance Languages and Literature - RMNCE LANG & LIT
