Contemporary Topics in Biological and Cognitive Psychology
description: A focus on the interpretation of contemporary research in neuroscience, cognition, perception, memory, and learning.

name: Introduction to Developmental, Social, Personality, and Clinical Psychology
description: Introduction to methods and statistics, motivation, assessment, developmental, personality, clinical, and social psychology. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 100 and PSYC 102.

name: Introduction to Biological and Cognitive Psychology
description: Introduction to Methods and Statistics, Biopsychology, Learning, Perception, Memory, and Cognition. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 100 and PSYC 101.

name: Research Methods
description: Focus on various research methods used in psychology, with an emphasis on critical thinking and experimental design.  Restricted to students in the Faculty of Arts who have declared their major in one of Psychology, Cognitive Systems, or Speech Sciences (Linguistics Department). Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 217 or PSYC 277.

name: Contemporary Topics in Social, Developmental, Personality, and Clinical Psychology
description: A focus on the interpretation of contemporary research in social, developmental, personality, and clinical psychology.

name: Questioning Psychological Science in the Media
description: Use basic principles of quantitative psychological research methods to critique psychological claims presented in the media and to translate psychological science to everyday life. Intended for non-psychology majors to prepare for upper level courses. Majors should take PSYC 217 instead.

name: Analysis of Behavioural Data
description: Use of inferential statistics in psychology and conceptual interpretation of data; experimental design (laboratory, field research methods); presentation of data analyses in reports. PSYC 218 excludes credit for a number of other statistics courses in various departments. Please consult the Science Exclusion List (www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414) before registering. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 218 or PSYC 278.
prerequisite: One of PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (And a major in Psychology, Cognitive Systems, or Speech Sciences.)

name: Behavioural and Neuroscientific Research Methods
description: Research methods used in behavioural neuroscience. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 217 or PSYC 277.
prerequisite: Either (a) SCIE 001 and BIOL 140; or (b) one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121, CHEM 123 and all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140. (And second-year standing in a Behavioural Neuroscience specialization.)

name: Introduction to Behavioural Neuroscience
description: Foundational topics in behavioural neuroscience. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 260 or PSYC 270.
prerequisite: Either (a) SCIE 001 and BIOL 140; or (b) one of CHEM 111, CHEM 121, CHEM 123 and all of BIOL 121, BIOL 140. (And second-year standing in a Behavioural Neuroscience specialization.)

name: Analysis of Behavioural and Neuroscientific Data
description: Statistical methods for use in behavioural neuroscience. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 218 or PSYC 278.

name: Abnormal Psychology - ABNORMAL PSYC
description: The definition, history, and scope of abnormal behaviour; emphasis on the psychological factors that control its origins, maintenance, and modification.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101, 102, and PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 227.)

name: Brain Dysfunction and Recovery
description: Cognitive and behavioral impairments resulting from brain dysfunction. Focus on the efficacy of various intervention approaches.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101, 102, and PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: Tests and Measurements
description: Theory and practice of psychological measurement, statistical models for items and tests, assessment of test reliability and validity, factor analysis, scoring.

name: Infancy
description: Human cognition, perception, motor, social, emotional needs, brain development and their interactions from birth until the emergence of language.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101, 102, and PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: Brain and Behaviour
description: The neurobiological bases of behaviour; brain processes involved in perception, motivation, emotion, psychopathology, learning and memory. Open to all Arts and Science majors except those in the B.Sc. Psychology program. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 304 or PSYC 360.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and one of PSYC 216, or either PSYC 217 or 277, or either PSYC 260 or 270.)

name: Personality Psychology - PERSONALITY PSYC
description: Theory and research on individual differences in motivation, emotion, and social behaviour.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277)

name: Principles of Animal Behaviour - PRIN ANIML BEHAV
description: Behavioural neuroscience; behavioural genetics; social systems; mating and parental strategies; instinct and learning; evolution of human behaviour. Credit will be given for only one of BIOL 310 or PSYC 306.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: Cultural Psychology
description: Cultural influences on human thought and behaviour; interactions of culture and self; multicultural experiences; intercultural relations; methodological issues.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: Cognitive Processes - COGNTV PROCESSES
description: Contribution of cognitive processes to perception, attention, and memory; cognitive development, language, thinking, and creativity.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: Social Psychology - SOCIAL PSYC
description: Theory and research of individual social behaviour; social motivation; attitudes; group interaction; socialization; prejudice.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: Childhood and Adolescence
description: Human development from the preschool period through adolescence.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: Health Psychology
description: Health-related behaviours such as smoking and drug use; effects of stressful events on health; methods for coping with stress; impact of chronic illness on the family; social support systems.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277)

name: History of Psychology - PSYCHOLOGY HIST
description: The principal trends of psychological explanation and events in the history of psychology from the earliest times to the present. Open only to Major or Honours students or by permission of the instructor.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: Psychology of Sex Differences - PSYC OF SEX DIFF
description: Theory and research on gender development and the influence of sex and/or gender on cognition, emotion, motivation, social behaviour, and health.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: Applied Developmental Psychology
description: Applications of theories and research in developmental psychology to contemporary social issues; topics may include daycare, child abuse, divorce and remarriage, substance abuse, sexuality.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: Socialization: Media Content and Effects
description: Examines human development in the context of the socializing role of media.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: Forensic Psychology
description: The application of psychological theory and research to legal issues and the criminal justice system.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: Memory: Historical, Clinical and Cognitive Perspectives
description: Classical and contemporary metaphors for memory and their impact on theory development.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277. Non-PSYC students may substitute LING 420 or LING 200 and 201 for the above prerequisite.)

name: Gambling and Decision Making
description: The psychology of gambling behaviour, with emphasis on relevant work from judgment and decision-making, the cognitive neuroscience of choice, and clinical perspectives on disordered gambling.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: Adulthood and Aging
description: Issues, theories, and psychological research regarding adulthood and the aging process.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: The Psychology of Language I
description: Psychological abilities underlying human language; language processing, lexical representation, and principles of online conversation; animal versus human communication.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277. Non-PSYC students may substitute ENGL 329, or LING 420, or LING 200 and 201 for the above prerequisite.)

name: Directed Studies in Psychology - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Directed investigation of a problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
prerequisite: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

name: Directed Studies in Psychology - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Directed investigation of a problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
prerequisite: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

name: Honours Seminar
description: Orientation to psychological research, with special emphasis on ongoing research within the department; effective presentation of research findings, oral and written; critical evaluation of research. Requires a research project.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102; and all of PSYC 217, 218. (Restricted to students in Honours.)

name: Directed Studies in Psychology - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Directed investigation of a problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
prerequisite: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

name: Psychological Aspects of Human Sexuality - PSYC ASP HM SEXL
description: Human sexuality from a biopsychological, behavioural, and psychosocial perspective.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: Advanced Research Methods in Behavioural Sciences
description: Prepares students for graduate studies or other advanced behavioural research; experimental design and analytic techniques; laboratory with computer applications.
prerequisite: Either (a) one of PSYC 217, PSYC 277 and one of PSYC 218, PSYC 278; or (b) PSYC 366.

name: Neuroscience of Motivation
description: Experimental analysis of hunger, thirst, exploratory and curiosity behaviour, maternal and reproductive behaviour, fixed action patterns, and complex processes involved in social motivation with emphasis on the biological basis of motivation.
prerequisite: One of PSYC 260, PSYC 270, PSYC 304, PSYC 360, PSYC 370.

name: Neuroscience of Simple Learning
description: Introduction to basic theories of non-associative learning, classical and operant conditioning. Experimental findings from behavioural and biological analyses with animals and humans.
prerequisite: One of BIOL 260, BIOL 361, BIOL 455, BIOL 458, CAPS 301, PSYC 260, PSYC 263, PSYC 270, PSYC 304.

name: Evolutionary Psychology
description: Theory and research on the evolution of the human mind, with emphasis on implications for cognition and behaviour in contemporary environments.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 102 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: Cognitive Neuroscience
description: Current research into human brain systems underlying cognitive processes such as perception, attention, memory, and decision-making.

name: Sensory Systems
description: Anatomy and physiology of the sensory pathways and their relation to perception.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) all of PSYC 101, PSYC 102. (or (c) 6 credits of 200-level Psychology (but not 205 or 263).)

name: Perceptual Processing
description: Perceptual phenomena and their underlying brain mechanisms.

name: Behavioural Neuroscience II
description: Neurodevelopment and neuroplasticity, the physiological bases of several motivated behaviours (sleep, sexual behaviour, hunger and eating, drugs and addiction), cognition, the stress response, and brain dysfunction and recovery.

name: Directed Studies in Behavioural Neuroscience - DIR STDY BEHV NS
description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem in Behavioural Neuroscience requiring a written report of the findings.
prerequisite: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits, permission of the supervisor, and permission of the department.)

name: Directed Studies in Behavioural Neuroscience - DIR STDY BEHV NS
description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem in Behavioural Neuroscience requiring a written report of the findings.
prerequisite: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits, permission of the supervisor, and permission of the department.)

name: Directed Studies in Behavioural Neuroscience - DIR STDY BEHV NS
description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem in Behavioural Neuroscience requiring a written report of the findings.
prerequisite: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits, permission of the supervisor, and permission of the department.)

name: Cooperative Work Placement II
description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full-time. Normally taken in fourth year Winter Session, Term 1. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

name: Behavioural Neuroscience I
description: Advanced methods and topics in behavioural neuroscience.
prerequisite: One of PSYC 260, PSYC 270 and one of PSYC 217, PSYC 277 and one of PSYC 218, PSYC 278.

name: Cooperative Work Placement I
description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full-time. Normally taken in Summer Session after third year. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

name: Psychology of Religion
description: Cognitive, emotional, and motivational underpinnings of religious behaviour; supernatural beliefs, magical thinking, ritual, sacrifice; religion's role in morality, prosociality, health, violence, and intergroup relations.
prerequisite: One of PSYC 217, PSYC 277, PSYC 366 and one of PSYC 305, PSYC 307, PSYC 308, PSYC 358.

name: Cognitive Neuropsychology
description: The structure of the mind as revealed by brain injury, neurological illness, and surgical intervention.  Topics include attention, memory, language, sense of self, topographic awareness, moral reasoning, emotion, theory of mind, and social awareness.
prerequisite: Either (a) one of PSYC 217, PSYC 277 and one of PSYC 218, PSYC 277; or (b) PSYC 366 and one of PSYC 309, PSYC 365.

name: Social and Personality Development
description: Comprehensive overview of the psychological processes in the social and personality development of infants, children, and adolescents.
prerequisite: One of PSYC 302, PSYC 315, PSYC 319, PSYC 322, PSYC 325.

name: Special Topics in Psychology - SP TPCS IN PSYC
description: Intensive examination of selected topics and issues in psychology.
prerequisite: Either (a) one of PSYC 217, PSYC 277 and one of PSYC 218, PSYC 278; or (b) PSYC 366.

name: Environmental Psychology
description: Psychological theory and research on the interaction between organisms and the physical environment; emphasis on applications to the design and management of constructed and natural environments.  Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 421 or PSYC 321.
prerequisite: Either (a) PSYC 100 or (b) two of PSYC 101, PSYC 102, PSYC 205, PSYC 207, PSYC 208, PSYC 216, PSYC 217, PSYC 277. (Strongly recommended: PSYC 101 and either PSYC 216 or one of PSYC 217 or 277.)

name: Clinical Psychology
description: Theoretical and research foundations of the processes of assessment and behaviour modification in clinical psychology. Credit will be granted for only one of PSYC 400 or PSYC 401.

name: Advanced Seminar in Psychology
description: Investigation of an issue, topic, or phenomenon in psychology, focusing on research deeply within a subfield or integrating research across subfields.
prerequisite: Either (a) one of PSYC 217, PSYC 277 and one of PSYC 218, PSYC 278; or (b) PSYC 366. (Restricted to Majors and Honours in Psychology. Consult Section Notes or the Psychology Department website for 300-level course(s) recommended for a specific offering.)

name: Directed Studies in Psychology - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
prerequisite: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

name: Directed Studies in Psychology - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
prerequisite: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

name: Directed Studies in Psychology - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem, requiring a written report of the findings.
prerequisite: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits and permission of a faculty member who is prepared to supervise the investigation.)

name: Honours Seminar and Essay
description: Students carry out a research project and report on its development during seminars. Students also discuss research by Departmental staff, with emphasis on choice of problems, research design and data analysis.
prerequisite: PSYC 349. (Fourth-year standing. Restricted to students in Honours. Intended for students in their graduating year.)

name: Behavioural Neuroendocrinology
description: Detailed examination of the interaction between hormones and neural control of reproductive and non-reproductive behaviours; emphasis on gonadal and adrenal hormone effects on learning and memory in the brain.

name: Advanced Neuroscience of Motivation
description: Neurobiological pathways mediating five core aspects of motivated behaviour: (1) affective decision making; (2) motivated drive; (3) goal-directed vs. habit-based behaviour; (4) learning from negative reinforcers; and (5) disorders of motivation.

name: Drugs and Behavioural Neuroscience
description: Introduction to neurochemical systems and functional neuroanatomy; animal models of human cognitive processes and mental disorders; neurochemical foundations and treatments for mental disorders.
prerequisite: One of PSYC 304, PSYC 360, PSYC 371. (BIOL 205 and/or PCTH 325 recommended.)

name: Neuroplasticity and Behaviour
description: Experimental findings and theory documenting the plasticity of the brain and its relationship to behaviour: emphasis on gene regulation, neurogenesis and cell morphology changes in relation to learning and experience.
prerequisite: One of PSYC 304, PSYC 360, PSYC 371, PSYC 460.

name: Directed Studies in Behavioural Neuroscience - DIR STDY BHV NEU
description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem in Behavioural Neuroscience requiring a written report of the findings.
prerequisite: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits, permission of the supervisor, and permission of the department.)

name: Directed Studies in Behavioural Neuroscience - DIR STDY BHV NEU
description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem in Behavioural Neuroscience requiring a written report of the findings.
prerequisite: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits, permission of the supervisor, and permission of the department.)

name: Directed Studies in Behavioural Neuroscience - DIR STDY BHV NEU
description: Directed investigation of an experimental problem in Behavioural Neuroscience requiring a written report of the findings.
prerequisite: (At least 72% average in the preceding 30 credits, permission of the supervisor, and permission of the department.)

name: Cooperative Work Placement III
description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full-time. Normally taken in fourth year Winter Session, Term 2. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

name: Cooperative Work Placement IV
description: Approved and supervised relevant work experience in an industrial, academic, or government setting for a minimum of 13 weeks, full time. Normally taken in Summer Session after fourth year. Work term report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Psychology (B.Sc.).

name: Biopsychology of Motivation
description: Not offered each year; consult Department of Psychology.

name: Advanced Methods in Social Psychology and Personality
description: To be offered in alternate years only.

name: Clinical Psychology Practicum - CLIN PSYC PRACTM
Ethical and Professional Issues in Clinical Psychology
Seminar in Psychological Problems - MULT REGRESS
Seminar in Psychological Problems - MEASRMNT IN PSYC
Seminar in Psychological Problems - MLTILVL MODL
Seminar in Psychological Problems - STRUCT EQ MODEL
Special Topics in Cognitive Neuroscience - TOP COG NEUROSCI
Psychoneuroendocrinology
description: Not offered each year; consult Department of Psychology.

name: Special Topics in Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience - DEV COG NEUROSCI
Introductory Sanskrit
description: Basic vocabulary and most important grammatical features of classical Sanskrit. Useful to students of South Asian history, culture, languages, philosophies, and religions, and of linguistics and classics. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 300 or SANS 102 or both SANS 100, SANS 101 or both SANS 301, SANS 302.

name: Intermediate Sanskrit
description: Advanced grammar and selected readings. Credit will be granted for only one of SANS 400 or SANS 200 or both SANS 201, SANS 202 or both SANS 401, SANS 402.

name: Basic Russian II
description: Continuation of RUSS 101.

name: Second-Year Russian I
description: Intermediate oral practice, grammar, reading, composition. A special section may be provided for Science students. Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS 201 or RUSS 200.

name: Basic Russian I
description: Introduction to contemporary Russian. Oral practice, grammar, reading, and writing.

name: Second-Year Russian II
description: A continuation of RUSS 201. Intermediate oral practice, grammar, reading, composition. A special section may be provided for Science students. Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS 202 or RUSS 200.

name: Nineteenth-Century Russian Writers in Translation
description: The writings, lives, and thought of selected authors.

name: Twentieth-Century Russian Writers in Translation
description: The writings, lives, and thought of major Russian authors.

name: Third-Year Russian I
description: Advanced intermediate oral practice, syntax and composition. Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS 301 or 300.

name: Third -Year Russian II
description: Advanced intermediate oral practice, syntax and composition. Credit will be granted for only one of RUSS 302 or RUSS 300.

name: Russian Literature in Translation - RUSS LIT IN TRAN
description: A comprehensive historical and critical presentation with emphasis on the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.

name: Imagining Location in Russian Literature (in English) - LOCATION RUSSLIT
description: Russian literature and film, focused around a particular geographical and cultural location.

name: Topics in Russian Culture (in English)
description: Features of Russian culture with an emphasis on historical and social contexts. Specific course content will vary. Consult CENES for this year's offerings at https://cenes.ubc.ca/undergraduate/slavic-studies/russian-minor/

name: Fantastic Worlds in Russian Fiction (in English) - RUSSIAN FICTION
description: Russian genre fiction and film (science fiction, fantasy and gothic).

name: Fourth-Year Russian - FOURTH-YEAR RUSS
description: Advanced oral practice, reading and composition.

name: Vikings and Norse Mythology (in English)
description: History, literature, and mythology of early Scandinavian societies.

name: Scandinavian Cinema (in English)
description: An introduction to the cinemas of the Scandinavian region.

name: Scandinavian Crime Fiction (in English)
description: Crime fictions and films as a mirror of Scandinavian society.

name: Topics in Danish and Northern European Cultural Studies (in English).
description: Selected topics, such as ethnicity, migration, identity, women's issues, Danish and Northern European film.

name: The World of the Sagas (in English)
description: Scandinavian contributions to medieval and early modern world literature, culture and history.

name: Science One A
description: Block registration marker for the biology, chemistry, mathematics and physics components of the Science One program.  Restricted to students in the Science One program.
prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 11 or (b) BIOL 12; and all of CHEM 12, CALC 12, PHYS 12, ENGL 12. (and Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12.)

name: Science One
description: An innovative first-year multi-disciplinary course incorporating biology, chemistry, mathematics, and physics with a strong focus on the connections between these traditional disciplines.  See the Science One website (www.scienceone.ubc.ca)  for further information and the application process for admission to SCIE 001.
prerequisite: Either (a) BIOL 11 or (b) BIOL 12; and all of CHEM 12, CALC 12, PHYS 12, ENGL 12. (and Principles of Mathematics 12 or Pre-calculus 12.)

name: First-Year Seminar in Science
description: Small-group experience where students study science in society, scientific process, and how to communicate scientific concepts.  Enrolment limited to students with first-year standing in the B. Sc. program in Science.

name: Communicating Science
description: Effective communication and presentation skills in science.

name: Sustainability for Community and the World
description: Explores systems thinking in the context of sustainability and also re-examines the familiar three pillar model of sustainability - society, ecology, and economics - highlighting its uses and limitations.
prerequisite: One of ASIC 200, ASIC 220, APBI 260, APBI 265, ARCL 309, BIOL 230, CHEM 301, CHEM 302, CHEM 341, CIVL 200, CONS 330, ECON 210, ENDS 221, ENVR 200, ENVR 300, EOSC 270, EOSC 340, FRST 100, GEOG 211, GEOG 310, HIST 106, ISCI 360, ISCI 361, LAW 386, LFS 250, PHYS 333, POLI 351, PSYC 321, SCIE 120. (Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.)

name: Literature and Film in Eastern Europe - LIT&FLM EAST EUR
description: Films and translated literature by Slavic writers with emphasis on the interaction between politics and literature.

name: Advanced Soil Processes
description: Integration of soil physics, chemistry, and biology in understanding essential soil processes.

name: Land and Water Resource Evaluation
description: Topics in land and water system evaluations and assessing resource development options; monitoring and modelling environmental systems.

name: Watershed Science
description: Watershed evaluation, key aspects of hydrology, water quality, land use impacts on water resources and integration of multiple land use activities and their cumulative impacts.

name: Water in International Development
description: Key water issues associated with international development: global water demand, scarcity, efficiency of use, water as a commodity, biophysical and policy aspects of water management, water and health, land use impact, water harvesting, improved irrigation, and pollution prevention.

name: Instrumentation for Biometeorology
description: The theory, design and evaluation of instrumentation for biometeorological research. Consent of instructor.

name: Topics in Social Work Practice I - SOWK PRACTICE I
description: Examinations of the foundation, knowledge and competencies underlying various topics in generalist social work practice. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program

name: Introduction to Social Work Practice
description: An introduction to the knowledge, skills and values of social work practice in its many forms, emphasizing different ways of understanding the context of social and personal problems.

name: Introduction to Social Welfare
description: An introduction to the perspectives, concepts and theoretical foundations of social welfare, including an analysis of the institutional structures of social welfare in the modern state.

name: Interviewing Skills - INTERVIEWING SKL
description: Communication theory and interviewing skills and their application to the Social Work interview. Enrolment is limited to students in the BSW program.

name: Topics in Social Work Practice I - SOWK PRACTICE I
description: Examinations of the foundation, knowledge and competencies underlying various topics in generalist social work practice. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program

name: Topics in Social Work Practice I - SOWK PRACTICE I
description: Examinations of the foundation, knowledge and competencies underlying various topics in generalist social work practice. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program

name: Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
description: Integrates students' learning from field, practice, policy and theory courses for the purposes of professional development.

name: Practicum I
description: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail.

name: Indigenous Peoples and Critical Social Work Analysis
description: Contemporary social issues facing Indigenous peoples and communities examined in the context of the history of Settler-Canadian/Indigenous relations; the impact of Settler-Canadian institutions upon Indigenous peoples; implications for social policy and social work practice. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 325 or 425. Enrolment is limited to students in the BSW program.

name: Culture and Race in Social Work Practice
description: Issues and problems inherent in practising social work in diverse cultural settings.

name: Canadian Social Policy
description: Analysis of race, gender, class and culture as factors in the distribution and delivery of Canadian social benefits and social services.

name: Social Work Practice II
description: This course examines the principles of optimal social work process with individuals, small groups, families and larger collectivities.

name: Practicum II
description: A supervised practicum in an assigned social service, two days a week throughout the program year. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program. This course will be graded Pass/Fail.

name: Advanced Integrative Seminar in Social Work Theory, Policy and Practice
description: Development of professional judgement, evaluation, and self-evaluation in practice.

name: Introduction to Social Work Research
description: Theory and conduct of social research as applied to social welfare and social work practice. Development of social work research questions and design of studies. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the school. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 420 or 320.

name: Integrative Seminars in Social Work - INTGRTV SEM SOWK
description: A series of seminars offered during the final term of studies which address salient issues in social policy and social work practice and draw upon combined knowledge from social work and related disciplines.

name: Integrative Seminars in Social Work - INTGRTV SEM SOWK
description: A series of seminars offered during the final term of studies which address salient issues in social policy and social work practice and draw upon combined knowledge from social work and related disciplines.

name: Integrative Seminars in Social Work - INTGRTV SEM SOWK
description: A series of seminars offered during the final term of studies which address salient issues in social policy and social work practice and draw upon combined knowledge from social work and related disciplines.

name: Integrative Seminars in Social Work - INTGRTV SEM SOWK
description: A series of seminars offered during the final term of studies which address salient issues in social policy and social work practice and draw upon combined knowledge from social work and related disciplines.

name: Social Context of Child Development
description: The ways in which the familial, physical, and social environment effects the life structures, opportunities and outcomes of epigenetic developmental processes.

name: Policy and Practice in Child Welfare
description: Covers the statutory bases and practices associated with the continuum of child welfare services from prevention through permanency planning.
prerequisite: SOWK 441. (or another course in child development.)

name: Social Work Practice in Community Mental Health
description: Online course providing overview of social work services to persons with a mental illness.

name: Disability and Justice
description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course considers how health and human service professionals can effectively practice with people with disabilities from a social justice perspective. Social and personal context and practice responses are examined. Offered as IHHS 407 prior to September 2015. Credit will be granted for only one of SOWK 453 or IHHS 407.

name: Advanced Social Work Practice: Mental Health
prerequisite: (A version of SOWK 440 with a focus on mental health, or equivalent (as specified by the School), including one-year employment experience in BC Mental Health system.)

name: Social Work Practice with Individuals and Couples - INDIVDUALS&CPLS
Topics in Social Analysis for Social Work Practice
description: Theoretical considerations of relevance to social work practice.

name: Social work Practice with Groups - GROUPS
Communities and Social Development: Debates, Approaches and Fields of Practice - CMNTY & SC DEV
Social Work Practice in the Field of Aging
Social Work Practice with the Family - THE FAMILY
Quantitative Methods in Social Work Research - RSCH-QUANT MTHDS
Advanced Integrative Seminar
description: Advanced development of professional judgment, critical reflection, and integration of theory, practice, research, policy.

name: Qualitative Methods in Social Work Research - RSCH-QUALT MTHDS
Directed Field Studies in Social Work II - DIR FLD STUDIES
Directed Studies in Social Work - DIRECTED STUDY
Directed Studies in Social Work - DIRECTED STUDY
Directed Studies in Social Work - DIRECTED STUDY
Social Work Doctoral Seminar
description: Critical examination of research, teaching, proposal writing and publication.

name: Social Theory, Ideology and Ethics
description: Critical analysis of major social theories, differentiating competing approaches to understanding human behaviour; social theory, social ideology, and social ethics.

name: Special Studies in Social Work - SPEC STDS SOWK
description: Lectures, seminars and/or individual tutorials to develop knowledge and skills in relation to a defined theory, policy or practice problem or client population. Enrolment is limited to students in the B.S.W. program, except by permission of the School.

name: Elementary Spanish I
description: Expansion of fundamentals. Enhanced ability to exchange information, discuss the past and future, and express wishes, hopes and feelings in common personal and social contexts. Aligned with CEFR level A1-A2 objectives.

name: Beginners' Spanish II
description: Continuation of foundational elements of the language. Communicate using essential vocabulary in common tasks and situations related to past, present and future events. Aligned with CEFR level A1 objectives.

name: Beginners' Spanish I
description: Fundamentals of the Spanish language. Communicate with basic vocabulary in common tasks and situations related to present and future events. Aligned with CEFR level A1 objectives.

name: Conversational Spanish II
description: Builds on communication skills through discussion, debate, and presentations; exploration of cultural topics through discussion of written texts and other media. May include experiential learning projects involving native speakers from the Hispanic community.

name: Elementary Spanish II
description: Expansion of fundamental notions and presentation of more elaborate structures in a variety of tenses and modes. Communicate to explore Hispanic culture and to hypothesize about present and past situations. Aligned with CEFR level A2 objectives.

name: Conversational Spanish I
description: Emphasizes communication skills through discussion, debate, and presentations; developing oral fluency and listening comprehension, through discussion of written texts and films. May include experiential learning projects involving native speakers from the Hispanic community.

name: Introduction to Hispanic Literature
description: Major texts, authors, periods, and genres of Hispanic literature; key concepts, terminology, and practices of literary analysis that serve as a foundation for higher-level Spanish literature courses.

name: Revolution! (in English)
description: Concepts, theories, and practice of protest, revolt, and revolution in the Hispanic world, highlighting the intersection of politics and culture through novels, poetry, letters, diaries, and/or historical accounts of specific revolutionary uprisings.

name: Introduction to Hispanic Culture
description: Media, figures, periods, and genres of Hispanic culture; key concepts, theories, and practices of cultural analysis that serve as a foundation for higher-level Spanish culture courses.

name: Intermediate Spanish I
description: Complex grammatical structures in context to enhance proficiency. Explores relevant cultural topics through reading, writing, and discussion. Aligned with CEFR level B1 objectives.

name: Hopscotch: Topics in Hispanic Literature (in English) - HISPANIC LIT
description: Spain and Latin America's contributions to global culture through popular Hispanic literature in translation.

name: Intermediate Spanish II
description: Expansion of and reflection on the use of complex grammatical structures in context to broaden lexical repertoire.  Enhances proficiency through reading, writing, and discussion of relevant cultural topics. Aligned with CEFR level B1 objectives.

name: Tradition and Diversity in Spanish History and Culture
description: Conservation and progress on the Iberian Peninsula, from the Middle Ages to the present. Includes the first modern European state and its diverse cultures.
prerequisite: One of SPAN 202, SPAN 207. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

name: The Golden Age of Peninsular Literature and Culture
description: Tradition, faith, conflict, prosperity, and decadence in literature and everyday life from the Middle Ages to 1700.
prerequisite: SPAN 221. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

name: Divergent Visions: Peninsular Literature and Culture since 1700
description: Modern Spanish literature and culture, from Empire to the European Union. Includes Romanticism, Modernism, Republicanism, and Separatism.
prerequisite: SPAN 221. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

name: Colonial Encounters in Spanish-American Literature and Culture
description: Spanish colonialism in the Americas from the Conquest to the 1820's and the dawn of Independence. Includes coloniality, hybridity, subalternity, and autonomy.
prerequisite: SPAN 221. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

name: Modern Magics: Spanish-American Literature and Culture since the 1820s
description: Literary engagements with modernity in the Spanish Americas, from the 1820's to the present. Includes civilization, progress, politicization, and violence.
prerequisite: SPAN 221. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

name: Upper Intermediate Spanish I
description: Strengthening fluency and accuracy in spoken and written communication. Emphasis on mediation, interpretation, and metalinguistic competencies through translation and comparative stylistics. Aligned with CEFR level B2 objectives.
prerequisite: SPAN 302. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

name: Ascent and Decline: Topics in Golden-Age Peninsular Literature and Culture
description: Selected areas of study relating to sixteenth- and seventeenth-century Spain. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.
prerequisite: SPAN 221. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

name: Imperial Eyes and Foundational Fictions: Topics in Spanish-American Colonial and Nineteenth-Century Culture - SP-AM CL< 19C
description: Selected areas of study relating to colonial and/or nineteenth-century Spanish America. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.
prerequisite: SPAN 221. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

name: Peoples and Nations: Topics in Twentieth- and Twenty-First Century Spanish-American Culture - 20&21C SP-AM CLT
description: Selected areas of study relating to modern and/or contemporary Spanish America. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.
prerequisite: SPAN 221. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

name: Research Intensive Seminar in Hispanic Literature and Culture
description: Theories and methodologies of the discipline. Consult the Department for this year's offering.
prerequisite: SPAN 221. (Or successful completion of a language placement exam or an assessment interview.)

name: Literary and Cultural Theory - LIT CULT THEORY
Transatlantic Hispanic Literatures and Cultures - TRANS HISP LIT
Peninsular Literature of the Eighteenth, Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries
Hispanic Languages, Literatures and Cultures - HISP LANG LIT
Contemporary Latin-American Literatures and Cultures - CTP LAT-AM LIT C
Introduction to Sociology
description: Introduction to problems in the analysis of social structures and processes. Basic sociological concepts will be introduced and their application demonstrated in various areas of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 100 or both SOCI 101, SOCI 102.

name: Social Interaction and Culture
description: Culture, identity, social interaction, relationships and socialization. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 101 or SOCI 100.

name: Inequality and Social Change
description: Inequality, institutions, social structure and social change. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 102 or SOCI 100.

name: Canadian Social Structure
description: Descriptive and analytic survey of such features as demographic characteristics, class structure, ethnicity, and regional variation in Canadian society as a basis for understanding current social issues.

name: Research Methods
description: Introduction to research designs and methodologies.
prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Sociology of Family
description: An introduction to contemporary family forms and relations.

name: Sociology of Indigenous Peoples
description: Sociological perspective of Indigenous peoples and issues both internationally and within Canada.

name: Shopping, Society, and Sustainability
description: Major theories of consumer society, evaluating impacts of shopping on human and non-human environments and popular solutions to these impacts.

name: Introduction to Social Interaction
description: A general introduction to research on social interaction, with an emphasis on group (as opposed to individual) processes and behaviour. Topics include: status, power and prestige, distributive justice, marginality and social control, authority relations, and group structure and membership, all to be studied in the context of a variety of groups (such as families, formal organizations, communities and friendship groups) and cultures.

name: Crime and Society
description: Crime as a social phenomenon, with emphasis on the changing definitions of crime in relation to social and political change in Canadian and other societies. The scope and nature of the crime problem, the growth of criminology as a science and profession, and relationships between components of state criminal justice systems.

name: Citizenship and Identity
description: The concepts of citizenship, identity, and human rights as social processes shaping individuals and communities (both local and global).

name: Ethnic and Racial Inequality
description: A critical examination of classical and contemporary theories and research evidence concerning ethnic and racial inequality at the societal and interpersonal levels.

name: Sociology of Migration
description: Sociological approaches to the movement of peoples and its impact over time.

name: Canadian Society
description: Social organization of Canadian society: relationships between social institutions and social processes (e.g., economics, education, family, law, media, and politics); including issues of ancestry, ethnicity, gender, region, and social class.

name: Gender Relations
description: The nature of gender relations, their social and cultural expression, and theories of gender inequality.

name: Diversity in Family Forms
description: An examination of diversity within and between families and of diverse family forms.
prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Social Statistics I
description: The testing of sociological theories using quantitative data analysis techniques on numerical data from social surveys, experiments and official statistics. SOCI 328 excludes credit for a number of other statistics courses in various departments. Please consult the Science Credit Exclusion List (www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414) before registering.

name: Consumers and Consumption
description: The structure and culture of consuming and consumption.

name: Community Studies
description: Study of the organization of human communities; a focus upon collective activities including family, work, neighbourhood, and formal and informal networks.

name: Organization of Work
description: The meaning of work and leisure. Properties of work organization: division of labour and specialization; technology and working knowledge; means of coordinating work, such as cooperation, authority, and exchange. Research problems concerning work in households, offices, and industry, division of labour by gender, industrial democracy and the relation of work and social inequality.

name: Sociology and Natural Resources
description: Sociological perspectives on property, resource industries (such as agriculture, fishing, forestry and mining), resource development, and resource communities. May also include examination of social aspects of resource development in the Third World.

name: Social Inequality
description: Tendencies toward equality and inequality; manifestations of inequality (occupation, education, gender, ethnicity, income, power) and their consequences; caste and class features of major stratification systems; theories of social class; stratification profile of contemporary industrial societies.

name: Built Environments
description: Physical, social, and economic aspects of built environments, including housing and community planning.

name: Sociology of Sexualities
description: Historical and social construction of sexual identities, desires, communities, and politics in the twentieth century.
prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Sociological Theories: Classical and Contemporary Approaches
description: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems, and current topics in the field of sociological theory. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 370 or both SOCI 371, SOCI 372.

name: Classical Traditions in Theory
description: An examination of selected traditions, conceptual problems and topics in the foundational theories of sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 371 or SOCI 370.

name: Contemporary Directions in Theory
description: A survey of theories in contemporary sociology. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 372 or SOCI 370.

name: Sociological Methods: Survey Research
description: Questionnaire design, interviewing, sampling, and analysis of survey data.
prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217 and SOCI 328.

name: Sociological Methods: Qualitative Research
description: Examination of the different traditions of qualitative sociological inquiry and the associated methodological features used to study the interpretive practices and meanings in the everyday lives of individuals.
prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

name: Sociology of Health and Illness
description: Classic and contemporary sociological perspectives on health, illness, and health care.  Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 384 and SOCI 484.

name: Sociological Methods: Historical Research
description: Methodological problems and research strategies associated with the interpretation of socio-historical data; contributions of classical and contemporary approaches to historical sociology and social history.
prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 217.

name: Selected Topics in Canadian Society - COVID & SOCIETY
description: Selected areas of study relating to Canadian society such as BC Studies; French Canada's demographic problems; rural communities; social welfare and community programs in Canada. Consult the Department for this year's offerings.

name: Feminist Theory
description: The emergence of feminist theory, its relationship to sociology, and the major theoretical schools of thought. The social basis and development of feminist thought from critiques of scholarship and research to contemporary debates will be addressed.

name: Theories of Family and Kinship
description: Theoretical approaches to the study of the family and family forms.
prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Social Statistics II
description: Primary emphasis on applications of statistical techniques to data in Sociology.
prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102 and SOCI 328.

name: Sociology of the Environment
description: Sociological approaches to the study of environmental conflicts, issues, movements, impact of changing technology, economic development on the environment.

name: Drugs and Society
description: Social dimensions of the causes, consequences, regulation, and treatment of substance use from Canadian and international perspectives.

name: Sociology of Food
description: Cultural, economic, and political aspects of food production and consumption, including connections to class, ethnicity, and gender.  Food-related social movements will be included.

name: Urban Sociology
description: Demographic, behavioural, and organizational aspects of urban structures and of urbanization in different societies and periods.

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under the supervision, of a Department faculty member selected by the student.
prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102. (And permission of the Department.)

name: Directed Studies - STU DIRECTED SEM
description: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under the supervision, of a Department faculty member selected by the student.
prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102. (And permission of the Department.)

name: Directed Studies - DIRECTED STUDIES
description: General reading and/or a research undertaking, with the agreement, and under the supervision, of a Department faculty member selected by the student.
prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102. (And permission of the Department.)

name: Sociology of Development and Underdevelopment
description: Processes of social change in the Third World and other developing countries. Major themes stress the relationship between urbanization and industrialization; modernization and ethnic conflict; imperialism, neo-colonialism, and foreign aid; and intra-national modernization problems such as regional underdevelopment in industrial societies.

name: Society, Economy and Family
description: The study of family in social and economic contexts. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 441 and FMST 440.
prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Honours Tutorial
description: Requires the presentation of at least one research paper. Restricted to students in the Sociology Honours program.

name: Sociology of the Arts
description: An examination of the arts as social practices from the standpoint of the relationships among artists, critics, patrons, and public; and the social institutions through which these relationships are structured.

name: Economic Sociology
description: Analysis of economic actions and institutions using the concepts and methods of sociology.

name: Social Determinants of Health
description: Relationships between social phenomena (e.g., personal beliefs, lifestyle practices, social support, socio-economic status, social class, gender, and ethnicity) and the health of human populations.

name: Sociology of Crime and Justice
description: Critical examination of specific forms of crime and delinquency in relation to the criminal justice system including law, enforcement, and corrections. Issues selected for study will be further scrutinized within the cultural framework of ethics, morality, and social justice.

name: Contemporary Chinese Society
description: Current social topics in Chinese society; perspectives on gender, inequality, culture, and social relations.

name: Sociology of the Environment - SOCI OF ENVIRON
Analyzing Quantitative Data in Sociology
prerequisite: (SOCI 502 is a prerequisite for Sociology graduate students. A background in material such as that covered in SOCI 502 is highly recommended for all others.)

name: Health, Illness and Society - HLTH, ILL&SOCTY
Families and Work
description: The effect of combining family and work roles. Credit will be granted for only one of SOCI 442 and FMST 442.
prerequisite: One of SOCI 100, SOCI 101, SOCI 102, SOCI 200.

name: Canadian Health Policy and the Healthcare System
description: Analysis of topical Canadian health policy issues including an historical overview of the health care system, health care funding, public / private financing, health care personnel and pharmaceutical policy challenges.

name: Government, Business and Health Care Policy
Basic Finance
description: Fundamental concepts of asset pricing and corporate finance.

name: Strategic Human Resources Management
description: Aligning the management of human resources with organizational strategy. Best practices in HR management, as well as the role of health care leaders in effectiveness and efficiency.

name: Organizational Behavior
description: The effects of individual and group behaviour on organizational processes and outcomes. The organization as an actor and how it behaves in different types of environments.

name: Economic Evaluation
description: Maximizing health benefits from health care budgets.

name: Health Care Priority Setting
description: Application of priority setting and resource allocation methods to improve health from the perspective of the policy maker, health professional, and patient.

name: Operations and Logistics
description: The application of management tools and principles to production and allocation problems.

name: Information Technology for Management
description: The role of IT in health care management, the importance of effective IT in a health care setting, and the strategic uses of IT.

name: Design and Measurement 1
description: Basic concepts and methods in Epidemiology.

name: Program Planning and Evaluation
description: Basic concepts and principles underlying program planning and evaluation in health services.

name: Application of Statistics in Management
description: Data analysis and statistical inference. Applications in assessment of the legitimacy and significance of reports.

name: Biostatistics
description: Data collection, numeric and graphic summarization, and elementary statistical analysis. Examples primarily from health sciences.

name: Quality of Health Care
description: Current concepts, methods, and applications in health care quality assessment and improvement.

name: Ethics and Ethical Decision Making in Health Care
description: Ethical dilemmas in the health care setting. Understanding how Ethical features of the system may contribute to or perpetuate some of these problems.

name: Selected Topics - SEL TOP
description: Current and emerging trends and issues.

name: Selected Topics - SEL TOP
description: Current and emerging trends and issues.

name: Directed Studies - DIR STUDIES
description: Opportunity to focus on a selected topic under faculty supervision.

name: Research Project - RES PROJECT
description: Completion of a bounded project within a health agency and under individual faculty supervision. Honours/Pass/Fail.

name: Social Determinants of Health
description: Foundations of population health. An overview of research on determinants of health, with an emphasis on the social determinants of health.

name: Understanding the Sociocultural Determinants of the Health of Populations
description: The Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the idea of "population health," and the implementation and evaluation of programs or policies to improve health. Open to all students. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 200 or IHHS 200.

name: Working in International Health
description: This is a tutored, web based Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course on planning/preparing for work in a developing country. Causes of ill health amongst populations living in poverty; analysis of available solutions. Health Science background not essential. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 300 or IHHS 300.

name: Topics in Health Informatics for Health/Life Sciences Students
description: Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 302 or IHHS 302.

name: Selected Topics - PUBLC HLTH ETHCS
description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

name: Selected Topics - GENDER & HEALTH
description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

name: Selected Topics - ENVIRNMTL HLTH
description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

name: Selected Topics - CAN HLTH POLICY
description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

name: Statistics for Health Research
description: Planned collection, numeric and graphic summarization, and elementary statistical analysis of data. Examples primarily from health sciences illustrate standard techniques for parametric and non-parametric hypothesis testing; regression and correlation; contingency tables. Also randomization, "blindfolding" and other specifically biomedical topics in statistics. Class size may be limited.
prerequisite: (Ability to use high school Algebra and simple graphs.)

name: Special Topics in Population and Public Health - PRISON HEALTH
description: Selected topics will vary.  Multiple versions may be taken. This course takes an interprofessional approach and population/public health perspective in addressing current issues in healthcare and health-related fields.

name: Special Topics in Population and Public Health - DH RESRCH MTHODS
description: Selected topics will vary.  Multiple versions may be taken. This course takes an interprofessional approach and population/public health perspective in addressing current issues in healthcare and health-related fields.

name: Analysis of Longitudinal Data from Epidemiological Studies
description: To explore and compare methods of analyzing continuous and categorical longitudinal data. The issues of missing data and errors in measurement/misclassification will be covered in depth.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of HCEP 400, HCEP 500, HCEP 502 or (b) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 500, SPPH 502 or (c) all of SPPH 500, SPPH 502, SPPH 567.

name: Analytical Methods in Epidemiological Research
description: Basic epidemiological designs as a framework for commonly used biostatistical techniques such as the Mantel-Haenszel, chi-squared, linear and logistic regression, and survival analysis. Computer packages will be available for computation of assignments.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of HCEP 400, HCEP 502 or (b) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 502 or (c) all of SPPH 567, SPPH 502.

name: Improving Public Health: An Interprofessional Approach to Designing and Implementing Effective Interventions
description: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course promotes collaborating interprofessionally. Each student team will identify and research a critical public health issue, and develop a detailed practical and effective intervention. Intended for students in health and human service programs. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 410 or IHHS 410.

name: Epidemiological Methods 2
description: Critical thinking in epidemiology; principles and methods of study design; context for epidemiological investigations of human health.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of HCEP 400, HCEP 502 or (b) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 502.

name: Application of Epidemiological Methods
description: This second level course will teach research trainees to apply methods taught in prior courses towards the development of a fundable research protocol and the analysis and interpretation of real epidemiologic data.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of HCEP 400, HCEP 500, HCEP 502 or (b) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 500, SPPH 502 and one of SPPH 503, SPPH 506, SPPH 519, SPPH 530.

name: Epidemiological Methods 1
description: Sources and uses of epidemiologic data for health services planning and administration including methods of data collection and study design.
prerequisite: (Enrolment in a Health Care and Epidemiology graduate program, or permission of instructor.)

name: Quantitative Research Methods
description: Major quantitative research designs, measurement reliability and validity, common data sources used, internal and external validity, research proposals, and peer review. Credit will be granted for only one of SPPH 506 or SPPH 548.

name: M.Sc. Research Seminar
description: SPPH 507 in conjunction with SPPH 607 is a required course for students in the M.Sc. program. Students present and discuss their research and other topics of interest.

name: Cancer Control and Epidemiology
description: Collection and analysis of epidemiological data on cancer; genetic, occupational, and other risk factors; analytic techniques; cancer control, prevention, screening, early detection, and policy issues.

name: Survey Methods in Health Measurement
description: Concepts and techniques of measurement in epidemiological research.  Topics covered include validity, reliability and misclassification, scale design and the construction of questionnaires and indices for both health outcomes and exposures.

name: M.P.H. Practicum
description: Includes a significant component of applied epidemiology and biostatistics in a field setting.

name: Clinical Epidemiology
description: Principles and methods of epidemiology are applied to clinical problems. Evaluation and design of laboratory and clinical tests and of therapeutic interventions.
prerequisite: Either (a) one of HCEP 400, HCEP 502 or (b) one of SPPH 400, SPPH 502.

name: Decision Analysis in Health Care
description: Methods and application of decision analysis to improve health from the perspective of the policy maker, health professional, and patient.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of HCEP 400, HCEP 502 or (b) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 502.

name: The Design and Analysis of Clinical Trials
description: Ethical considerations, intention-to-treat versus efficacy trials, principles of sampling and exclusion, methods of allocation and techniques of randomization, parallel versus cross over design, monitoring treatment outcomes, adverse effects, stopping rules, analytic techniques and data interpretation, and logistical issues in the management of clinical trials.
prerequisite: Either (a) one of HCEP 502, HCEP 513 or (b) one of SPPH 502, SPPH 513.

name: Surveillance and Monitoring in Public Health
prerequisite: Either (a) all of HCEP 400, HCEP 502 or (b) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 502.

name: Methods for Systematic Reviews in Health Research
Qualitative Methods in Health Research Design
description: Purposes, context, procedures, and relationships within qualitative health research and methologies.

name: Control of Communicable Disease
description: Epidemiology of viral, bacterial and parasitic infections with emphasis on the control of these infections in human populations. Immunization programs will be stressed.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of HCEP 400, HCEP 502 or (b) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 502.

name: Topics in Environmental Health
description: Role of air, water, food and solid waste as sources of human health risks; global environmental health issues; sustainability.

name: Global Health and Human Security
description: Global threats to human health stemming from conflict, poverty, and environmental degradation.

name: Issues and Concepts in Public Health
description: History of public health research and practice; occupational and environmental health; health services and systems; social and lifecourse determinants of health; and population health and emerging trends.

name: Social Determinants of Health
description: Foundational thinking giving rise to the concept of population health.  Overview of the current state of research.

name: Major Essay
description: Required for all M.H.Sc. students.

name: Health Care Systems Analysis
description: Theory, concepts, measurement, and practical skills using administrative data for analysis of health care systems.

name: Principles of Occupational and Environmental Hygiene
description: Scientific basis for the recognition, evaluation, and control of chemical, physical, and biological, exposures; standard setting; exposure monitoring methods.

name: Aboriginal People and Public Health: Ethics, Policy, and Practice
description: Experience of colonization; Indian Act; the histories and intergenerational impact of the residential school; child-welfare systems; communicable disease prevention; the challenge of ethical public health practice; and traditional healing.

name: Perinatal Epidemiology
description: Indicators of maternal/newborn well-being across population subgroups, changing trends in obstetrical intervention, perinatal morbidity, and the analysis of perinatal data.

name: Toxicology and Public Health
description: Mechanism of action of commonly encountered occupational toxic agents; relevance of laboratory and epidemiological evidence.

name: Program Planning and Evaluation
description: Examines the concept of evaluation in health services and how various methodological approaches can be used in evaluative studies.
prerequisite: Either (a) all of HCEP 400, HCEP 502 or (b) all of SPPH 400, SPPH 502.

name: Economic Evaluation
description: Economic evaluation of health service interventions and programs, with emphasis on methods and components of program costing.

name: Canadian Health Policy
description: Analysis of the evolution and structure of the Canadian health care system.

name: Health Technology Assessment for Health Policy
description: This course is an advanced program evaluation course.

name: Community Health Promotion
description: Practice and community-based (participatory) research related to health promotion, including its historical and philosophical roots. Application of social and behavioural theories to participatory research and the planning, implementation, and evaluation of community health promotion initiatives.

name: Introduction to Health Economics
description: Broad understanding of the health system and health system change from an economics perspective, with a focus on delivery, organization, and financing of healthcare.

name: Public Health Approaches to Substance Use and Addictions
description: Critical examination of strategies regarding addictive behaviours, substance use and related problems, in the context of a multi-disciplinary approach.

name: Health Care Priority Setting
description: Resource allocation, economics and ethics based approaches for decision making, uptake of evidence to inform resource use in health care.

name: Risk and Communication in Public Health
description: Theory and practice of risk communication in public health, basic principles underlying effective science communication with peers, the media, and the public.

name: Principles and Practices of Injury Prevention
description: Injury epidemiology; surveillance; development, implementation, and evaluation techniques of preventive strategies; determinants of health; social marketing; injury policy; evidence-based prevention strategies; utilization of injury datasets.

name: Foundations of Public Health Computing
description: Data gathering, cleaning, analysis, and visualization to produce key results using statistical software.

name: Chemical and Biological Hazard Measurement
description: Industrial hygiene and environmental exposure monitoring, methods, and instrumentation, and theory. Laboratories demonstrate workplace sampling and analysis techniques.

name: Technical Aspects of Chemical and Biological Hazard Control
description: Industrial ventilation, heating and air conditioning systems, respiratory protection, chemical protective clothing.

name: Occupational Hygiene Practice
description: Application of occupational hygiene principles using field investigations, critical appraisal of results, and communication with labour and management.

name: Quantitative Methods for the Assessment and Analysis of Exposure Data
description: Determinants of exposure, sampling strategies.

name: Safety
description: Safety management; systems analysis; accident investigation; collection of accident data; fault trees; total loss control.

name: Industrial and Environmental Acoustics and Vibration
description: Fundamentals of acoustics and vibrations, physiologic effects, measurement, instrumentation, interpretation of data, industrial standards, and control.  For students in Occupational and Environmental Hygiene; other graduate students may enrol with permission of the instructor. Credit will only be given for one SPPH 569 or MECH 505.

name: Public Health, Transportation, and the Built Environment
description: Health issues associated with transportation and the built environment; design of urban form for non-motorized transportation for the improvement of personal and environmental health; factors that impact transportation choices; applying findings from research to specific transportation planning processes and projects. Credit will be granted for only one of PLAN 579 or SPPH 571.

name: Introduction to Indigenous Health Research Ethics
description: Principles and regulatory requirements related to conducting health research with Indigenous communities.

name: Social Determinants of Indigenous Health
description: Survey of impacts of land and resources, housing, education, criminal justice systems, child apprehension and other determinants on the health of Indigenous peoples in Canada.

name: Collecting, Analyzing and Using Public Health Data in Indigenous Communities
description: Applied biostatistics, epidemiology and data management addressing public health priorities and clinical research in Indigenous communities.

name: Selected Topics - DATA ANALYSIS
description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

name: Selected Topics - SELECTED TOPICS
description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

name: Selected Topics - GLOBAL HEALTH
description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

name: Selected Topics - KNOWLDGE TRNSLTN
description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

name: Selected Topics - PED NTR PUB HLTH
description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

name: Selected Topics - ETHICS EBM
description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

name: Selected Topics - SELECTED TOPICS
description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

name: Indigenous Health Policy in Canada
description: Indigenous health policy and history in Canada through four substantive areas: economics and financing; need and demand; ethics, rights and law; quality and effectiveness.

name: Introduction to Quantitative and Qualitative Research Methods in Indigenous Health Research
description: Qualitative, quantitative and mixed methods research as applied to Indigenous public health priorities.

name: Occupational and Environmental Hygiene Project
description: Applied project on approved topic based on practicum: requires a written and oral report.

name: Mental Health Care and Delivery in Indigenous Communities
description: Approaches to mental health and resilience concepts and strength based interventions with Indigenous communities.

name: Approaches to Enquiry in Population and Public Health
description: Research approaches in the area of population and public health; focus on developing research questions and the centrality of research questions in conducting research.

name: Ph.D. Research Seminar
description: Required course in Ph.D. program. Topics of current interest will be presented and discussed by students and various faculty.

name: Selected Topics - SELECTED TOPICS
description: By seminar and directed readings, certain topics of current interest are explored in depth.

name: Core Seminar in Science and Technology Studies
description: Thematizes the relations of historical, philosophical, literary, rhetorical, sociological, and anthropological approaches to science and technology.

name: Proseminar in Science and Technology Studies
description: Classic work in the history, philosophy, rhetoric, and sociology of science, and the development of a unified science and technology studies.  Required for all students in the STS Program.  This course is co-taught.
prerequisite: (Enrolment in STS Program or permssion of the STS Advisory Committee.)

name: Master's Colloquium in Science and Technology Studies
Doctoral Colloquium in Science and Technology Studies - STS PHD COLLOQ
Elementary Statistics for Applications
description: Classical, nonparametric, and robust inferences about means, variances, and analysis of variance, using computers. Emphasis on problem formulation, assumptions, and interpretation. See the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion Lists: www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
prerequisite: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.

name: Statistical Inference for Data Science
